SKE 83, Lee 1958, 111, МССНЯ 356, ОСНЯ 1, 225. One of the few PA monosyllabic roots. The relation of the Turk. form is somewhat dubious (for semantic and phonetic reasons). One may conjecture that the original shape was PT *Ka- - actually attested in OT, see EDT 578 - which was early substituted by *Ko- under the influence of the more widespread *Kod- and then disappeared altogether.
A Mong.-Kor. isogloss.

Rozycki 85 (TM-Mong.). Despite Doerfer MT 51, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong. The Mong. form presents some difficulties: apart from the unclear variant *ganča, the form *gagča itself can only belong here if it is an irregular development < *gagči < *gagti, or if it is a contraction of a derived form *gagta-ča. Note that Jpn. *kàtà may also be derived from PA \U*kal(t)o\u q.v.
Murayama 1962, 107. An interesting common Altaic cultural term.

Мудрак Дисс. 102. Cf. also Kalm. gejǖn, WMong. gejeɣün 'grievous, gloomy' (perhaps < *gaju-gi- with secondary fronting). Note the peculiar *-d- in PT, reflected as -j- (not -r-) in Chuv.: perhaps we should rather reconstruct *Kaj(i)-dgu for early PT, with subsequent development either > *Kajgu or > *Kadgu.
A Western isogloss; maybe the same root as \U*gằju\u ('sorrow' > 'surprise'?)
Mong. gelme- 'to be scared, afraid' is probably a variant reflex of the same root - despite KW 133, Poppe 25, АПиПЯЯ 18, Дыбо 14, all connecting it with TM *ŋēle-.
An Eastern isogloss.
VEWT 226, ТМС 1, 138. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.

Ramstedt (SKE 415) thinks of a loan Kor. > Turk., which is highly improbable (see TMN 1, 415); despite late attestation in Turkic the root may well be archaic. For TM one should suppose the original meaning children of smb.'s concubine(s)"."
Владимирцов 250, АПиПЯЯ 295, KW 132 (Turk.-Mong.). A Western isogloss.
A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss. It is interesting to note the Old Turkic title qapaɣan which may be = OJ kabane and Mong. gabĳa(n).

KW 145, Владимирцов 391, Poppe 24 (Turk.-Mong.; but ТМ *ŋāla 'hand, arm' cannot belong here), Колесникова 1972a, 95-97; АПиПЯЯ 290, Дыбо 310-311, Лексика 247. Borrowing in Mong. < Turk. is quite improbable, despite Щербак 1997, 134 (even Doerfer in TMN 1, 207, 3, 461 describes the Turk.-Mong. match as Zufall" - which in all his works is actually a synonym for "cognate")."

Martin 251 (Kor.-Jpn.), Lee 1958, 111 (Kor.-TM). Fronting in Turk. is unclear (*Kaŕ would be normally expected). The Kor. word may also reflect \U*kale\u q.v. (Joki 1963, 154); in any case, it actually reflects a suffixed form *gàŕ[a]-KV (cf. Man. GarGa) or *kale-kV.

A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. On a possible reflex in PT see under *gājrV; if PT *Kāŕ at least partially reflects the present root, it would be an argument to reconstruct PA *gāso with a long *ā. One should also note Kor. dial. kesani 'goose' (KED 109) - if it is not a derivative of PK *kə̀jú 'goose' (see under *kúja).
The root reveals some phonetic irregularities - probably because of contaminations with \U*két`o\u 'much, many' and \U*kadi(rV)\u 'strong, tough' q.v.

KW 152, SKE 128, Poppe 24, Ozawa 89-90, Miller 1986a, 55. The development 'fur on paws' > 'shoe' in Mong. and Jpn. may well have been independent, but one has also to reckon with a possibility of ancient borrowings (especially because of some phonetic irregularities in Mong.).
Дыбо 10. Verbal low tone in Kor.
EAS 113, Poppe 18, Цинциус 1972, 6, АПиПЯЯ 80, Лексика 171, TMN 3, 387 (onomatopoetisch"). The Turk. form is probably contaminated with *Kās == TM *gasa 'crane
column17: duck'
column18: which should explain the exceptional preservation of vowel length. See also comments to *ki̯ujilV and *gi̯ằla."

REFERENCE: Because of the peculiar shape of the Turkic form one should perhaps reconstruct *gā́jt`i.
Владимирцов 209, Poppe 48, АПиПЯЯ 14, 280. One of several similar PA roots (see *k`ā́p`a, *k`epa, kèp`i, k`i̯ā̀bu).
A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*kup`e,\u \U*gupu.\u
EAS 48, Владимирцов 206, Poppe 24, 53, Колесникова 1972a, 101-103, ОСНЯ 1, 228, АПиПЯЯ 71; Дыбо 4. Despite Doerfer's criticism (TMN 1, 492) the root still holds.
The PT form has an irregular *-k-, most probably under the influence of the synonymous PA root \U*kak`i\u ( > PT *Kek-).
Дыбо 14, Федотов 1, 270-271.

АПиПЯЯ 99, 274. The verb loses the final resonant in Jpn., Kor. and in some forms of the Turkic paradigm: this must be an archaic feature (also present in some other frequently used verbs), speaking perhaps in favour of the root's original monosyllabic structure (*gèl).
Cf. also notes to *k`ŏ́mi.
The original meaning may be reconstructed as 'to be unexpected' / 'not expect smth.'.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Poppe 25, KW 133, ОСНЯ 1, 226-227 (despite Doerfer's criticism in TMN 1, 489 the forms are perfectly semantically compatible).
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. Cf. *gi̯ūp`a.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
KW 134, Poppe 25, 80 (Turk.-Mong.). Cf. also Old Koguryo *kŭš (Lee reads *kɨl, Miller 1979 emends to *kŭnš, which is hardly correct).
Cf. various similar bird names in TM: Evk. goriwkī 'swallow' (ТМС 1, 161); Orok kiru, kireu 'crane' (ТМС 1, 399); Oroch kurau, koro; Evk. karaw, karawul 'gray crane' (ТМС 1, 379).
A Western isogloss.
KW 135. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss; despite TMN 1, 489, Doerfer MT 79, hardly a borrowing in TM < Mong. (because of semantic differences).
Cf. \U*gŭ̀k`a,\u \U*k`i̯úŋu\u, \U*k`ōki.\u
One of the common Altaic navigation terms.
A Western isogloss.

A Western isogloss. The isolated Karakh. form may be borrowed < Sak. käbä 'well-bred horse'; perhaps a better match in Turkic would be *Kojn 'sheep' (Лексика 431, ЭСТЯ 6, 24-26) ( > Mong. qoni(n) > Evk. konin etc., see TMN 3, 564, Щербак 1997, 139, Doerfer MT 37; despite KW 194 and Poppe 70, hardly a common Altaic *koni). In that case Turk. *Kojn < *Kobi-n, with a subsequent reconstruction of PA *gi̯abo(nV).

Kalm. kāčə- (WMong. kĳači-, KW 222) 'to split (wood)' is probably borrowed from the Turk. derivative *Kɨjgač- (although the latter  now means basically 'slant', the original meaning was 'cut aslant'). If the latter was the original meaning in PA, one could also compare Mong. *geji-, *geje- 'slanting, oblique' (otherwise see notes to *k`i̯úŋ(k)u).

KW 136, ОСНЯ 1, 230. In TM cf. also a variant *kilbe- / *kilt- 'glitter' (ТМС 1, 393, 394; hence Yak. kilbej-, kɨlbaj-; but Dolg. gilbej-, gɨlbaj- may be directly < Mong.; see Kał. MEJ 103, Stachowski 86, 87). Since Mong. also has a variant *gilt- (MMong. (MA) qiltai-, WMong. giltagir, giltuji-, Kalm. giltəgṛ, giltī-, KW ibid.), the TM forms may be borrowed from Mong. (see Doerfer MT 21-22, Rozycki 89). Note that Jpn. *kìrà- may also reflect PA \U*gari\u q.v.
EAS 110, Лексика 76, Miller UAJ 1986, 47, Miller 1996, 114.
A Western isogloss; cf. *gi̯ā́ĺu.
KW 133. Cf. Evk. gimdigī- 'to break (of a belt, strap)' (ТМС 1, 152).
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
SKE 112, АПиПЯЯ 296. In Turkic the root is contaminating with the reflex of *k`ā̀re q.v.
A Western isogloss.

Cf. also some similar roots: \U*gokV,\u \U*ki̯omga,\u \U*k`ema\u (with possible mergers). Medial -m- in Turk. may be either due to these mergers, or a result of labial assimilation (*gEmürgen < *gEŋürgen). The Jpn. form must go back to a suffixed *gi̯aŋ(u)-gV.
ЭСТЯ 3, 11, JOAL 125, 126, АПиПЯЯ 74, 289, Дыбо 13.
The match is possible if TM *girke- is a secondary contraction < *giarke-. Another possibility would be to suppose *girke- < *gerki- and reconstruct PA *gĕrV.
The meaning 'acacia' is surprisingly well reconstructable for this root.
The original meaning is well reconstructable as to lag behind > become separated". The derivative *gi̯ā́la-kV 'separation
column17: lagging' is reflected in PTM *giala-ku 'separated space
column18: room' and the denominative *gal-gi- in Mongolian."

REFERENCE: A specific common Altaic cultural term.
Very scantily represented in Turkic, so basically a Mong.-Kor. isogloss; not quite reliable.
ТМС 1, 167. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Basically a TM root, but cf. Yak. kej- 'to butt'. Jpn. *k(ù)i 'fang' may belong here, too - but see under \U*k`i̯ùge\u). On the whole, rather dubious as a common Altaic etymon.
АПиПЯЯ 294. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. Poppe 24, 75 compares the TM stem with Mong. ɣolu-mta 'hearth', but cf. rather \U*gi̯ūĺo.\u
The Turk.-Manchu match is semantically straightforward; the Jpn. match is phonetically plausible, but less certain semantically.

АПиПЯЯ 288, Miller-Street 1975, 108ff (with a somewhat different distribution of roots). MKor. kằr-hằi-  < *kə̀r-hằi- through assimilation (?). The root tends to contaminate with a number of similar roots: see \U*k`irga,\u \U*k`iregV,\u \U*kiro.\u
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
The medial consonant behaves irregularly: the Turk. and Mong. forms point to an intermediate *gi̯ogo, probably a result of assimilation < *gi̯oko.

Лексика 78, Doerfer MT 143. Cf. also Mong. geji- 'to dawn' (KW 137), proving that *geɣe- < *geje-. The Korean form points to a cluster with *-j-, therefore a reconstruction *gi̯òjnu (with subsequent assimilative palatalization -jn- > -jń-) is perhaps more plausible; cf. also the variation *n/*ń in PT. The Jpn. reflex is somewhat problematic: loss of final resonant here may be explained by a standard development before a velar suffix (*ka < *gi̯òjn(u)-gV, cf. Mong. *gege-ɣe, Man. geŋ-ǵe); but one would rather expect a PJ form like *ku(i). The irregular vowel may be due to contraction, cf. a similar case in PJ *ká 'mosquito' < PA *kúńe.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss, with very similar semantic developments. Лексика 212. {Cf. WMo ɣuldaŋ, ɣulduŋ 'arch (as of a bridge or gate)'}.
Cf. \U*kŏp`e,\u \U*k`àpe.\u
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
EAS 148, Poppe 25, Doerfer MT 73. Cf. \U*gṓp`i.\u
ТМС 1, 150 (Mong.-Tung.). A Western isogloss.
One of several similar roots (cf. \U*ki̯ajo,\u \U*ki̯aju\u) tending to contaminate, which may explain some irregularities (notably, tone and irregular -a- in Jpn.).
A common derivative *gi̯ū̀la-bV- is reflected in Turkic, Mongolian and TM.
Cf. \U*gi̯ola.\u
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. Cf. *gep`V.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. Cf. perhaps Mong. *gergei 'wife' (if not derived from *ger 'house'; Mong. pl. gergen > Yak., Dolg. kergen 'family', see Kał. MEJ 28, Stachowski 145).
KW 156, Владимирцов 160, 272, Poppe 24, 49, Ozawa 202-203, Miller 1985, 145, АПиПЯЯ 81.

EAS 48, KW 150, SKE 121, Martin 245, Whitman 1985, 191, 222, Martin 1996, 39, АПиПЯЯ 19, 70. Mong. cannot be borrowed from Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 139.; the isolated Manchu form may be < Mong. (see TMN 1, 439, Doerfer MT 116, Rozycki 91), but not necessarily so.
EAS 90, SKE 124 (despite Doerfer's - TMN 1, 422 - doubts, the comparison seems impeccable), Miller 1985, 144-145, АПиПЯЯ 15, 68, Ozawa 18.

MEANING: to be diligent, persistent, to endure
REFERENCE: Cf. \U*ki̯ū́di,\u \U*kit`u.\u
KW 153, Владимирцов 160, 319.
The Jpn. form reflects a contraction *kía < *kV́ja, frequent in roots with medial *-j-.

MEANING: a k. of reed or leek
REFERENCE: A Turk.-Mong. isogloss: not quite reliable because of late attestation, but borrowing in either direction seems improbable. Cf. \U*gi̯aŋu,\u \U*ki̯omga,\u \U*k`ema.\u
Poppe 19, 51, АПиПЯЯ 288, 295. The Mong. and TM forms reflect a derivative in *-dV (probably originally locative). See also a discussion under *gudA.

MEANING: a k. of weapon for sea-hunting
REFERENCE: A common Altaic cultural term.
The word is rather scantily represented in Turkic and Mongolian, but borrowing is rather improbable.
KW 157, Дыбо 8, Лексика 188 (Doerfer TMN 3, 527 regards the Turk.-Mong. match as aus lautlichen Gründen mindestens unwahrscheinlich")
column17: although phonetically the match is quite plausible. The Kor. form is not quite clear morphologically (kūmp(j)əŋ(i) < *kūŋ-p(j)əŋ
column18: a compound with some unclear second component?)
column19: but semantically matches the other forms very well."

REFERENCE: A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss.
PKE 85, АПиПЯЯ 281, Дыбо 14. ? Cf. Mong. girkaj 'having good eyesight'.
It is not quite clear whether Mong. and TM reflect a common derivative *got`ò-gV (with assimilation -g- > -k- in TM) or these are independent derivations.
Jpn. \I*ki\i must be a result of early secondary contraction (*kəj- > *ki).
An interesting Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*gi̯ube.\u
Martin 231 (Kor.-Jpn.)
A Western isogloss. The root is homonymous with *gōŕa 'to starve' (except that the final vowel is uncertain here), but it seems impossible to reduce the two roots to a single entity.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.

Lee 1958, 111, ТМС 1, 166 (Tung.-Kor.). Not a very reliable root.  Note that the Manchu form may belong here only if it is separated from TM *gugda 'high, tall' (see under *gók`i), which is not necessarily so. The reflex -t- in Kor. points rather to *-t`- (unless one presumes secondary morphonological analogies). One wonders if all the forms present here do not actually represent reflexes of *gok`-dV, the suffixed form of PA *gók`i.
Дыбо 12, Martin 236. The root contains a rare medial cluster *-jŕ-.
Cf. \U*gék`á,\u \U*k`i̯úŋu\u, \U*k`ōki.\u
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss; cf. perhaps also MMong. gölme, WMong. gölme, Ord. gülme 'skin of ox or swine, saddle cloth'.
An expressive root; not quite reliable because of scanty reflexation in TM and possible contaminations with \U*gebo\u et al. On a possible reflex in Turk. see under \U*kobu.\u

Martin 248. In Kor. the word seems to be related to kằr- 'to grind, pulverize' - but this meaning is probably secondary (the verb originally means 'to polish, whet'). The tone discrepancy between Kor. and Jpn. should be explained either by the secondary influence of this verbal stem in Korean, or by contraction in Japanese (where *kuà < *gur(e)-ga); the first explanation seems more probable because the vowel reflex in Korean is also not quite regular (*-o- would be normally expected).
A Western isogloss. See Лексика 230.
Despite Poppe (1960,18 etc.) the TM form cannot be compared with Mong. qola 'far'.
Poppe 25, 107, Miller 1996, 154, Tekin 1979, 127. Korean has standard verbal low tone.
Martin 246. Korean has a usual verbal low tone.
PTM and Korean reflect a common derivative *gúri-nV-. Note that Mong. *gura 'roebuck' is to be kept apart, see *ŋurV.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. АПиПЯЯ 17, Мудрак Дисс. 41, Rozycki 92. ? Cf. OJpn. kasu 'dregs'.
EAS 48.
A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*koli,\u \U*k`i̯uli,\u \U*k`iĺa.\u
Poppe 24, KW 155, ОСНЯ 1, 234, АПиПЯЯ 291. Verbal" low tone in Korean. There are several "mental" verbs of the type KUNV in Altaic
column17: and they are not always easy to distinguish from each other. Besides *gū̀no 'think' cf. also notes to *kḕńu 'distress
column18: envy'
column22: torture'). On the whole this produces an extremely complicated etymological situation
column23: and we are not sure we have disentangled everything correctly."

REFERENCE: The root is not widely attested, but seems quite reliable.
Ozawa 209-210, KW 156. The original meaning may be reconstructed as 'deteriorate', with two directions of semantic development ( > a) 'to become mad, enraged'; > b) 'to become spoiled, rot').
Дыбо 9, Лексика 170. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.; seems reliable, but the front vowel in Turk. is unclear.
Martin 232, JOAL 119 (Kor.-Jpn.). Reflexes outside the Eastern area are scarce, but still the comparison seems probable, despite some phonetic problems (in TM *-ü- would be expected).
Menges 1982, 109. A good common Altaic root; if TM *īb-ǯe belongs here, can be reconstructed as *ī̀be.
In Kor. a frequent initial vowel reduction occurred.
Mong. may be < Turk., but otherwise the root seems quite reliable.

MEANING: to go, reach, get ready to go
REFERENCE: One of the common Altaic verbs of motion.
Basically a Turk.-Mong. isogloss; the Jpn. reflex is somewhat dubious because of the influence of *ōŕi > PJ *útì q.v.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Poppe 116, VEWT 167, KW 210, АПиПЯЯ 286, Лексика 371. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Cf. Kor. ìs 'moss' (?)
? Cf. Evk. ilu 'pregnant' (ТМС 1, 311).
KW 207, Tekin 1975, 280, Street 1980, 296. The Korean form may belong here if it is historically distinct from *ərɨ- 'fondle' < *i̯áĺa q.v.
Дыбо 13. A Western isogloss.
Cf. Bur. eĺge(n) 'sunny side, Southern slope'.
Дыбо 14. A Western isogloss.

MEANING: third (or next after three), consisting of three objects
RUSMEAN: третий (или четвертый после трех), состоящий из трех предметов
REFERENCE: An interesting etymon; the original meaning can be probably reconstructed as (a group of) three objects
column17: followed by a fourth". The Turkic form must represent a vowel assimilation < *ilöŋ."

REFERENCE: Martin 1996, 75. A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.
The Karakh. form is isolated, but borrowing is hardly possible here.
Whitman 1985, 180, 237. A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss, so the reconstruction is rather approximate. Cf. perhaps Oroch impai 'a k. of onion (порей)' (ТМС 1, 313); Orok imu 'potato' (ibid.) may be  < Jpn.
Лексика 83.
Лексика 81-82. The Turk. form reflects a velar suffix (cf. PTM *ine-ŋi 'day, dawn'). Cf. perhaps OJpn. ina-(bjikari) 'lightning' ('light in darkness'?).

EAS 114, KW 208, Poppe 70, Robbeets 2000, 111. Mong., with a strange reflex of *h- in Southern dialects (opposed to 0- in MMong.) may in fact reflect a contamination: cf. Evk. heŋne- 'to laugh' (see under \U*p`eŋk`a\u). In any case, despite Doerfer MT 23, the TM root is hardly < Mong.
EAS 114, Владимирцов 175. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Despite Щербак 1997, 163 Mong. cannot be borrowed from Turk.
An expressive root, but quite regular and doubtlessly common.
See SKE 76. An Eastern isogloss; the Jpn. form presupposes *iŋ(V)-gV, with further contraction.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.

Martin 249, АПиПЯЯ 111, 277. An Eastern isogloss (but cf. perhaps Mong. abĳa(n) (L 4), Khalkha av́a, Bur. ab́a 'sound' ( < *ibaja ?); on a possible Turkic parallel see under *ŏ́t`è); seems reliable, despite a tonal discrepancy between Kor. and Jpn.
KW 299, Дыбо 308, Лексика 227.
Mong. may be < Turk. (cf. Karakh. jɨraɣu 'singer', see TMN 4, 242, Щербак 1997, 164). Note also PJ *útá-p- 'sing' = Kor. *ɨr-p-.
SKE 73 (Kor.-Tung.), АПиПЯЯ 281.
A Tung.-Turk. isogloss; not quite reliable because the Turkic form may reflect a contamination with *p`i̯úsa q.v.
A Turkic-Mong. isogloss, but no doubt archaic: a Nostratic etymology see in МССНЯ 340, ОСНЯ 1, 273-4.

MEANING: to rely, trust, take upon oneself
REFERENCE: The root should be kept distinct from \U*ēt`a,\u although they tend to be confused.
The Mong. reflex is somewhat dubious (because of a secondary merger with *ide- 'eat, feed'), but the Tung.-Jpn. match still seems reliable.
Cf. perhaps Evn. ịtъ̣ŋ- 'to flounce, thrash about' (ТМС 1, 333).
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A Western isogloss. The original meaning here is probably arrange in order"
column17: whence all the other meanings are easily deduced. Cf. similar roots: \U*adV
column18: \u \U*i̯ude
column19: \u with a possibility of secondary contaminations."

REFERENCE: A Western isogloss.
Cf. also OJ ebi 'shrimp, shellfish' - perhaps an old dialectal variant of the same root.
Мудрак Дисс. 196.
Cf. also notes to \U*úmu\u 'to bear' (the reflexes of which tend to merge with the reflexes of *i̯amu with specialized meanings 'vulva, genitals').
Дыбо 9, Лексика 159.

EAS 154, Poppe 107 (Turk.-Mong.). Щербак 1997, 131 treats the Mong. word as borrowed from Turk., which is hardly the case. In the Turk.-Mong. area the root could have interacted with *ā̀ŋo `right' (sometimes also acquiring the meaning 'front') q.v.; note also the common Mong. derivative eŋge-sge `rouge, red paint' ( < `face skin').
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Despite VEWT 522, hardly borrowed in Turkic < Mongolian; the reverse direction is possible, but semantics of the Mong. word speaks rather against it.
KW 292, VEWT 2. A Western isogloss.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss. In Kor. one has to suppose a secondary monophthongization (*jə́rhì > *írhì), cf. the attested Old Koguryo *yaši ( = *yarhi) 'wolf' (see Miller 1979, 10).
An Eastern isogloss.
A Western isogloss.
The Turkic reflex is somewhat questionable; it belongs here if we suppose a semantic development 'young (animal)' > 'young horse, stallion'.

Cf. Bur. jogšo- 'to ache, nag'. Turk. *īg is perhaps a result of secondary narrowing < *(i)ēg. In TM there exists also an apparent derivative *iagsi- 'to sneeze' which is very similar to PT *aksɨr- (*agsɨr-) id. (see ЭСТЯ 1, 194-195). This may be either an old derivative, phonetically distorted in Turkic, or an independent onomatopoeic root.
ТМС 1, 337 (TM-Turk.), АПиПЯЯ 282. A Western isogloss.
A Western isogloss. Despite some confusion in Turkic, should be kept distinct from *ḗga 'rise' (q.v.).
АПиПЯЯ 110, 277. The final vowel is not quite clear: some languages point to *-i or *-e, others - rather to *-a.
Korean demonstrates a frequent vowel elision. Phonetically a good match would be PTM *iata 'ritual pollution, desecration in child-birth', but the meaning appears too specialized.
Mong. and Kor. reflect a common derivative *p`i̯oli-gV.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.

ТМС 1, 352. It is tempting to compare also Evk. ńewte, Evn. ńewte 'spring, well' (*'washing or pouring place') and perhaps also OJ mjiwo 'water-way, seaway' (if mji- is to be analysed as 'water', the -wo part stays completely obscure).
A Turk.-Jpn. isogloss; but cf. \U*adV,\u \U*idV\u, with a possibility of interaction.
Дыбо 15.
A Western isogloss.
Poppe 69, KW 457, АПиПЯЯ 45, 285, 290. Korean has a frequent initial vowel loss. Despite Doerfer MT 40, Rozycki 168, the Mong. form (attested already in the Secret History) cannot be a tungusism.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. The TM form must go back to *iŋ-ni- with a suffix (Mong. -ɣ- does not point to a cluster in PA).
Korean has a frequent initial vowel reduction.

ЭСТЯ 1, 500. The Turkic form is hard to separate, although one would rather expect a back vowel (*iab-) here. There indeed exists a PT root *(i)abɨ- 'to bend, fall, swing' (Tat. avu- 'to bend, fall', Oyr. abɨ-, Tuva aa-t-tɨn- 'to swing', Kirgh. oo- 'to bend on one side, fall, swing, also in a play', oon- 'to roll, as a dog', Kaz. awu-, awɨn-, avɨ-t-qu- 'id.', Nogh. avɨ-, avna-, avda- 'id.', Bashk. aw-, awn-, awδ- 'id.', KBalk. aw-, awan-, awda- 'id.', Karaim avd-, Kum. avun-), whose relationship to *ebir- is not quite clear. {Cf. PE *uvə-ʁ- (-a-) 'to turn upside down, to tilt, round'}
АПиПЯЯ 46, 291. One of the cases with prefixed" s- in Korean body part names (cf. also *s-pjə́ 'bone'
column17: *s-kòrí 'tail')."

REFERENCE: Лексика 377. A Western isogloss.

MEANING: to hang on (smth.), hang on hook
REFERENCE: SKE 178, EAS 106, Poppe 76 (Turk.-Mong.; assumption of Mong. being borrowed from Turk., see Щербак 1997, 120, is improbable). Turk. has a somewhat unexpected narrowing: *īl- instead of *ẹ̄l-; however, the etymology still seems probable (despite Doerfer's categorical refusal: lautgesetzlich unmöglich"; see TMN 2
For possible TM reflexes see under *ṑnV; cf. also PTM *uŋki- 'send' (ТМС 2, 277-278).
The Turkic forms should be kept apart from the reflexes of *ēr < *ā́ri q.v.
Accent in Korean is irregular. An Eastern isogloss; cf. Yak. oton 'berry' (isolated in Turkic, but perhaps archaic). {Cf. Drav. *at-i 'fig'.}
Ozawa 184-185. Korean has a verbal" low tone."

ЭСТЯ 1, 403 (Turk.-Tung.). The vocalism is not quite secure: the diphthong must be reconstructed because of Jpn. *-w-, but in Turkic one would rather expect *ɨba in this case (perhaps *ɨba > *uba > *oba because of later vowel assimilations).
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
The Jpn. form must be derived < *idar- < *idi-ra-. Mong. reveals a causative meaning here: *'make choose' > 'instigate, urge'.

Ozawa 52-53, 177-181. Despite Щербак 1997, 120, not a borrowing in Mong. < Turk. The Middle Jpn. itiko 'virgin consecrated to a deity, sorceress' (with a later form itako id.), which is compared by Miller (1985, 148) directly with the Mong. form, should be treated as a secondary distortion of *i-tu-kua (lit.) 'sacred girl'.
Martin 227 (Kor.-Jpn.). Original vocalism is somewhat uncertain; a diphthong must be reconstructed to account for loss of *-g- in Jpn. (where *bəri < *uəri < *i̯ugVri).

EAS 146-147, Poppe 60, Rozycki 222 (Mong.-Tung.), Martin 247, Menges 1984, 291, АПиПЯЯ 15, 81, SKE 284.  This is a well known Altaic root, and the Mong.-Tung.-Kor. match seems undeniable. Doerfer first tried to abolish the obvious Mong.-Tung. parallel by attempting to postulate the original meaning in Mong. as opposite" (see TMN 1
column18: then included it into his list of Mong.>Tung. borrowings (Doerfer MT 25): both positions are certainly untenable. However
column19: the Turkic and Japanese reflexes here are not devoid of problems. The Turkic reflex reveals an exceptional preservation of *i̯u- as jü-  (regularly *ɨg- would be expected) - which may be explained by the inner Turkic confusion of the synonymous roots *jüg- and *jok- ( < *ŋi̯ṑk`è q.v.). The Japanese match can be (and has been traditionally) explained as a compound of *u- 'top' with *pa (*ba) 'place' (v. sub *bi̯ŏ̀ga). However
column20: in case of a compound we would rather expect *u-m-pa. It should be also noticed that the form *úpa- itself is very frequent as a first component of compounds
column21: while the root *ú- alone is never attested. This all may mean that the Japanese form actually reflects a different root (with a medial labial consonant)
column22: or a merger of PA *i̯ugu with some different root. Such a root may be perhaps discovered in TM (*ebu-ri- 'to lift
column26: with a provisional reconstruction of PA *ébu {(*épu)}."

REFERENCE: Note the widespread velar suffixation and the identity Mong. *üliger = Kor. *ə̀rkùr.
Turkic and Mongolian reflect a common derivative *i̯ùlò-kV.
SKE 286, EAS 117. Korean has a usual verbal low tone. The Jpn. form reflects fusion with an original labial suffix (*ə̀mpí < *i̯ùme-bV = Mong. *umuji-). Cf. also \U*i̯umi.\u

Лексика 478. A Western isogloss. In TM a reconstruction *üm- is also not excluded; if this is the case the root should be reconstructed as *i̯ume and would be just a specialization of *i̯ùme 'tie, belt': 'girdled clothes'.

MEANING: a k. of fruit or berry
REFERENCE: The Jpn. word is usually derived from Middle Chinese moj 'plum', but the problem here is the same as in the word for 'horse' (see *èŋu): inexplicable initial u- in Japanese. The matches in TM and Turkic may provide an alternative Altaic explanation of Jpn. *úmái.
A reliable common Altaic root; a small problem is fronted *im- instead of the expected *ɨm- in Turkic.
VEWT 362, Цинциус 1984, 43. The Kor. word is regarded as borrowed from Mong. in Lee 1964, 192, which is somewhat dubious (-ă- is unexplainable). See also notes to *i̯ū́ńa and *i̯ańu.
Martin 227. An Eastern isogloss.
A Western isogloss.
An onomatopaeic root, but with a rather precise phonetic matching between Turkic, Mongolian and Japanese.
All languages reflect the root with different derivational suffixes; the simple verbal stem is perhaps preserved only in Manchu.
Cf. *i̯uŕo (the two roots are very similar, but clearly distinguishable).
A Turkic-Tungus isogloss; phonetically a good match, but semantics raises some doubts. {? Cf. PE *uqru- 'fat, blubber'}
One of numerous common Altaic terms of emotion.
KW 209, Martin 228, Lee 25-26. Cf. Old Koguryo \I*uš\i (see Miller 1979, 17).
Poppe 108. In Kor. one has to suppose a secondary reduction *jə̀sVk > *ìsàk; otherwise the correspondences are regular.
A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*p`i̯ōpo.\u Despite TMN 2, 151, Chag. oɣur and other late attested Turkic forms are most probably < Mong. (see Ligeti 1954, 110).
Cf. also Kalm. usχə- 'to become free' (KW 452) - if not < Turk. The Jpn. form can be alternatively compared with MKor. irh- 'to lose'.
Mong., Turk. and Jpn. reflect a common reciprocal derivative *ṓč`é-ĺV- 'to be inimical (towards each other)', on which see above.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.
MKor. has a frequent initial vowel reduction.
A Western isogloss. Ramstedt (SKE 79) compares Kor. jət 'candy, taffy', but MKor. has consistently jə́s here.

MEANING: to be insolent, angry, flamed up
REFERENCE: See SKE 68 (in Kor. cf. also igɨrə-ǯida 'to act up, put on airs'). One of the numerous common Altaic verbs of emotion. Semantic match between Turkic, Mongolian and Japanese is straightforward (to be angry
column17: indignant"). In TM one has to suppose a shift > "to be insolent
column18: obscene" > "sing obscene songs
column20: with further generalization > "sing" in other languages. In Korean we see a different semantic shift > "to put on airs

REFERENCE: A Western isogloss; cf. perhaps Jpn. *asai 'sweat' (?).

There may be more than one root here. Jpn. has, besides *i(n)sar-, a synonymous *asar- 'to fish'. One of the two Jpn. words may be alternatively compared either with TM *ŋisū- 'to bring the killed animals from the hunt' or TM *ŋusu 'fishing-rod', with a provisional reconstruction of PA *ŋisV or *ŋusV.
EAS 109. Mong. üjile < *ilü-le; Mong > Man. uilen, see Doerfer MT 119, Rozycki 222). {Cf. PE *ulima- 'to make, work'}

Vovin 1993 (Jpn.-Kor.).  Cf. also MKor. àńắm 'family', àńí 'child'. The Korean reflexes raise some doubts: tone does not correspond to TM, medial -ń- is also irregular (unless it was palatalized in àńí before -i, and other forms were changed by analogy); see a discussion in Martin 1996, 67-68, Robbeets 2000, 116-117. In Japanese *'younger brother' > *'brother'; with the introduction of *ətə 'younger brother' ( < *i̯ore 'young male') *ani changed its meaning to elder brother"."

Poppe 117 (Mong.-Tung.), KW 209, АПиПЯЯ 293-294. In Jpn. one could (following Ozawa) compare *ír- 'to enter', but the latter should be rather compared with Kor. tɨr- id. (see \U\I*tire\u),\i while *ítá-r- is also a perfect phonetic match for PA *ī́re. Turk. reveals variants *ēr- and *īr- ( < *īre-?). Cf. also Koguryo \I*i-\i 'to enter' (Lee 37, Menges 1984, 267).
EAS 112, KW 209, Poppe 81, Lee 1958, 113, ОСНЯ 1, 251. Despite Doerfer's (TMN 2, 53) doubts ( allerdings zweifelhaft" )
column17: the comparison seems completely justified."

REFERENCE: KW 219, Владимирцов 181.
One of many common Altaic verbs of emotion. Correspondences are quite regular, and the etymology seems reliable.

A common Altaic cultural term. The difference between *kabari and *gằja is not quite clear: both can mean 'oar' or 'boat pole' in daughter languages. The Mong. forms can be explained from an earlier form *kabi(r)-ɣur, whence *kaibur / *kai-ɣur.
Cf. also MKor. kóróm 'pus', probably preserving the original accentuation.

The root is rather difficult to distinguish from *k`ăp`u 'barrier'.  There also exists MJ kòfòrì 'district, county' - which is considered by most authors a loanword from MKor. kò'ắr ( = kòwắr), see e.g. JLTT 457; the loan must have occurred already after the merger of -f- ( < *-p-) and -w- in Japanese, which can explain the orthography.
The suffixless root is nominal both in Turkic and Mongolian; verbs are derived from it by means of various productive suffixes.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
SKE 102, PKE 74, АПиПЯЯ 297. The Turkic form is somewhat dubious and resembles a loanword (cf. Sak. khauca 'covering', see Bailey 76?), but the other forms are undoubtedly related.

KW 159, TMN 3, 184(: unklar" ). In Jpn. we probably have a compound with \I*pa\i 'leaf'; *kání < *kadV-N with regular nasal assimilation. The old form *kadiNpa is reflected in the Ainu loanword karinpa 'birch tree or cherry tree'."
A suffixed form *kádì-rV is reflected in most subgroups.
EAS 97, KW 174. Despite Doerfer MT 57 the TM forms are very hard to explain as borrowed from Mong. In Jpn. the word is usually analysed as mouth ring"
column17: which seems to be a folk etymology (in view of external parallels: together with Kor. kùr'ə́i it presupposes a suffixed form like *kádu-bV-). It seems that we in fact are dealing here with an archaic term of horse harness."

REFERENCE: EAS 46, 97, KW 158, Poppe 95, VEWT 221, АПиПЯЯ 288, Лексика 96-97. A Western isogloss. PT -j- instead of the expected -d- is baffling (cf. TMN 1, 394, 3, 566); perhaps OT qaja is a borrowing from some archaic j-dialect"? Helimski 1995 proposed a Sam. etymology for the Turkic word (PS *koəjə 'mountain')
column17: which cannot be excluded. But obviously Mong. is not < Turk. (despite Щербак 1997
column18: 132). Cf. also a toponym: OT Ezgenti qadaz = Mong. Ergenetü qada]."

REFERENCE: Лексика 183. Cf. \U*ki̯uma,\u \U*kumi.\u In Mong. cf. perhaps Mongor xāmənʒə (153) 'taon'.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss; but cf. also Mong. kik laɣusa 'mule'; OJ ke-mono 'animal' (usually explained as 'hairy being').
Martin 247. A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss.
Дыбо 15. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss; very poorly attested and thus not very reliable.
Ozawa 69-74. {Cf. PE *qăʁ-cu-ʁ- 'white, bleached', *qaʁu- 'light, bright'}
KW 223. A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*gĕ́ka.\u
A Western isogloss.
The meaning 'overflow' in Mong. is probably secondary ( < 'pour too much, pile up very high').

EAS 123, KW 83, Владимирцов 366, Poppe 78 (Turk.-Mong.), Цинциус 1984, 83, Miller 1970, 130, JOAL 121, Street 1980, 286-287, АПиПЯЯ 75. Despite TMN 3, 391, Щербак 1997, 135. borrowing in Mong. from Turk. is excluded. One cannot exclude a possibility that we are dealing with two different roots here: cf. the distinction in Turkic, strange loss of *-b- in Tungus *kala-n, and another Kor.-Jpn. root for 'vessel, container': MKor. kari 'fish pot, basket for catching fish', OJ ke (PJ *ka-i) 'vessel, container' (see Whitman 1985, 160).
One of the many verbs of cutting" in PA
column17: with only nominal derivatives preserved in PT and PTM."

REFERENCE: EAS 46, 154, АПиПЯЯ 75, Martin 228. The tone correspondence between Kor. and Jpn. is irregular, so the accent reconstruction here is difficult; note that the Kor. high tone here must be archaic, because it resists the general Korean tendency to introduce low tone into all verbal forms.
SKE 98, Poppe 17, 75; Doerfer MT 47 (Turk. > Mong.). On a possible reflex in Jpn. see under *gằgta.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss; cf. \U*k`ula,\u \U*k`ile,\u with possible mergers.
KW 164, Владимирцов 391, Poppe 67-68, Цинциус 1984, 88. Mong. can hardly be explained as borrowed < Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 132, 165.
A Western isogloss (although the Turkic reflex is somewhat dubious). MKor. kamtho 'a horsehair cap worn by officials' (compared with TM in SKE 92, Lee 1958, 113) is rather < Manchu.
Poppe 68, Лексика 450-451. Despite Doerfer's doubts (TMN 3, 515-516) the Turk.-Mong. parallel cannot be a coincidence.
-p- in TM is not easily explained as a suffix, so we prefer rather to reconstruct an original consonant cluster here.
ЭСТЯ 5, 332, Лексика 43 (Turk.-Mong.)
SKE 94, ТМС 1, 370, Мудрак Дисс. 184. Despite Doerfer MT 240 (semantisch unsicher")
column17: the Turk.-Tung. match seems quite plausible."

REFERENCE: PT and PM reflect a suffixed form *kanti-rV.
SKE 123.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
The TM form may belong here if it goes back to *kaŋ-čikān (= PT *Kaŋčɨk, MKor. kàŋ'àčí).  See SKE 84-85, ТМС 1,385, Menges 1984, 270-271, АПиПЯЯ 296, Дыбо 9; TMN 3, 520 (alles sehr unsicher")."
EAS 145, Владимирцов 153-154, 258, Poppe 45. One cannot exclude Mong. < Turk. in this case. An expressive Western isogloss. Cf. also \U*k`ĕ̀p`e\u (and Ozawa 201).

KW 180, Владимирцов 270, Poppe 48. A Western isogloss. Despite Doerfer's doubts (TMN 1, 450), the Turk. and Mong. forms cannot be separated from each other. It is interesting also to mention the forms meaning 'to wink' ( < *'press eyelids together') among the reflexes of PT *Kɨp- (usually confused with *Kɨp- 'spark')  and the TM derivative *kapta- (usually confused with *kapta- 'flat'). Cf. also \U*k`ap`V.\u

АПиПЯЯ 276, Мудрак Дисс. 89. Cf. \U*kéro.\u In PTM cf. perhaps *(x)arča- 'to meet, oppose (an animal during hunting)' (ТМС 1, 53) - a root that should be kept distinct from *ača- 'to meet'. In this case the reconstruction *k`àra should be preferred for PA.
KW 169, VEWT 235 (the TM forms in ТМС 1,380 - Man. qara-, qarun etc. - are obviously borrowed from Mongolian, see Doerfer MT 51, 138, Rozycki 135), Lee 1958, 114, АПиПЯЯ 287.
The root is not widely represented, but seems reliable; the meaning 'axle' in Kor.-Jpn. has developed < 'thin stick'. {ND 1199 adds WMo qaraŋɣa 'long front teeth of domestic animals; small arrow'.}

Lee 1958, 112 (Tung.-Kor.). Turkic has *KAra- (not *Kora-), obviously influenced by *Kara- 'black'. Cf. similar weed names: Turk. *Küreŋ 'sedge' (ЭСТЯ 5, 147-148), Mong. küresün, kürmenli, kürümeli id.

MEANING: bow, to shoot from a bow
REFERENCE: A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*kàra.\u
Cf. perhaps Nan. kerxe 'hump' ( < 'back').

Martin 232-233, Лексика 173. Cf. perhaps MMong. qara'una (HY 15) 'a k. of bird'. The tone correspondence between Kor. and Jpn. is irregular. Like many bird names, an expressive and rather unreliable root.
Новикова 1972, 129-130, Лексика 161. A Western isogloss.

EAS 107, Владимирцов 324, ОСНЯ 1, 338, АПиПЯЯ 54-55, 73, 103-104, 274. Despite TMN 3, 427, Щербак 1997, 134, there is no need to regard the Mong. word as borrowed from Turkic (although it is not excluded).
A Western isogloss. See Лексика 175, Pelliot HMP 573 (Doerfer TMN 3, 499: unsicher"). Like many bird names
column17: the root is expressive and probably onomatopoetic in origin."

REFERENCE: A Turk.-Mong. isogloss., with many later interlingual loans.

MEANING: to prohibit, be in one's way
REFERENCE: Cf. \U*kesa\u, \U*gi̯aso.\u

EAS 155. Cf. also MKor. kòs-kár 'hat'. Formally this Kor.-Jpn. isogloss may be derived from PA *k`i̯ū̀ča 'skin from animal's paw' (if the original meaning is postulated as 'skin covering'?); however, until some additional information is available, we prefer to keep these two etyma apart.
An expressive root, but seems to be common Altaic.
KW 158, Владимирцов 325, АПиПЯЯ 290. Mong. has also variants gada-sun, gata-sun (either < Turk. or interdialectal).
The root is not widely spread and somewhat dubious semantically.

KW 223. An onomatopoeic root; the correspondences, however, are quite regular (except for the sporadic assimilative weakening *kahi- > kai- in Kor.), and it may well be common Altaic. Mong. is hardly borrowed from Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 126.
KW 162 (but Turk. *Kāl- 'to stay behind' hardly belongs here), ТМС 1, 369, АПиПЯЯ 292. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss, but, despite Doerfer MT 144, hardly borrowed in TM < Mong.
An Eastern isogloss, with somewhat unclear tone / length correspondences; cf. perhaps also Chuv. kъʷmъʷs 'young fish' ( < PT *kem- ~ *köm-); Khak. xamnax 'roach, сорога'.

KW 165, EAS 47, SKE 91-2. The Kor. parallel is found only there; as for the Japanese  word, it is not attested in any OJ or MJ sources, so the PJ reconstruction is  uncertain. One should also note irregular PJ vocalism and tone (*-a- with high tone would be expected). This all makes the Kor.-Jpn. aspect of the etymology dubious.

EAS 114, KW 166, Poppe 70 (but despite Ozawa 192-193 and АПиПЯЯ 72, PJ *kànàp- should be attributed to *k`ā̀no).  The root is very similar to *k`āno, both phonetically and semantically, but the opposition of *Kān- and *Kon- in Turkic does not allow to unite them. The hypothesis of Mong. *kanu- being borrowed from Turkic (see Щербак 1997, 133) is possible, but not very probable.

A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. Cf. perhaps Chuv. xondъ 'protect', 'influence' etc. (if not < Mong.). Cf. also OJ katug- 'to carry' (although this may be a variant of kataga-, a compound of kata 'shoulder' + aga- 'lift, raise').
ЭСТЯ 3, 43. Some irregularities are due to expressivity.
EAS 89, Poppe 48, АПиПЯЯ 14, 68. Despite Poppe 1972, 97, TMN 1, 485, Doerfer MT 94, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong.
АПиПЯЯ 294, Ozawa 203-204, SKE 114.

A possible derivative is PA *keju-ŕ(ga) 'kettle': PT *Kāŕgan (ЭСТЯ 5, 186-188 - a contraction < *Kaj-rgan ?); Mong. kaji-sun ( < *kajir-sun); PTM *kejren (ТМС 1, 444); see KW 169; ЭСТЯ 5, 188. In that case PA *k- should be reconstructed.
A Western isogloss.
KW 163, 176, 177, ОСНЯ 1, 335. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss; but a suffixed form *kel-k`a- may be discoverable in OJ kaker- 'to fly, soar' (see Miller-Street 1975, 73-75, Street 1985, 641).
Цинциус 1984, 81-82, АПиПЯЯ 75, Мудрак Дисс. 89-90.

ОСНЯ 1, 296, Räsänen 1955, 18:3, 9. A well known Turk.-Tung. isogloss. Despite Doerfer TMN 3, 667 (Tung.-Turk.: ...der Vergleich zweifelhaft bleibt"; Turk. *gelin < *gel- 'come' - "ethnologisch sehr überzeugende Etymologie"...)
column17: the relation between PT *gẹl- 'to come' and *gẹlin 'daughter-in-law' is purely folk-etymological."

REFERENCE: KW 163, Poppe 17 (Doerfer TMN 3, 479: aus phonetischen Gründen unsicher"). The meaning 'head' in Kor.-Jpn. (whence 'brain' in Kor.) is secondary
column17: with a universally usual semantic shift ( < 'bald spot'; cf. Slavic *golъ 'bare
column18: naked' and *golva 'head' etc.; see Фасмер 1
column19: 429). -čhí in MKor. may either reflect the variation of the reflexes of *-ĺǯ- (it is interesting to note also MKor. kắrčhjə̀ŋ 'young skin of a plant'
column20: which may actually reflect the same root)
column23: rub': the two roots tend to be confused with each other."

REFERENCE: A Western isogloss; cf. perhaps OJ kata-na- 'dirty' (if not = kitana- id.). Turkic reflects a metathesized form (*Kartal < *Kaltar).
SKE 90.
KW 225, АПиПЯЯ 112, 274, Лексика 262. Borrowing in Mong. from Turk. is impossible (despite Щербак 1997, 126); the Manchu form, however, may be < Mong. (see Rozycki 137).
Дыбо 306, Лексика 243. A Western isogloss.
Ramstedt 1951, 66. Despite  TMN 1, 488, Clark 1980, 43 hardly borrowed in Mong. from Turk. (the semantics is too different for a borrowing).
A not quite certain Turk.-Tung. isogloss; Helimski 1995 supposed a loan in Turk. < Sam. *kaəti̯ə.

In Mong. one would rather expect -ö-; -e- is perhaps a result of assimilation. In Turko-Mongolian -ŋ- is possibly an original suffix (Turk. *köjŋe- < *köń-ŋe-); but a reconstruction like *k`i̯ùńŋí can also not be excluded.

A Western isogloss. In Turkic the root has merged with *Kājnat 'wing' (see under *kēńa); this homonymy may have influenced Mong., where the stem qana(n) occasionally means 'wing, маховые перья'; but Mong. hardly < Turk., despite TMN 1, 416. In Mong. one has to suppose a reanalysis of *-t as a plural suffix.
ЭСТЯ 5, 107 (Mong.-Tung.). In Mong. the root has several expressive variants (cf. also PA *k`eŋa). In Kor. an early palatalization occurred (*-ŋi- > -ń-). See also notes to PA \U*k`ēmŋV\u 'wide'.
Дыбо 307, Лексика 232, 276. A Western isogloss.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
Дыбо 5, Лексика 267. A Western isogloss. The root is sometimes difficult to distinguish from *kēp`V 'belly' and *k`eba 'corpse', due to natural contaminations.
One of several similar PA roots (see *k`ā́p`a, *k`epa, *k`i̯ā̀bu, *gébo).

АПиПЯЯ 281, Дыбо 5, Лексика 277. Ramstedt (SKE 89) compares the Kor. form with Mong. qarbiŋ etc. (see *k`i̯áŕme), but this seems improper (the modern form kalbi goes back to MKor. kari-spjə). The Japanese form is somewhat insecure due to its late attestation and unclear suffix. In Mong cf. perhaps kerseŋ 'brisket'.
EAS 107, KW 227, SKE 104, Poppe 79-80.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss (with assimilation in Mong. *kerken- < *kergen-, cf. similarly in *k`úrgo); cf. perhaps also Evk. (Tokk.) ker 'membrane' (ТМС 1, 452).
EAS 146, KW 227, Poppe 18, 79, Murayama 1962, 110. Cf. \U*kàra.\u
The root must have denoted some big predator, probably the wolverine. Cf. also MMong. (HY 10) qarxulax 'small tiger'.
Cf. also Turk. *Kurt-ga 'old woman' (see ЭСТЯ 6, 168-169).
Mong. *küsünüg < *kesü- (with secondary vowel assimilation).
KW 228, Poppe 18, 65. Cf. \U*kasa.\u The Turkic form points rather to *k`-; if the TM forms are borrowed from Mong. (see Doerfer MT 69), we should rather reconstruct PA *k`ésa.
SKE 113, Poppe 65. A Mong.-Kor. isogloss; the TM forms (see ТМС 1, 455) probably < Mong., see Doerfer MT 116, Rozycki 139.

A Western isogloss. Mong. > Chag. kačir 'mule' etc. (see VEWT 217). The Mong. form itself may have been borrowed from Turk. (see Щербак 1997, 137), but may as well be genuine. The Tung. parallel makes the theory of Turk. < Iran. (Sogd. ɣrtr'k, see TMN 3, 393 with literature) rather improbable.
EAS 47, KW 228, SKE 84, Poppe 18, 50, Miller 1985a, 81. Despite Doerfer MT 64, the TM form is hardly borrowed from Mong.
SKE 99, Martin 241. A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss.
See Лексика 82: rather dubious, because of very scanty attestation in Mongolian.
Martin 229, Miller 1980, 161-162, 1985a, 81, 1986, 48, Лексика 183. Medial *-j- has to be reconstructed to account for loss of resonant in Korean.
The Jpn. form goes back to *keju-(ga)-. The Turkic parallel raises doubts: the isolated Chuv. form may stem from Mari kaj- 'to go' ( < FU *käwe, UEW 654), as suggested in VEWT 221.
A Western isogloss; not quite reliable because of poor attestation (and possible borrowed nature?) in Turkic and TM. Cf. OJ. kédá-mono 'animal' (?).

In Turkic one would expect *geń-; the root, however, has since the oldest texts almost completely merged with PT *köń- 'to burn', so as to become almost indistinguishable from the latter. See also notes to *gū̀no.
KW 229, Poppe 20, 46, ОСНЯ 1, 293, АПиПЯЯ 15, 69, 109, 279, Ozawa 208-209, Дыбо 14, Лексика 227. Correspondences are regular except for low tone in Jpn.  (high tone would be expected).
A good common Altaic root; the original meaning is  'face' or 'jaws', with a more abstract meaning 'shape' developed in the Western area (a very usual semantic development).

Владимирцов 205. Despite Doerfer MT 93, Rozycki 104 the TM forms cannot easily be explained as mongolisms (except Sol. kêli). The root is homonymous (except for the final vowel which is in this case unknown) with *kēp`a 'shape', and one wonders if it is in fact not the same root, but semantically influenced by another similar one, PA *kepV 'upper part of body'.

MEANING: a k. of bird of prey
REFERENCE: KW 170, Лексика 169.
KW 223, Владимирцов 260, Poppe 19, ОСНЯ 1, 309. One of the common Altaic monosyllabic verbal stems. In view of the external evidence, -l- in PT is to be regarded as a historical suffix.

Martin 244 (Kor.-Jpn.). PJ *kama- presupposes a nasal suffix (*ki̯ap`a-nV). A very similar fish name is found in TM (Oroch kiampai 'чилимс', Nan. qǟfu 'гольян (озерный)', see ТМС 1, 397); cf. also a quite isolated Turkm. kepir 'carp' (if not from Pers. kopur, see ЭСТЯ 5, 47). Whether these forms reflect the same root is yet to be determined.
The reflexes point to a tree with distinct bright bark, probably birch (cf. also PU *kojwV 'birch' compared in МССНЯ 330, ОСНЯ 1, 300).

The root denotes some wild-growing grass with sharp edges or thorns. In Kor. there probably occurred a secondary vowel assimilation (*káj- would be expected). Some interaction with *kúja  'nut' was possible, especially in the Kor.-Jap. area.
KW 231, SKE 112, ТМС 1, 394. Cf. similar semantic development in \U*ábo\u q.v.
A derivative *kìkú-čV is probably observable in Karakh. kikčür- = PM *kegǯe-.
KW 244, Menges 1982. .

MEANING: a k. of big wild animal
REFERENCE: An interesting Mong.-Jpn. isogloss.

Poppe 19, 65, 116, VEWT 267, KW 233 (without the Korean parallel), АПиПЯЯ 285. The original meaning may be reconstructed as 'press, scrape off by pressing' (whence 'sharpen' and other meanings). Tone correspondences seem to be regular, but cf. notes on the Korean tone above.
A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss.
Cf. \U*ki̯ū́di,\u \U*gode\u (with possible contaminations).
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss; rather dubious because of scarce attestation in TM.

In Turkic one has to suppose vowel assimilation (*Küĺül < *Keĺül), and in Mong. - a regular r/l metathesis ( < *keler-ǯegene). Cf. a number of similar roots, with a possibility of contaminations: see *keru, *k`i̯ūĺa, *ki̯ùti, *k`ela.

АПиПЯЯ 111. For Jpn. cf. also Koguryo /xuče/ 'mouth'. The root must have basically meant 'mouth or throat cavity' (whence 'mouth', 'cheek' (originally probably 'inner side of cheek') and 'trachea'), with a secondary development > 'cavity in general' > 'well' in TM.

KW 236, Poppe 19, Ozawa 197-199, JOAL 72, 73, 136, АПиПЯЯ 72. A possible TM match is Man. adu = Jurch. ha-du 'clothes'  < *xadu (ТМС 1, 6); this would make us reconstruct *k`ajdi and suppose a secondary (assimilatory) voicing in Turk. *ged- < *ked-.

Martin 245, АПиПЯЯ 15, 16, 71, 103, 279 (but the Turkic parallel has to be attributed to a different root, see *gāt`i). In TM one would rather expect *kid- - but the PTM reconstruction is dubious anyway (based only on one dialectal Evk. form).

Mong. may be < Turk. (see TMN 3, 542, Щербак 1997, 132), but may well be genuine, see KW 202, Владимирцов 206, Poppe 48. Korean has the typical verbal" low tone. The specific medial cluster explains somewhat irregular vowel behaviour in Kor."

АПиПЯЯ 109, 277, Мудрак Дисс. 103 (see also \U*gi̯ūbe,\u \U*ki̯aju,\u with a possibility of contaminations). Note that both in MMong. and OJ the root is sometimes treated as borrowed from MChin. khɨ̀j (see, e.g., Rozycki 139) - which is not totally excluded, but somewhat dubious (very early attestation both in Mongolian and Japanese texts, and unexplained vocalism).
Cf. \U*ki̯ájo:\u the two roots seem to be distinct, but certainly contaminations were possible. Kor. *kuri- < *kuju-ri-, cf. the Jpn. form.
АПиПЯЯ 293. A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss; seems quite reliable (linking the Jpn. form with Kor. kur by Martin 238 should be rejected).

PKE 68 (Kor.-Turk., without Japanese parallels), АПиПЯЯ 279, Лексика 200. Tone correspondence between Kor. and Jpn. is irregular. The variation between *-m- and *-p- in most subgroups reflects the PA cluster *-mp`-, possibly with later interdialectal loans.
Мудрак Дисс. 192 (Turk.-Mong.). Cf. perhaps also MKor. -kɨ́m in nīm-kɨ́m 'master, Lord' (if -kɨ́m is not borrowed < Jpn. kimi, see under *kiŋo).
EAS 155, SKE 122-123, Дыбо 9, Martin 225, Лексика 162.
Martin 230. Korean has a 'verbal' low tone and a secondary monophthongization (*-jə- > -i-). In Mong. one has to assume labial assimilation *köb- < *keb-.
Дыбо 8, Лексика 171. In Turk. cf. also *Kuŕgun 'raven' (see TMN 3, 468-469, ЭСТЯ 6, 107-108).

An interesting root, demonstrating the acquaintance of the speakers with the way of life of the salmon (weakening and dying after releasing roe). Note a common derivative *ki̯áta-rV in the Turko-Mongolian area.

Reasons for voicing in TM and Turkic are not clear (assimilative development in a suffixed form *ki̯át`ó-gV?; note that in PTM we can also reconstruct *kudege - the -ge would have been lost in all languages where the root is attested).
VEWT 222 (Turk.-Mong.), АПиПЯЯ 287, Лексика 97. A Western isogloss.

KW 158, Poppe 52. Despite TMN 3, 579, Щербак 1997, 132 Mong. is hardly < Turk. Cf. also Evn. kēde 'friend' (ТМС 1, 443). The Kor. word is compared alternatively (JLTT 438) with OJ kara `clan, family', but the latter seems to have a better match in TM *kal-, see *kala.
A Western isogloss. In Mong. one has to suppose assimilation: godoli < *kodoli. Cf. *k`i̯ōt`e.
Mong. keče-ɣü and some Turkic forms (e.g. Khak. xača-ɣ) reflect a common derivative *ki̯oči-gV.
Cf. \U*k`i̯ŏ́ǯa\u, \U*kéč`a\u (the three roots are sometimes difficult to distinguish). The medial -j- in Kor. is not quite clear.

Владимирцов 210. *-jb- is reconstructed to account for Mong. -b- rather than *-ɣ-. Note, however, that modern Turkic and Mongolian forms interact actively: some Turkic forms may be backloans from Mong. quwa (which itself is probably a Turkism, see above).

ОСHЯ 1, 304; Дыбо 312-313; VEWT 230, Лексика 149-150. Cf. also Kalm. xanə 'маховые перья' (KW 165, АПиПЯЯ 289); but due to restricted distribution in Mong. this form should be rather considered a Turkism (see Щербак 1997, 133).
An interesting common Altaic cultural term (although Mong. -u- here is not quite regular; one would expect -i-/-e- or -ö-).
Poppe 1950, 575, Lee 1958, 114. In the Kor.-Jpn. area some confusion of this root with PA *gā̀jrV 'wild goose' was possible.
АПиПЯЯ 295. A Mong.-Kor. isogloss. The Mong. form cannot be compared with TM *gora 'far' (despite Poppe 18).

A Western isogloss. The root tends to contaminate with \U*k`ema\u q.v. (and cf. also \U*kemV,\u \U*gi̯aŋu,\u \U*gokV\u). The Mong. form may be < Turk. (cf. Щербак 1997, 198), but may as well be genuine.

The tone correspondence between Kor. and Jpn. is irregular. Note, however, that the reconstruction of low tone in PJ in this case is based only on the Kagoshima form (MJ accentuation is unattested, while Kyoto and Tokyo may point both to *LL and to *HL). Therefore a reconstruction *kə́mài for PJ is not completely excluded. Medial -n- in Turkic is not quite clear (-ń- would be expected); still the relation of the Turkic form remains probable. See also Robbeets 2000, 109.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.
A Western isogloss. Cf. also \U*kobu,\u \U*gupu\u (with possible contaminations).

A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss. It is worth noting Yak. kuba 'swan' - usually derived from PT *Kugu, but with a quite inexplicable -b-; it is, in fact, possible that some other Turkic forms - cf. Turkm. Guv, Nogh. quv etc. also go back to PT *Kub(a) - naturally confused in most modern languages with the reflexed of *Kugu (see under *kūgu).

Whitman 1985, 182, 226 (Kor.-Jpn.). Cf. Chag. (VEWT 281) kopuk 'eine vorteilhafte  (stehende) Stellung des Knöchels beim Spiel'. In TM cf. *kōkčān 'hoof' (ТМС 1, 405-406) - perhaps < *kōpčān, cf. Evk. Tott. kopčan.
KW 222. Cf. Nan. kutumiekte 'currant, gooseberry'.
Martin 228.
A Western isogloss.
Jpn. \I*tuna-\i < *tuda-n with nasal assimilation ( = OT tɨdɨn).
A common derivative *ki̯òt`è-rV is reflected in Kirgh. qatɨ-r- = Evk. koto-ro-n-.
EAS 147, Poppe 107, Ozawa 204. An expressive root with not quite secure vocalic correspondences. Cf. also notes to *k`úlo.
An onomatopoeic root, but seems to be well reconstructable for PA.
The tone in Jpn. is irregular; the form should be perhaps separated and compared with Mong. qaǯi- 'to hate, blame, tease' (L 948), allowing to reconstruct a separate PA root *kadu ( ~ k`-, -e-).

EAS 46, KW 233, Владимирцов 171, 318, Poppe 19, Лексика 94. Cf. perhaps MKor. kɨ̀th 'edge'. The Jpn. form must have originally meant 'border fortification, fortress'; there is hardly any reason to regard it as borrowed from Old Paekche, despite Miller 1979).
ОСНЯ 1, 305. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. The root should be distinguished from *k`oli- 'shadow, cloud' (although contaminations are possible).
An Eastern isogloss.
Cf. \U*kumi,\u \U*kajamV.\u
Poppe 68. A Western isogloss. Mong. cannot be explained as a Turk. loanword, despite TMN 3, 508-509, Щербак 1997, 143 (conversely, late Turkic forms like Oyr., Kaz. qumaq etc. are evidently < Mong.).

KW 249, VEWT 309 (Turk.-Mong.), АПиПЯЯ 294, TMN 3, 656-657 (with criticism). The Mong. form is somewhat difficult: one has to suppose original *künün with velar ( > *küŋün > *küɣün) and labial ( > *kümün) assimilations.

SKE 113. Cf. also Mong. köbüŋ 'cotton' ( > Oyr. köböŋ, Tuva xöveŋ, Khak. köböŋ etc., see ЭСТЯ 5, 108-109 (with some confusion of this root and Turk. *köpe 'cloth' < \U*k`op`e\u q.v. and Turk. *köp- 'swell, foam' < \U*k`op`i\u q.v.); > Man. kubun id., see Doerfer MT 102). In fact, it would be tempting to consider Mong. *kib as a Turkic loanword (despite the fact that the Turk. *Kɨp is not widely spread and late attested, it cannot be < Mong.), because Mong. -i- is not quite regular here, while köbüŋ is a perfect phonetic match.
A Western isogloss.

Judging from the Turkic evidence, the vehicle in question could have been not a wheeled one, but some kind of sleigh or sledge; however, this may be also a secondary development in Turkic (all other languages point rather to some wheeled  carriage or just wheel).  Among common derivatives one can mention PT *Kɨŕak = Evn. kūruke-n.
A Turk.-TM isogloss; cf. *kumi. Doerfer (MT 240) tries to refute the comparison (by deriving the Turk. forms from kirpi hedgehog" and the TM forms from kiri- "to glitter") - quite unconvincingly."
The Mong. form could be alternatively compared with Turk. *Kodan 'hare' (ЭСТЯ 6, 29-30).
Cf. \U*kit`u,\u \U*gode\u (with possible contaminations).
The basic meaning of the root may be formulated as 'having not enough, insufficience' - whence 'debt', 'miser', 'beggar' etc. A Mongolian match is perhaps *kudal 'lie, liar' ( < 'beggar'?).

MEANING: a k. of bird of prey
REFERENCE: EAS 113, ЭСТЯ 6, 231. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
SKE 122. Cf. \U*gupu.\u The Kor. form *kōr- presupposes *kobVr-; however, it is only found in SKE and may be in fact = *kòrh- 'be hungry, empty' (see \U*gṓŕa\u).
A Western isogloss; see under *k[ā]p`á about possible mergers.
Poppe 63, KW 241, Владимирцов 377; Лексика 490; TMN 3, 633 (...nicht hinreichend gesichert"). Despite Щербак 1997
column18: not borrowed in Mong. < Turk. (see also Clark 1980
column19: 56); -s- instead of the expected -č- in Mong. is due to a position within the cluster (köske = köčke). -č- (or *-š-) in Evk. is
column21: more difficult to account for (*-s- would be expected normally)
column22: which means that the Evk. words may actually be borrowed < Yakut."

REFERENCE: The root (as a verb) meant basically 'to use a prop or lever', whence an instrumental noun *kóšì-p`V (TM *kuši-pu-n, PJ *kúsà-pì, possibly also Mong. kösi-ɣü-r).
Poppe 62. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss, but hardly borrowed, despite TMN 3, 540, Щербак 1997, 139.
Владимирцов 365, Poppe 77 (Turk.-Mong.), Дыбо 46. A Western isogloss.
PTM and Japanese reflect a common derivative *kòna-kV.
An expressive root. Cf. also Turk. *Kɨg 'dung' (VEWT 261), *Kakač id. (EDT 610).
Poppe 108, Колесникова 1972a, 78-84, Цинциус 1984, 106-107, Martin 248, Murayama 1962, 111, АПиПЯЯ 15, 32, 280, JOAL 147, Дыбо 13, Лексика 272-273, TMN 1, 482 (Elementarverwandtschaft?")
column17: Doerfer MT 142. Mongolian and TM have a parallel verbal stem 'to suck (breast)'
column18: thus the probable semantic development here is 'to suck (breast)' > '(female) breast' > 'breast (in general)' > 'heart'."

REFERENCE: The meaning 'big' in Korean certainly derives from *'plentiful'. The match between Kor. khɨ- and Jpn. *kə̀kə́-  appears quite satisfactory, despite the attempt of Vovin (2000) to link Kor. *hɨkɨ- with PJ *sùkùnà-  'few': it is hardly possible to analyse the Jpn. word as *'big'-does-not-exist, since all the existing compounds of this type are noun+-na"
column17: not "adjective+-na"
column18: and anyway it is hardly possible to separate PJ *sùkùnà- 'few' (adj.) and *sùkùa-(si) 'few' (noun

REFERENCE: An interesting common Altaic cultural term.
One of the many common Altaic verbs of emotion.
Лексика 69-70.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Contaminations with several other roots were possible: cf. \U*gū́ldi,\u \U*k`i̯uli,\u \U*k`iĺa.\u Cf. Щербак 1997, 128 (Turk. > Mong.).
Illich-Svitych ОСНЯ 1, 329 lists MKor. kul- 'to lie', but this is probably = MKor. kūr- 'to blow', due to a character misidentification by Lee Kee-mun (1958, 112).

Cf. also Mong. *köɣemej  which can go back to *köme-ɣej, cf. potential Turkic loanwords like Chag. kömekej, Yak. kömögöj etc., see VEWT 289. Such a metathesis, however, is rather uncommon (as well as the rendering of Mong. -ɣ- by Turkic -k-), and there are obvious loanwords from the same Mongolian source: Yak., Dolg. küömej 'throat' (see Kał. MEJ 88, Stachowski 165). It may well be that the above Turkic words are genuine after all, going back to *gömü-kej (derived from the same root as *gömül-dürük), while Mong. köɣemej has a quite different origin (e.g. PA *kúŋe 'middle, heart' q.v.).
A common derivative *kòmpo-k`V is reflected in PT *Kopa-k = PTM *komba-kī.
A reconstruction *kómVtV ( ~ -t`-) is also not excluded (and perhaps would account better for the PJ form).
Martin 246 (Kor.-Jpn.). Korean has a usual low 'verbal' tone, but the -a-vowel is quite irregular . Perhaps one should think of an early merger in Kor. with the root \U*kàma\u 'to connect' (q.v.).

Poppe 72, KW 185, VEWT 281, Whitman 1985, 183, 199, 222, АПиПЯЯ 290, Дыбо 12, Robbeets 2000, 109. The Mongolian form qoŋɣur might as well be a Turkism, cf. TMN 3, 525-526, Щербак 1997, 139-140 (note that qon-dun, qoŋ-du < Chinese). The TM forms, despite Doerfer MT 37, cannot be regarded as mongolisms. In Kor. cf. also kə̀'úró 'mirror' (probably a derivative from the same root; semantically cf. Jpn. kaga-mi id. - 'mirror' < 'shadow'). Note that *kắnắrh  reflects a suffixed form *koŋ(a)-rV with assimilation > *konrV, while *kànkâ-i reflects another suffixed form *koŋ(V)-kV ( = Mong. *koŋgu-r).
Whitman 1985, Robbeets 2000, 102. The Jpn. form is historically a compound with *s(u)- 'to make, do'. In Kor. a palatalization *kŏŋe > *kŏńe occurred.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Poppe 84 (Tung.-Mong.; Doerfer TMN 1, 483 criticizes Poppe's TM reconstruction *köndes - which is justified, but does not abolish the parallel).
A Western isogloss.
Cf. \U*gi̯ṓp`e,\u \U*k`àpe\u (in Mong. and TM also a partial contamination with \U*kup`e\u 'light, float'). See also notes to *k`ep`orV 'curved bone'.
KW 191, Владимирцов 255, АПиПЯЯ 15, 27, 289, Дыбо 12. A Western isogloss (possible Kor.-Jpn. reflexes see under \U*k`óp`i\u).
Accent correspondence between Kor. and Jpn. is irregular.
VEWT 311, KW 240.
A good common Altaic root, denoting some kind of big vessel (used as a measure of weight in the Eastern area).

Дыбо 11, Whitman 1985, 193, 231, Menges 1984, 274-275. Basically an Eastern isogloss: the Turkic forms of the type koz are most probably borrowed from Iranian. There are also forms reflecting *koŕak (VEWT 285), but they may also reflect a contamination of the root *Koŕ (or the borrowed koz) with the genuine root *kusɨk (e.g. Tuva kusuk)
column17: see *kušu."

REFERENCE: KW 186. Cf. MKor. kàrm- (Whitman kălm-, SKE ka̯m-) 'to hide, put away'? Cf. also *k`ure 'basket' - with a possibility of contaminations in Mong.
An Eastern isogloss. Cf. Old Koguryo *kos 'gem, jewel' (see Miller 1979, 10).

SKE 113-114, EAS 102. The Kor.-Jpn. forms are not quite regular: in Kor. one would rather expect *kɨ́sìrk (so probably we are dealing with a metathesis); the diphthong -ui- in Japanese (as in the few other similar cases) has a not quite clear origin. It may well be that the Jpn. form is related to *kui 'fortress' < *'border', see *ki̯udu - although the suffixation is peculiar.
Лексика 281. Derived are Turk. *göten(e) 'stomach' (ЭСТЯ 3, 85), Mong. *kotuɣa- id. ( > Evk. koto etc., see Doerfer MT 103-104); cf. also TM *kuta id. (ТМС 1, 418, 439), see Doerfer ibid.
EAS 154, SKE 127.
EAS 46, Martin 244, АПиПЯЯ 56, 49, 277. The root behaves like *kó'e (with a second front vowel).
KW 182. {Cf. PE *kukrV- 'unsure, clumsy, afraid to do'}

EAS 154, VEWT 287, KW 236, Владимирцов 168, 324,  Poppe 56, АПиПЯЯ 288. A Western isogloss. Despite Щербак 1997, 128, Doerfer TMN 3, 641-642, MT 99 and Rozycki 145 there is no need to assume Mong. < Turk. or TM < Mong. (although it cannot be excluded). Derived are probably bird names: Turk. *gȫkerčin  'dove', *gȫkel 'he-duck', ТМ *kukēkī 'jay', Mong. *kögürǯegene 'dove' (see Лексика 175; Mong. is hardly borrowed < Turk., despite Clark 1980, 44).
KW 137, Poppe 25, 78. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. PT has a quite irregular *k-, probably due to contamination with *kičük 'small, young of animals' q. v.
In the Western area the root denotes basically a carpet or covering (>saddle) made of skins; since in Japanese it is a straw matting, it is not quite clear what sort of mat was denoted by it in PA.
KW 186, ТМС 1, 410. In Jpn. the word is homonymous with *káná-i 'metal', which is probably secondary (but may explain the irregular tone).
MKor. păi-s-kop has also a variant păi-s-pok - which must be secondary in the light of external evidence.
KW 243, Владимирцов 212, EAS 113, Poppe 48, 82. Despite TMN 1, 486, Mong. is not < Turk.
The root is not widely spread, but seems to be reliable.

A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss. Cf. also OT (ДТС) qobɨ (USp.) 'belongings, inheritance', which Doerfer (TMN 1, 423) considers to be the source of the Mong. word, but which in fact hardly exists (the attestation is rather scarce and dubious, see EDT 581).
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.
Turk. *Kɨjgɨ- 'a k. of bird' (VEWT 261) may be possibly related, but merged with *Kɨj- 'to cry' (ibid.).
An Eastern isogloss; see also notes to *kìjá.
The second vowel and tone are hard to establish because of contraction in Jpn. and Kor.
The meaning in Mongolian is probably original here; in Japanese one has to suppose a shift 'carpal joint of feet' >  'heel'; in TM - > 'covering for the carpal joint (wrist)' = 'mittens'.
АПиПЯЯ 296. An Eastern isogloss; but cf. perhaps Mongor xuGo 'ventre, entrailles'.
Turkic and TM reflect a common derivative *kúmle-ŕV.
SKE 132, АПиПЯЯ 293. A Tung.-Kor. isogloss; further Nostratic parallels see in ОСНЯ 1, 308.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
SKE 106. Cf. \U*kupro\u - the two roots are to be distinguished.
Either length in TM or tone in Jpn. is irregular.
SKE 105, Lee 1958, 119, Martin 242, ОСНЯ 1, 309, АПиПЯЯ 290, Дыбо 9, Лексика 184. An expressive root: cf. \U*ki̯uma,\u \U*kajamV.\u
Poppe 19, 68, Дыбо 5, Лексика 214 (but the Turkic parallels should probably be separated: cf. \U*ki̯uru(mV)\u). Despite Doerfer MT 80, TM forms cannot be < Mong. {Cf. PE *qəməʁja- 'eyelash'}
Lee 1958, 114, Martin 233.
Mong. may be < Turk., but may as well be genuine.

Räsänen 1955, 18:3, 19 (Turk.-Tung.), ОСНЯ 1, 298-299, Лексика 186, Robbeets 2000, 108; TMN 3, 660 (...der ev. Vergleich zweifelhaft..."). The Japanese form goes back to a suffixed *kuńe-gV (cf. the TM and Kor. forms); the vowel
column17: however
column18: is quite irregular - which may be due to contraction (cf. a very similar case in PJ *ka 'day' < PA *gi̯òjńu)."

REFERENCE: A Turk.-Jpn. isogloss. Cf. perhaps Evn. qōŋań 'witch' (ТМС 1, 411).
A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*k`i̯ūńa.\u
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.
The root appears well reconstructable for PA, with a common derivative *ki̯àntú-kV (PT *Kendük = PM *kundaga = PTM *kondi-kā-n.
On a possible Mongolian reflex see under *kómp`i.
KW 242, АПиПЯЯ 82, Дыбо 7. The Jpn. form goes back to *kuŋ(i)-gV.
EAS 141, Poppe 18.

Владимирцов 211, Poppe 18, 48, 82. The root cannot be united with \U*kúma\u for phonetical reasons, although in modern languages their reflexes tend to merge. Despite Doerfer's doubts (TMN 1, 445: Urverwandtschaft ist sehr unwahrscheinlich")
column17: it is probably archaic; loan from Turk. into Mong. (TMN ibid.
column18: Щербак 1997
column19: 139) is quite improbable. Jpn. has -t- (instead of the expected -r-) probably because of a special cluster development."

MEANING: light (of weight), floating on the surface
REFERENCE: In Kor. cf. also MKor. kàpór'o- 'to winnow'. The root tends to contaminate with  \X<0.1124>*k`óp`i\x 'foam' and \X0*gĕbo\x 'empty, light' q.v. See SKE 82, Poppe 43.
SKE 115. The Korean root is attested only there, thus not very reliable (and the vocalic reflex is dubious).
KW 187, SKE 125, Poppe 88, TMN 1, 434. The root is actively contaminating with \U*k`ōra\u q.v.
Poppe 1950, 576. A common Altaic cultural term.
Accent correspondence is irregular. Cf. also OJ kùsúri 'medicine'. Cf. perhaps also Chuv. ku(r)žanak ( < *kösinek) 'agrimony, bur'.

An Eastern isogloss; but cf. also WMong. kösür-sün (Kalm. kösrsn) 'dung' = OJ kùswò id.; WMong. kusam 'sediment in a pot after boiling milk' (MGCD 392); Yak. kuha-ɣan, Dolg. kuha-gan 'bad' (Stachowski 159). Kor. has a usual verbal low tone.
АПиПЯЯ 17, Дыбо 14, ЭСТЯ 6, 23-24 (with some confusion of this root and \U*k`usa \u q.v.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
EAS 142, Poppe 18, 50. Mong. is not < Turk., despite TMN 3, 553, Щербак 1997, 143.
The root is not very widely spread, but seems both phonetically and semantically plausible.
АПиПЯЯ 294. In Kor. one has to assume a secondary fronting kič < *kɨč; otherwise the correspondences are regular.

EAS 96, KW 249, Владимирцов 165, Poppe 63, 112, АПиПЯЯ 16. High tone in Kor. is not clear. Despite TMN 3, 627, Щербак 1997, 128, Mong. is hardly borrowed from Turkic; TM cannot be borrowed from Mong., despite Rozycki 113. In АПиПЯЯ (p. 77) the root was compared with PJ *kìsV- 'to contest'. The latter, however, has better Tungus parallels: TM *gali- 'to contest' (ТМС 1, 138), see *gaĺi.
A Turk.-Kor. isogloss.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. Cf. also Kalm. keln, WMong. kele 'slave' (if not == tongue")."

АПиПЯЯ 294 (although Jpn. *kəti is probably to be separated, see *k`ĕdo), Лексика 75. A Western isogloss. The comparison seems quite plausible, although it seems not to have been proposed earlier. The Korean form, compared in SKE 118 with Turk. *gǖŕ (kɨru '2-d harvest in one year') is late attested and probably = kɨru, MKor. kɨ̀rɨ̀h 'stubble'. {Cf. PE *ukju[r] 'winter, autumn, year}.

KW 199. A Western isogloss. Doerfer (TMN 3, 441) (and Clark 1980, 43) regard Mong. as borrowed from Turk. (saying that the original meaning in Turkic is 'steel' - which is not the case, see EDT 647). On a possible Jpn. reflex see under *k`[u]ri. {ND 1154 gives WMo kürü- 'sharpen an arrow'.}

Дыбо 9, Лексика 172, Whitman 1985, 183, 222. Kor. has an irregular low tone. The root is onomatopeic and the medial consonant behaves irregularly in TM (various assimilations are attested). In Turkic the root could additionally contaminate with *ki̯òpu q.v. The Altaic antiquity is, however, beyond doubt.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss - but despite TMN 1, 473-475, hardly borrowed in Turk. from Mongolian.
A Western isogloss; the Mong. reflex has an irregular vowel and is somewhat dubious.
The Mong. vocalism is not quite clear.

KW 167, 180, Poppe 17, 18, 43, Цинциус 1984, 76-77. Mergers with phonetically close roots (e. g. *k`ap`a  'barrier', *k`op`e 'film, covering', *kobe 'clothing', *k`āp`V 'bladder') were possible - which may explain some vocalic and prosodic irregularities.
Despite some problems with vocalism, the root seems reliable.
A Western isogloss. Despite vocalic irregularity, the TM forms are hard to separate from Turko-Mongolian.
Cf. also \U*k`i̯ùru\u 'heavy, difficult'.
KW 158, Цинциус 1984, 79-80. The meaning swell" is probably secondary
column17: under the influence of \U*gi̯ṓp`e\u q.v. (in Mong. possibly also under the influence of Turk. *Kāp- < *gi̯ṓp`e); cf. also \U*kop`e.\u"

REFERENCE: The vowel *-ə̄- in Kor. must be due to contraction.
АПиПЯЯ 16; Цинциус 1984, 88-89. A Western isogloss.
Цинциус 1984, 80-81. A Western isogloss. On a possible Jpn. reflex see under *kéč`a.

MEANING: to scrape off, scraper, tool for processing skins
RUSMEAN: соскребать, скребок, инструмент для обработки шкур
REFERENCE: PTM *xargan < *xadVrgan with a regular loss of -d- before -r-. Diphthong in Jpn. is not clear (*kíntúr- would be normally expected).

The root is rather difficult to distinguish from \U*k`et[o]\u q.v.; contaminations may explain partial vocalic irregularities. Mong. *kidu- is usually compared with Turk. *Kɨd- 'to destroy' (thus KW 244, VEWT 261, TMN 1, 487-488), but this form probably does not exist: in OT (8th c.) there is a dubious Hap. leg. qɨdmaz 'did not spare (?)', but all other sources (starting with MK) have only *Kɨj- and its reflexes (see EDT 595) - which is quite a different root, see \U*gĳo.\u
EAS 46, 47, 140, KW 225, Цинциус 1984, 75-76, АПиПЯЯ 41-42, 285. The TM form, despite Doerfer MT 27, Rozycki 222 has nothing to do with Mong. *ja- q.v.
A possible derivative is PA *k`akt`o 'castrated animal' q.v.

Дыбо 15. Cf. Khalkha xǖxeldej 'doll' (a contamination with xǖxe-n 'child, girl'). One should also mention WMong. qoduɣu-čin 'clown; mask': this may be a metathesis < *kogu-du- ( = PJ *kùnkùtú)  and the form may actually shed light on the mysterious Karakh. qoδurčuk (quite probably < *kog-du-rču-k = WMong. qoduɣu-čin). {Cf. PE *kəɣina- 'face'}.
A Western isogloss.
Цинциус 1984, 82. A Western isogloss.
EAS 110.
An interesting common Altaic cultural term. PT and Korean reflect the common derivative *k`alo-ŋV.
A Western isogloss.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Cf. perhaps some other plant names: Oyr., Tuva kɨlbɨš 'бадан широколистный'; perhaps TM *xul- > Evk. uli 'толокнянка', xuletũ 'назв. растения с целебным корнем'.
Irregular low tone in MKor. (possibly due to contraction). Mong. *koŋgurčag is a result of frequent labial attraction ( < *kaŋgurčag).
Martin 227. An Eastern isogloss. Cf. \U*k`èpu.\u
KW 178, 179, Цинциус 1984, 77-78. A Western isogloss.
EAS 89-90, Владимирцов 208, ОСНЯ 1, 337, Цинциус 1984, 85. Mong. qaɣa- is not < Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 133. See also notes to PA *kábo.

Владимирцов 206, Tekin 1979, 127. Despite a widespread point of view (see e.g. ЭСТЯ 5, 277), Mong. can hardly be < Turk. The root (especially in the Turk.-Mong. area) is liable to mergers with \U*k`i̯ubu\u 'coffin' and \U*k`áp`a\u 'barrier' q.v.
Цинциус 1984, 85, Дыбо 9. A Western isogloss.

KW 167, Poppe 43, ОСНЯ 1, 315, АПиПЯЯ 289 (but the Jpn. form should be kept separate, see \U*k`apa\u). A Western isogloss. The root is expressive and tends to contaminate with \U*kap`e\u 'to squeeze, pinch' (q. v.), as well as with \U*k`épà\u `side' (in Mong.: 'to grasp' > 'press' > 'flatten, flat'), but nevertheless reconstructable for PA (despite Doerfer's doubts in TMN 3, 374); borrowing in Mong. < Turk. is quite improbable, despite Щербак 1997, 133.
The cluster *-jr- is reconstructed to account for the loss of *-r- in Korean.
Цинциус 1984, 86.
EAS 46, 111, KW 169, Цинциус 1984, 87. Cf. Old Koguryo *kaš 'plough' (thus in Miller 1979, 13; Lee has *kal; the isolated Manchu χalχan 'ploughshare' may be < Kor.).
The root is not widely represented (a Turk.-Mong. isogloss), but it seems reasonable to distinguish it from \U*k`ĭrma\u q.v.
Poppe 17, 82. A Western isogloss.
In Mong. cf. also qorgaj 'brocade' ( > Chag. qurgaj id.), which, however, may be alternatively compared with PT *kürk 'fur, fur coat' (ЭСТЯ 5, 148-149).

SKE 103 (Turk.-Kor.; despite TMN 3, 596, Kor. kəsk- is not a teleologischer Sternchenform"). Cf. also Nan. (Bik.) kesi- 'to cut out' - with quite inexplicable k- (a borrowing?). Reasons for prenasalization in Jpn. are unclear (perhaps a suffixed form like *k`ắsi-gu-n is reflected)."
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss; cf. also Bur. xasuuri, xasuurgana, xasuurha(n) 'fir-tree' ( < TM?).
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
Cf. *kā́na.
JOAL 102, 1981, 853 (attracting also OJ núr- 'to paint', which seems less plausible because of tone incongruence with *nì; on its etymology see *ni̯úŕe).

EAS 147, KW 243, Poppe 110 (but  Kor. kurək 'small sack' is derived < kur- 'roll, wrap' and does not belong here). Despite Щербак 1977, 128, the Mong. form is hard to explain as a Turkic loanword. Irregular labialization in Turk. is probably caused by the simplification of the cluster with labial -b-.

Martin 225, KW 201, Владимирцов 255, АПиПЯЯ 15, 38-39, 67, 92, 274, Лексика 107. Regular except for tone variation in Japanese, possibly due to interaction of several similar PA roots (see *gébo, *k`epa, *k`i̯ā̀bu, *kèp`i).

One of several similar roots, actively interacting with each other - see notes to *k`[ā]p`a 'to cover'. Mong. *kabi-čak 'groin' is a result of secondary semantic development, probably < *'scrotum' or 'hymen' (cf. the meanings in Turkic).
EAS 144, KW 232, Poppe 114, Дыбо 12, Лексика 96, TMN 3, 568, ЭСТЯ 6, 226. A Western isogloss; in Turkic contaminating with the reflex of *giru q.v.
Closed *ạ̄ in Turkic is not clear.

Цинциус 1984, 124. In Turkic the root is preserved basically in Oghuz languages; it obviously obtained initial *g- (*k- would be normally expected) under the double influence of *gēp- 'to swell (of belly)' and *gebre- 'fragile'.
Martin 250 (Kor.-Jpn.). An Eastern isogloss. The irregular high tone in MKor. may be due to contraction after the loss of *-b-. Cf. OT (MK Ganǯaki) kevli 'the mouth of a canal' (EDT 689).
АПиПЯЯ 289, Дыбо 11.
Miller 1985, 143. An exact Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.

Miller 1975, 157-72, 1985, 151, АПиПЯЯ 38, 80, 285, Лексика 107. The Mong. word belongs here with high probability, although medial -j- is not quite clear: the form is perhaps a dissimilation < *kari-ra- (a similar process *-lVl- > -jVl- is widely spread).
A Western isogloss.
АПиПЯЯ 76, 289. Cf. also comments to \U*si̯oga.\u
A common Altaic cultural term; despite the rare cluster *-lń- the reconstruction appears reliable.

MEANING: a k. of reed or leek
REFERENCE: Cf. \U*ki̯omga,\u \U*gi̯aŋu\u, \U*kemV\u.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
АПиПЯЯ 111, 276.
A derivative of the same root may be Mong. kiŋgan 'mountain ridge'.
ОСНЯ 1, 350, Цинциус 1984, 103. Mong. has secondary labialization (*köŋgen < *keńö-gen); depalatalization in Kor. is not quite clear. Otherwise correspondences are regular.
One should also note Mong. qajiči 'scissors' - possibly a contamination of this root with \U*kap`e\u q.v.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss, perhaps an expressive variant of *kĕ̀ŋi q. v.
Turk. > WMong. kebeg, whence Mongor kawaG (TMN 3, 580, Щербак 1997, 127). One of several similar PA roots (see *k`ā́p`a, *k`i̯ā̀bu, *kèp`i, *gébo).
KW 167. In Mong., due to secondary contaminations, the root is somewhat hard to distinguish from *k`ap`V `press, grasp' q.v.
Cf. \U*k`ápa\u (with a possibility of mergers).
Лексика 187. Cf. also names of 'bat': OJ kapapori, Evn. kêwêč (ТМС 1, 386). An expressive and not quite regular root.
In Mong. secondary contaminations with *kajira- 'burn, roast' were possible.

Turk. forms may be < Mong.  Note that the TM forms have nothing to do with Mong. ebčeɣün 'breast bone', despite Doerfer MT 20, Rozycki 65. The word probably had the original meaning 'rib', preserved in Western languages; the Korean and Japanese forms cannot be kept apart, but they deserve special comment: in both languages the root was naturally influenced by the reflexes of *kŏp`é 'bend' (q.v.); the Japanese form is also aberrant accentologically, shows rather *-m- than *-p- - and may in fact be a merger of the present root with PA *k`i̯ome 'marrow'.

MEANING: to dry out, become fragile; to break
REFERENCE: Cf. \U*kăpi\u (with possible contaminations).
Note a rare case of Jpn. -t- < *-ŕ- before -ə-; this should be probably explained by an early vowel assimilation: *kə̀tə̀pə̀k- < *kə̀tùpə̀k- (cf. also another attested variant, *kə̀tə̀pùk-).
Цинциус 1984, 127-128. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
An expressive root with not quite regular correspondences.

Martin (JLTT 441) unites Jpn. kase 'spool' and kase 'fetters, shackles'; the two words, however, are clearly opposed in OJ and seem to have quite different Altaic origin (on *kàsi 'fetters' see under PA *k`ìĺa). PJ *kasai 'spool' surely cannot be separated from PT *K(i)as- 'hoop, hoop brace'; the attribution of PTM *xesi- is less secure: it can belong here if we suppose a semantic development 'spool' > 'spool string' > 'string in net'.
Martin 1996, 75 (Jpn.-TM).
An expressive Western isogloss; cf. \U*k`ad[u],\u with a possibility of contaminations.

KW 172, Владимирцов 195, 318, SKE 132-133, Martin 233, TMN 1, 410, Lee 1958, 114, АПиПЯЯ 70. Mong. is hardly < Turk. (despite Щербак 1997, 137); Mong. > Man. qata- etc., see Doerfer MT 19, Rozycki 103.
A Western isogloss.

A rather complicated Western isogloss. The TM form is compared (in SKE 61-62, АПиПЯЯ 297) with Kor. hə̀i- 'swim'; this seems now dubious because of the apparent lack of development PA *k`- > Kor. *h-. The Korean word should rather be considered as having lost the initial vowel (*hə̀i- < *uhə̀i-) and be derived < PA \U*uku\u q.v. On the other hand, Evk. kajama, Orok qajama 'bare (not fur-lined) skis' are most probably borrowed < Mong. qaiba 'a k. of oar' (or perhaps from some unattested Yakut form, cf. the meaning 'skis' in Yak.?).

Цинциус 1984, 125-126, Дыбо 12. A Western isogloss. In PT *k- would be expected; initial voicing is probably due to the influence of another Altaic root, \U*kĕ̀ŋi\u 'empty' (PT *geŋiŕ 'nasal cavity'), cf. its reflexes in Mong. (keŋkeji- 'be wide and empty'; Щербак 1997, 127 actually regards the latter as borrowed from Turkic - which is quite dubious; see TMN 3, 612-613).
Владимирцов 201. Despite Щербак 1997, 134, the Mong. form is hardly borrowed from Turkic. Jpn. has an irregular high tone. On a possible Korean parallel see under *k`i̯ăli.
