Lee 1958, 115, АПиПЯЯ 18; a different analysis see in ОСНЯ 2,35.
АПиПЯЯ 297. Turk. > Mong. \Ial\i (KW 6, Щербак 1997, 97). The Jpn. parallel is quite convincing, despite a mismatch in tone (probably distorted in a long compound).
An interesting common Altaic root, with quite plausible phonetic and semantic correspondences; however, some contaminations with *nuŋu 'chief, master' were possible.
EAS 148, АПиПЯЯ 18, 43, 292; SKE 162-163. Medial *-j- has to be reconstructed to account for the peculiar vowel behaviour in Mong. and TM.
Дыбо 10, Лексика 146, 423. In Jpn. \I*ua\i would be expected - which would yield OJ \Iwo\i (therefore undistinguishable from *bua or \I*bə).\i
АПиПЯЯ 109, 276. The PTM form should be reconstructed with *-l- (despite АПиПЯЯ); therefore it belongs here rather than to PT *ȫn-, Mong. *ön-.

Дыбо 15. Ozawa 170 compares  the Jpn. form with Mong. arča- 'to quarrel, fight', but the latter is rather a reflex of \U*ēŕa\u q.v. We should note that the Jpn. form may also belong to a different root, PA *erV 'seek, contest' (a possible Mong.-Turk. isogloss, on which see under *īre 'reach').
АПиПЯЯ 18, Дыбо 12.
SKE 177, EAS 107. A Western isogloss. See also *gúri.
The original meaning is probably preserved in Mongolian, with a specialization ('heel' > 'heel strap, ski strap') in TM, and a generalization ('heel' > 'back') in Japanese.
АПиПЯЯ 18, 50, 101, 280, Мудрак Дисс. 102.

АПиПЯЯ 18, 55, 81, 104, 278 (with literature). Initial *n- in Jpn. is probably due to assimilation to the following nasal (the most usual form is *na-ni); there also exists an interrogative *i- (in *i-ka 'how', *i-n-ture 'which' etc., reflecting nasalless *ŋi-. Vocalism in this archaic monosyllabic pronoun is not quite clear, evidently because of different suffixation.

? Cf. also Turk. *üč (*öč) 'three' (ЭСТЯ 1, 641-642, Stachowski 254). The match is somewhat problematic, basically because of the absence of the TM cognate, shortness of the root and unclear suffixation. The basic phonological correspondence pointing to PA *ŋ- is, however, observed, and the parallel seems to be worth noting.
АПиПЯЯ 280. A Korean match (dubious) see in SKE 176.
Martin 234-235. Cf. TM: Nan. wasoana 'not long ago' (see ТМС 2, 295). Kor. ə- is probably a result of secondary assimilation ( < *ɨ̀čə́i or *ùčə́i).
KW 455, Владимирцов 153, Лексика 68-69. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Cf. also Mong. udaɣa, Mongor udā 'time' (MGCD 666). Nan. udur 'heat' may be borrowed < Mong.

The reconstruction of the diphthong in this root is based on PT *j-: one should suppose an early development *ŋi̯ō- > *jo- in Turkic (which explains the vocalic reflex). Cf.  \X<0.658>*i̯úgu\x 'up, above'  (which could also influence the Turkic form due to mutual influence of synonymous *jüg- and *jok-).
EAS 98, АПиПЯЯ 79, 99, 277.
ОСНЯ 1, 242, Ozawa 65-66 (Mong.-Jpn.).

Дыбо 10. Cf. Turkm. ülǯe 'cherry'; Kum., KBalk. ülkü 'bush, shrub', Bashk. ölköm id.? Despite Doerfer MT 81, Rozycki 217, TM cannot be < Mong. or vice versa. Cf. also *èri, *ùjrV. {Cf. PE *ulaʁi(ʁ) 'apple berry'}
Despite poor representation in TM, the root is well preserved elsewhere and appears to be well reconstructable for PA.
KW 191, Poppe 98, Дыбо 10. A Western isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Cf. *uk`e (with possible contaminations).
A possible comparison, but the Turkic reflexes are rather sparse and somewhat dubious.

MEANING: to die; to be hungry, exhausted
REFERENCE: A Western isogloss. See EAS 146, KW 295, Poppe 108 (but the Evk. form that he lists is probably < Mong.), TMN 2, 112, АПиПЯЯ 281, Дыбо 13; see further Nostratic parallels (Ural. *welV et al.) in МССНЯ, 367.
A Western isogloss. Somewhat dubious because of the possibly borrowed nature of the OT word.
A common derivative *olu-bV is reflected in Mong. *ul-ba-ji- and TM *ol-ba-n-.
Poppe 98. TMN 1, 178, Doerfer MT 25, Rozycki 167 consider Mo < TM, which is dubious.
PTM and PT probably reflect a common derivative *ŏ́mu-kV. The meaning 'buttocks' in Mong. gave rise to two widely separated semantic reflexes: a) > 'large intestine'; b) > 'back' > 'North'.
Poppe 68, Колесникова 1972a, 93-94, Дыбо 308; Лексика 241. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss, but, despite Щербак 1997, 129, not a loanword in Mong. < Turk.
KW 297, Лексика 233.
Jpn. ógór- 'be arrogant' = Mong. oŋgira- (a variant of the same root?).

MEANING: a k. of small wild animal
REFERENCE: An alternative match for PT could be Evk. hatala 'beaver' (ТМС 1, 384).

MEANING: to wear out, be wasted, have a bad {look}
REFERENCE: Cf. \U*apo,\u \U*ebi.\u
Дыбо 5, Лексика 277.
EAS 90, Владимирцов 210. A Western isogloss. Despite TMN 1, 182, Doerfer MT 142, Rozycki 215-216 not borrowed in Mong. from Turk. or in TM from Mong.
A Western isogloss.
KW 298, VEWT 375, АПиПЯЯ 288. A Western isogloss.
Lee 1958, 118 (TM-Kor.), Константинова 1972, 240-241, ТМС 2, 288, Rozycki 215.
МССНЯ 345 (Mong.-Tung.). An expressive root. Mong. may be < Turk. Cf. also notes to *ū́lo.
Murayama 1962, 110 (Jpn.-TM). Cf. \U*ōŕi\u (the two roots are liable to mergers).

A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Phonetically a good match would be Jpn. *úrúsí 'lacquer' ( < *'liquid'?), but semantics raises doubts. Poppe 102 compares *urus- with Evk. urigden 'backwater' - the same comparison see in ОСНЯ 1, 240-241. Cf. also Yak. ürex, Dolg. ürek 'river' (Stachowski 253) - suggesting that *-si might be an original suffix.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.

EAS 102, Poppe 65, Finch 1987, 58. Despite TMN 2, 135, Щербак 1997, 131, Clark 1980, 51, Mong. ös cannot be borrowed from Turk. *ȫč (see *ṓč`e). Attempts to disprove the Turk.-Tung. match in TMN 2, 149-150 are unsuccessful.
The Kor. form (attested only in SKE) has a frequent loss of initial vowel.
An Eastern isogloss.
KW 302, Владимирцов 323, Poppe 51, АПиПЯЯ 286. Despite TMN 2, 134, not borrowed in Mong. < Turk.

It is not quite clear whether PTM *utē-n and PJ *ùtàina point to a common derivative *ŏ̀t`ù-nV; because of the diphthong in the second syllable Jpn. may rather reflect a compound with some obscure second element.
Цинциус 1972a, 31-32, Дыбо 7. Voiced -g in OT is not quite clear; otherwise correspondences are regular.
Poppe 64, TMN 2, 225 (semantisch möglich
column17: nicht mehr")."

REFERENCE: ЭСТЯ 1, 503. An expressive  Western isogloss.
SKE 285 (Turk. : Kor.), АПиПЯЯ 288.
SKE 174, Menges 1984, 281-282, АПиПЯЯ 284. Note the loss of *-l- in Kor. and some Turkic forms, which may indicate the original monosyllabic nature of the verb (*ṑl).
? Cf. OT oŋužin 'a k. of devil'; TM *ogiaŋä 'evil spirit' ( + Orok oŋdo id.; < Mong.?).

Владимирцов 164; Ozawa 57-59; АПиПЯЯ 18, 290. Comparison with Tung. (see АПиПЯЯ) should be abandoned. Ramstedt (SKE 55) compares  Kor. ənč- (MKor. jə̀nč-) 'to put on the top,  place  above' (?), considering  Kor. undu to be a mongolism.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.

The root is very similar to *i̯ū́ńa 'pit, ravine' and *i̯ŭ́ne 'notch (on arrow)' q.v., and there could have been some interaction between them - which could, in particular, explain Turk. -n instead of the expected *-ń.

A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. Some of the TM forms could have been influenced by reflexes of *i̯òmke 'to crawl, move' (q.v.). In Mong. cf. also (with a velar suffix) WMong. oŋqu, Kalm. oŋxə 'head over heels' (KW 287), Khalkha onxoldo- `to fall head over heels'. {Cf. PE *in-[r]aʁ- 'to lie down, go to bed', *iŋ-aʁ- 'to lie'.}
EAS 78, Владимирцов 211. An expressive root. Cf. also Turk. *öp- 'to kiss' (ЭСТЯ 1, 539); Mong. *aɣa-ki-la- (L 25 akila-, Khalkha āxila-) 'to gasp for breath, pant'; Evn. ābu- 'to kiss' (ТМС 1, 6).
Мудрак Дисс. 199; Лексика 323. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss - but hardly borrowed in Mong. < Turk., despite TMN 2, 133.

Poppe 110 (Turk.-Mong.). Mong. *ör-mege may be < Turk. (cf. TMN 2, 47, Щербак 1997, 197), but may also reflect a common Turk.-Mong. derivative. The Turk. form can be alternatively compared with TM *poro-, *pori- 'turn round, spin', Mong. hor-či- id. (see \U*p`i̯áru\u), but the Turk.-Mong.-Jpn. comparison seems closer semantically.
The Turkic form strongly suggests that PJ *bə̀rə̀tì is a contraction of a longer *ə̀bə̀rə̀tì.
EAS 112, KW 298, Poppe 81, АПиПЯЯ 74, Лексика 90. Despite TMN 2, 146, not borrowed in Mong. < Turk. Cf. \U*òru.\u

SKE 178, EAS 107, ОСНЯ 1, 254. Despite Щербак 1997, 131 the Mong. stem cannot be regarded as a Turkic loanword. The root is sometimes difficult to distinguish from \U*p`ōre\u q.v. See also notes to \U*p`i̯ŏlge.\u

EAS 122, Poppe 80, 83, 111. Mong. may be < Turk., see Щербак 1997, 162. There is also a possibility of confusion of this root with \U*p`i̯uri\u q.v. - in Turkic their reflexes could have merged, and in Mong. some dialects (cf. the Dagur form) may reflect *hürgü-.

KW 291, ОСНЯ 2, 104, АПиПЯЯ 70, 97, 102, 278, Martin 234, Лексика 356. The Mong. form may belong here if *očkin < *očikin < *oti-kin; however, it may also reflect PA \U*p`ōči\u 'spark' q.v. Korean has a frequent loss of initial vowel. Tone in Jpn. is irregular.
EAS 146, KW 302, Poppe 51, 107 (Mong.-Chuv.-Tung.), Дыбо 11, Лексика 85. Despite Doerfer MT 46, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong.

Cf. \U*bā̀di.\u {Note Austronesian forms: Mar banderaŋ 'ceremonial tasseled spear', Mal benderaŋ 'spear with a tuft of goat's hair on the shaft; an emblem of royalty'; PAN *bandaŋan 'goat hair decoration on a spear or staff'}

An Eastern isogloss. Turk. \I*bat-\i may be a contamination of this root with \U *pat`a\u  q.v. The Korean match is somewhat dubious semantically, unless one presumes a semantic development 'float' < 'be wet, flow'; this may be corroborated by apparently related (dialectal?) variants MKor. pàthắ- 'to strain, filter' and MKor. phjə́tì- 'to overflow'. Ramstedt (SKE 191) compares the TM forms with MKor. pằrằ- 'to plaster, smear', which is dubious (see \U *píla\u ).
An Eastern isogloss. Cf. \U*bi̯uk`[e].\u Kor. *phắkái < *pago-kai ( = PTM *pagakī), which explains seemingly irregular tone correspondence between Kor. and Jpn.

MEANING: a k. of fish or sea animal
REFERENCE: Лексика 178. The vocalism reflects a variation between *pak`o (in most languages) and *pak`u ( > Jpn. *púká), perhaps under the influence of a similar fish name \U*bek`u\u q.v.
EAS 55-56, AKE 14, ОСНЯ 3, 95, АПиПЯЯ 109, 278. An Eastern isogloss. Jpn. reflects a suffixed form *pal(a)-gV (cf. Nan. paloa).

KW 7, Poppe 11, Цинциус 1984, 30-31, Doerfer MT 22, Rozycki 78 (although, despite the two latter authors, in this case one can hardly think of a loanword). A Western isogloss. May be an old Wanderwort" (cf. PIE *pelek'u-). Low tone and shortness reconstructed because of Mong. *h-."
An Eastern isogloss. {Cf. PE *pinŋi- (~ *pińi-) 'good, beautiful.}

АПиПЯЯ 68, 280, Дыбо 13. In Jpn. 'thin' < 'pressed, compressed'. The root is actively interacting with \U*pĭ̀sa\u and \U*p`i̯úsa\u q. v. The vowel variation in Japanese dialects may point to a variant *pằse.
Poppe 89. Korean has a usual verbal" low tone. See also \U*pagdi
column17: \u \U*p`etV.\u"

REFERENCE: An Eastern isogloss. Aspiration in Korean may be due to secondary affixation (*phó < *po-h- < *pVbV-g-); however, a reconstruction *pāgu- is not excluded for PTM, and therefore the PA form may be as well reconstructed as *pājgu (*-j- is needed anyway to explain fricativization in Japanese).

An expressive root with somewhat violated correspondences. Cf. some similar bird names: Khak. pegem 'wood-hen',  Bur. bug-bātar 'owl' (if the analysis 'demon-hero' is a folk etymology); Oroch bajakuli 'name of a bird', Man. bajbula 'magpie'.
PA length is responsible for the preservation of b- in Mong. (otherwise *halči- would be expected).
VEWT 61, KW 31 (but Kalm. balɣă zaɣăsn̆ 'a k. of fish', also compared by Ramstedt, is a Turkism), SKE 185, АПиПЯЯ 282, Дыбо 8, Лексика 177.
KW 42, SKE 150, Лексика 98. Mong. may be borrowed from Turk. (see TMN 1, 238, Щербак 1997, 104).
Лексика 182. Mergers with \U*p`unte\u were possible (which may explain the non-etymological -n- in TM). Cf. also Kor. pindä 'bedbug'?
EAS 112, KW 41, Poppe 53 (Turk.-Mong.). Despite Щербак 1997, 163, Mong. cannot be borrowed < Turk. High tone reconstructed because of Mong. *b-. See also notes to *méru.

MEANING: a figure made of stone or clay
REFERENCE: The comparison is very tempting, although one has to suppose secondary folk-etymological reanalysis in Mong. (where barimal /a regular development < *balima-r/) is associated with bari- 'to build', and in Jpn., where all the variants are  associated with pani 'red clay'.
SKE 189.
A Western isogloss. High tone reconstructed because of Mong. *b-.

Shortness and low tone reconstructed because of Mong. *(h)-. The etymology is somewhat questionable because of late attestation in Turkic and a possibility of an alternative analysis of the Korean form (see above).
АПиПЯЯ 68, 90 (with literature), 274, Martin 243. See also notes on *boga. Medial *-j- is reconstructed to account for the loss of -l- in Korean; Mong. *h- before a long vowel indicates PA *p`-.
Cf. \U*bàka\u which could have influenced some of the reflexes (in particular, the accentological irregularity of Jpn. *pàkàr- may be explained  by  a secondary analogy with *bàkàr-).
KW 43. A Western isogloss. For Turkic cf. alternatively Mong. marma- 'be covered with scars' (cf. traces of nasalization in Turkic languages).
PA length is responsible for the preservation of b- in Mong. (otherwise *höǯi- would be expected).
Martin 238 (Kor.-Jpn.). Irregular vowel in Korean (*parV- would be expected) can be probably explained by vowel assimilation, as well as by secondary adjustment of this root to părăm 'wall' q.v.
JOAL 119.

Shortness and low tone reconstructed because of Mong. *h-. A Western isogloss; cf. perhaps OJ p(j)e- in p(j)è-wò 'foot-cord for a falcon' (wo 'cord, rope'), although the word pe is not attested separately. PJ *pìa < *pĭ̀l(e)-gV would be a very good match for Mong. *heliɣe.
Егоров 171 (Chuv.-Mong.), Лексика 209 (with a different Turkic parallel), Robbeets 2000, 111.
KW 46, Martin 237. Despite Doerfer's skepticism (TMN 2, 311), Ramstedt's comparison still holds. Low tone in Jpn. is perhaps due to contraction (it does not match either Kor. or *b- in Mong.).
An Eastern isogloss.
An Eastern isogloss. Mergers of this root with \U*pằsi\u and \U*p`i̯úsa\u q.v. were possible.
An isolated TM form without secure etymology.
An Eastern isogloss. Kor. phí < *pìhí (with vowel reduction).

EAS 56, KW 31, Владимирцов 147-148, ОСНЯ 3, 91-92, Sinor 1981 (listing all forms but considering the Turkic word to be borrowed from Ugric), Дыбо 15, Мудрак Дисс. 194. Despite TMN 1, 216, 2, 258, Щербак 1997, 104 the Mong. form is hardly borrowed from Turk. Jpn. *pá-i presupposes a form *pi̯ắl(a)-gV = TM *palVga etc. Note that this is a case of monophthongization after *p- in TM (cf. similarly *pi̯ari, *pi̯āki).

Martin 228, Лексика 174. An expressive root with not quite precise correspondences (like in many bird names). Vocalism is rather hard to reconstruct: in PT we have to assume a secondary delabialization (*buldɨr- > *bɨldur-). Note velar suffixation in several Turkic and Mongolian forms; the PJ form also may go back to *pi̯oltor-ga > *pi̯oltoɣa > *patua.
An onomatopoeic Eastern isogloss.

Whitman 1985, 153-154, 210 (Kor.-Jpn.). Jpn. *pia < *pi̯àr(i)-ga (cf. TM *par-ga-) or < *pi̯àr(i)-ŋa (cf. PT *biar-ŋa-k). For the reflex *-a- in TM see notes to *pi̯alagV. The original meaning is 'finger, finger width', whence 'bedding, layer (one finger thick")'. Such a combination of meanings is still clearly seen in TM (without which the Turkic and Jpn.-Kor. forms would be hardly comparable)."
OJ pətə-pə-r- and PM *hata-ɣa-  may reflect a common derivative *pi̯ằt`è-p`V.
АПиПЯЯ 45, 286, Мудрак Дисс. 196-197, Лексика 278. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss, demonstrating again the rule of monophthongization in PTM after *p- (see *pi̯alagV, *pi̯ari).
In Turkic one has to suppose the semantic development 'mighty, severe' > 'heavy' (cf. similarly 'important, authoritative' > 'heavy' in Mong., see under *kuńi). Cf. also *pek`i.
Poppe 51, KW 36, PKE 146-147. The Kor. form is expressive and not quite regular.
Дыбо 11. Kor. *phá < *puhá ~ *păhá with usual vowel reduction. The Turkic forms are very scantily attested and somewhat dubious (one would rather expect *bagɨr).
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. High tone can be reconstructed because of Mong. *b-.
If the Negidal form belongs here, it may reflect, together with PT *bAńak, a common derivative *beńa-kV.
A Western isogloss. High tone may be reconstructed because of Mong. *b-. Reflected are forms with different suffixes (*pi̯oro-k`V and *pi̯oro-gV).
In PT *bos- would be expected; the root had changed to *bas- probably because of the folk-etymological resemblance to *bas- 'press'. Cf. *bi̯ási 'penthouse'.
A Western isogloss.

Correspondences are basically regular, with the following comments: in Turkic one has to suppose secondary delabialization *bĳ- < *büj- ( < *büb-); the Kor. form pjàpắi- must be denominative, derived from a noun *pjàpắ- < *pibV-pu- < *pi̯ubi-p`u- ( = PTM *pubu-pu-). Cf. \U*p`i̯ōpo\u : the two roots are sometimes hard to distinguish.

EAS 144, KW 47, ОСНЯ 1, 178. In Turk. also OT biče 'small', Tuva biče id. Cf. also MKor. pčằ- 'to wring out, squeeze' (SKE 18); MKor. pči- 'to cut' (SKE 32); mod. pit-ta (piǯ-) 'cut, slice'. Doerfer's (TMN 2, 427) doubts are hardly justified - the semantic development in Mong. is perfectly well explainable. One should note, however, that low tone in Jpn. does not correspond to Mong. *b- here (one would rather expect *h-); either this is an incorrect tone notation (the Jpn. word is attested in RJ, but not accented in Hirayama's dictionary), or an irregularity in an expressive etymon.

АПиПЯЯ 292 (without the Jpn. parallel). See Poppe 11, 55, Цинциус 1984, 42. Despite Poppe 1966, 198, 1972, 99, Doerfer MT 132, Rozycki 78 the TM forms are hardly borrowed from Mong. {A different, but similar Altaic root may be reflected in Mong. bogoni 'short', MTurk. (EDT 322) boɣaj 'short, low'.}
Лексика 185.
Лексика 72 (but the Turkic root should be divided and Mong. *boli- attributed rather to *pŭ́lo 'old, ancient -  although the two roots may have converged in Mong.).
Дыбо 9, Лексика 177-178.

EAS 58, KW 53, Владимирцов 277, Poppe 21 (although words for 'slave' should be kept apart, see \U*bŏga\u); Дыбо 15 (compares TM *bōki-, see \U*bṑki\u). A Western isogloss. Shortness and high tone are reconstructed because of Mong. *b-; note, however, that Mong. can be borrowed from Turk. (see TMN 2, 346, Щербак 1997, 108). If this is the case, the real Mong. reflex could be *bög-si- 'choke', *böɣe-lǯi- 'vomit', suggesting a reconstruction *pŏ́ge or *pŏ́gi.

KW 57, Владимирцов 195, Martin 250, АПиПЯЯ 68, Дыбо 6, Лексика 278. Despite TMN 2, 353, Щербак 1997, 108, there is no need at all to suppose Mong. < Turkic. The variant *puki- in TM is assimilative ( < *pugi-). Cf. also MKor. pùrə̀i 'fish bladder'.
KW 58, Лексика 152. A Western isogloss. High tone reconstructed because of Mong. *b-.

MEANING: to dig, cut off; a cutting instrument
REFERENCE: Cf. other similar roots: \U *p`i̯ùjge,\u  \U*bā̀k`ù,\u   \U *p`ū̀ge,\u  \U *p`ago.\u
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss; high tone can be reconstructed because of Mong. *b-. Cf. perhaps also Jpn. coll. fuke- 'to run away, flee' (dubious because of very late fixation).
Poppe 21, Ozawa 288-289, ОСНЯ 1, 188-189, АПиПЯЯ 69. Cf. *boru, a contamination with which should explain Mong. *b- (one would expect *h- with low tone and shortness).
Cf. also Yak. bötüön 'грудная кость'; Az. pötänä 'потроха'.
Murayama 1962, 110, АПиПЯЯ 80, 107, 277. An Eastern isogloss. Jpn. has a contraction (like in *kík- < *k`ūjlu-k`-).

Lee 1958, 119 (Kor.-Mong.). Cf. also MKor. pthə̄k 'reason'; without vowel reduction perhaps also MKor. pùrə́, mod. purə 'intentionally, on purpose'. Mong. > Evk. bodo- etc. (see ТМС 1, 88, Doerfer MT 78). The Jpn. reflex is not quite certain, being somewhat distant semantically and aberrant accentologically (TM length should correspond to low tone in Jpn.). The voicing in modern dialects (Tok. hodo etc.) also contradicts *-t- in *pōto. One should consider a possibility of relating Kor. pthə̄k and PJ *pətua (*pə(n)tua) to PA *p`ēt[e] 'name, to call' ('name' as the essence or reason of the called object?) which would be phonologically more plausible (assuming Gruntov's rule about *C`VCV > *CVC`V in early PJ).

KW 446, Poppe 12, 52, Цинциус 1984, 52-53, Дыбо 10, Лексика 104. Despite some confusion between *pōt`o and \U*p`ude,\u the two roots are clearly distinguishable. Kor. *pə̀tɨ́r must be delabialized < *pòtɨ́r.
EAS 96, Martin 249-250, АПиПЯЯ 109, 278. Korean has a frequent vowel reduction between a stop and an affricate, which makes the precise vowel reconstruction difficult.
Дыбо 10, Лексика 150. A Western isogloss. High tone is reconstructed because of Mong. *b-. The root is actively contaminating with \U*bŏ̀ku\u 'throat' q.v.
An expressive root.{}

AKE 14, Lee 1958, 110, EAS 53, 143, KW 448, Poppe 12, 74, Цинциус 1984, 54, Menges 1984, 287, АПиПЯЯ 40, 291, Rozycki 80-81. Despite Poppe 1972, 100, Doerfer MT 23, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong (and vice versa, as suggested in TMN 1, 540); borrowing in Kor. from TM is also highly improbable.

EAS 55, Цинциус 1984, 61, АПиПЯЯ 78, 277, Rozycki 82. Despite Doerfer MT 80, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong. Initial *p`- (not *p-) is reconstructed because of *h- in Mong. and high pitch in Jpn. Cf. *póńe.
ТМС 2,43-44, Цинциус 1984, 54-55, АПиПЯЯ 295. In Korean one has to presume a semantic shift smoking place" > "kitchen"."

EAS 53, 141, SKE 205, KW 286, 295, Poppe 11, 69, Цинциус 1984, 43. Despite Doerfer MT 143, Rozycki 78-79, the TM forms meaning 'time' are hardly < Mong. Cf. perhaps also Jpn. *pàrû 'spring' (if -ru is regarded as a suffix  < *pUn-ra); see Whitman 1985, 188, 202, 211.
Poppe 72 (Mong.-Kor.). The stem may be derived from *p`úńe 'smell' q.v.
Jpn. *pá presupposes a suffixed form  *púr(e)-gV ( = Mong. *bor-gu-).
Laufer 1919, 575 (Doerfer: lautlich unmöglich"). Cf. perhaps Nan. furgẽ 'loud
column17: bass' (ТМС 2
column18: 303). The final velar element is suffixed
column19: and the suffixes are different here (Jpn. -k- pointing to *-k`- or -k-

REFERENCE: Цинциус 1984, 56. A Western isogloss. Low tone is reconstructed because of Mong. *h-.
Whitman 1985, 191, АПиПЯЯ 283, Лексика 215. Turk. \I*bur-\i  must be a secondary assimilation < *bɨr-.
High tone is reconstructed because of Mong. *b-; voicing in Jpn. is unclear.
Reason for voicing (prenasalization) in Jpn. is not quite clear.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.
The Mong. form has a strange variation of *h- and *0-, so far unexplained.

Turk. *baĺ(č)ka 'other' is very similar, but phonetically unclear. Another irregularity is the tonal discrepancy between TM and Kor.-Jpn. (note that the TM reconstruction is not quite certain: one should perhaps reconstruct *pubuski because of the Even form, and either separate the TM form from the rest or suppose a form with a cluster like *pubsa). On the whole, a tempting but not quite secure etymology.
See SKE 207. An expressive root; cf. *buk`V.
An onomatopoeic Kor.-Jpn. isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss; cf. perhaps Nan. pāčila- 'жечь багульник во время камлания'.
A Western isogloss. KW 18, Poppe 63, Цинциус 1984, 36-37 (with somewhat different TM data), TMN 2, 14 (:semantisch unwahrscheinlich")."
PTM *padu and PJ *pítú may reflect a common derivative like *padi-bV (otherwise final -u is hard to explain).

Cf. perhaps also Chuv. pora 'сруб'. See Redei 4,347. The Kor. form can be formally analysed as derived from pằrằ- 'to plaster', but this is probably a result of secondary reinterpretation (see under *pila).
KW 2. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.

KW 1, Poppe 52, VEWT 5 (Turk.-Mong.; but the Kor. parallel listed there - patak 'bottom, foundation' - should be rather compared with TM *pata 'id.', see *p`át`a(-kV)), АПиПЯЯ 282, Лексика 288. Despite TMN 4, 266 Mong. cannot be < Turk. Further Nostr. parallels (PIE *ped- 'foot' etc.) see in МССНЯ, 368.
SKE 212, EAS 56. Kor. phằ- is a result of usual reduction < *pVhằ-.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss. In Turkic cf. perhaps either Karakh. (MK) ojuq 'mirage' or *bej > Chuv. paj `frost'.

MEANING: to rub off, wipe off, cut off
REFERENCE: One of the common Altaic Verba des Schlagens"
column17: with a rather uncertain semantics. The basic meaning seems to be "rub off
column18: peel off"
column20: tear into small pieces" etc. MMong. xa'ut- may reflect the same derivative as PT *ajɨt-

MEANING: to insert, shut in, sew in
REFERENCE: An Eastern isogloss.
Цинциус 1984, 31. An Eastern isogloss. The Korean etymology in SKE  187 - to TM *pak- 'dark' - is hardly plausible). Cf. perhaps also TM *pāŋ-sa- ( < *pań-ŋsa?) 'black'.
Цинциус 1984, 31-32. See also Miller-Naumann 1991, Miller 1998 (connecting it with Old Chinese \I*pap\i 'law'), and recently Stachowski 2001 (although Yak. aba 'gift' should be rather kept apart).
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. In TM cf. perhaps Evn. hapkon- 'to sit in ambush' (ТМС 2, 316).
A rather abstract common Altaic root. Note WMong. abu-ri which can probably be identified with Man. fafu-ri < *pap`ó-rV (but MJ faberi is rather < *pampi ari, with a Jpn. auxiliary verb.
Lee 1958, 109 compares the TM forms also with Kor. dial. paradi, paraǯi 'a window in the wall'.
EAS 53, 125, Poppe 11, Цинциус 1984, 33. A Western isogloss.

Poppe 11, 77, 78-79, Цинциус 1984, 32-33, Ramstedt 1916, 3, Lee 1958, 108, Лексика 555, Rozycki 74. The root is frequently quoted, but indeed rather problematic (cf. TMN 2, 40-41). If the Mong. form is *aral (accounting for the HY and South Mong. evidence), and the Turkic form is borrowed from a different source, all we are left with are the Tungus and Korean forms - which, however, are difficult to explain as loans.
See KW 128 (Turk.-Mong.), Лексика 86.  Korean has a frequent vowel reduction between a stop and a fricative.
KW 5, 16, Poppe 65, Цинциус 1984, 34-35. The Mong. parallel is somewhat dubious semantically.

The root should be distinguished from \U*bàšo\u q.v. (cf. the distinction in Manchu), although some contaminations were possible. Note a peculiar alternation *-s-/*-č- both in TM and Kor., possibly indicating an old suffixed variant *p`asi-č`V. PJ *pasir- 'run', because of its vocalism, is rather to be attributed to PA \U*p`eĺo\u q.v.

The root is very similar phonetically to *p`ắt`à(-kV) 'bottom, lower side' and the two roots could in fact have influenced each other in Turkic and Japanese. The TM languages, however, clearly oppose them. The TM evidence may indeed point to a different second vowel in 'fish fin' - perhaps a reconstruction like *p`átì(kV) would be more plausible; in the latter case the -a-vocalism in Jpn. would be secondary, under the influence of *p`ắt`à(-kV) 'bottom'.
EAS 53, SKE 192-193, Poppe 51, 82, Menges 1984, 284, АПиПЯЯ 16, 67, Martin 231.

EAS 52, KW 1, Poppe 11, 50, Цинциус 1984, 35, 36, Lee 1958, 109, АПиПЯЯ 70, Дыбо 317, Лексика 252-253, Rozycki 75. In Kor. cf. perhaps also MKor. pə̀thə́ŋ 'step (of stairs)', ptɨ́r 'staircase', 'yard'. The original meaning was no doubt 'bottom', 'bottom side', with a subsequent development > 'bottom of hand or foot' > 'sole, palm' in the Western Altaic region. In Turkic and Mongolian such a semantic change was probably favoured by a contamination with yet another PA root, *p`et`V 'to pinch' (q.v.), so that the final meaning resulted in 'take a handful, clutch'.
Korean has a frequent vowel loss between two stops (which occurred before *-d- > -r- and thus explains medial -t-). Correspondences are regular except for the aberrant high tone in Jpn.
Mong. *h- before a long vowel indicates PA *p`-.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss; MKor. pàhói could also be related (if separated from *bi̯úge q.v.).
Martin 238, АПиПЯЯ 67.

A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. Original vowel length is not quite clear: in Turkic the reconstruction is based only on the absence of pharyngealization in Tuva-Tof., while in TM critical evidence is lacking from Evk. and Nan. {WMo elberi- 'to respect or honour parents or elders'.}.

EAS 107, KW 7, Poppe 95, Цинциус 1984, 27-28, ОСНЯ 3, 94-95, Дыбо 317, Лексика 252, Doerfer MT 22, Rozycki 73 (but note that TM forms meaning 'foot, sole' should be certainly kept apart, see *pằlka). The Mong.-Tung. match here seems impeccable, and (despite MT and Rozycki) borrowing is excluded. The Turkic form presents problems with a unique cluster development *-ĺŋ- > *-lń- > -ń-, but still is probably the reflex of the same root. The Korean form may belong here if we suppose a secondary semantic development 'palm' > 'handful' > 'armful'.
The original meaning, still well traceable in Mong. and Jpn., must have been 'to follow (smb.) secretly, investigate stealthily'.
AKE 15, EAS 139, KW 13, Poppe 96, АПиПЯЯ 73, Цинциус 1984, 34, Мудрак Дисс. 182.
EAS 56. An Eastern isogloss.
The Evk. word, albeit isolated in TM, builds a good bridge between the Turkic and the Korean forms.
Poppe 61, Цинциус 1984, 45; Miller 1985, 147-148.

EAS 96, PKE 32, Цинциус 1984, 72.  A Western isogloss. Despite Poppe 1966, 198, 1972, 99, Doerfer MT 98, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong. A Western isogloss: the Korean parallel mentioned in PKE 32 (č:i- 'be inferior to, weakened') is unreliable - probably a misreading of či- id.
SKE 203. MKor. pɨ̀skɨ́rì- = pɨ̀čkɨ́rì- (-s- and -č- are usually neutralized in this position).
The meaning 'horrible' in Japanese must be secondary, going back to < 'extreme' < 'powerful, energetic', reflected elsewhere.

Martin 226, АПиПЯЯ 12, 13, 39-40, 67, 92, 274, Лексика 286. The irregular tone correspondence between Turk. and Kor.-Jpn. here should be probably explained by a secondary contraction *-ej- > *-ẹ̄- in PT. The medial *-j- is also responsible for the loss of *-ń- in Kor. and for the emergence of *j- in Mong. (*ja-su < *jan-su < *p`ejńe-sV). Kor. has here the *s-prefix (cf. also *s-kòrí 'tail', *s-pɨ́r 'horn').

SKE 62 (Mong.-Tung., incorrectly criticized in TMN 1, 554), 213. Turk. > WMong. beki, bekü > Evk. beki (see Doerfer TMN 1, 238, MT 101). Low tone and shortness reconstructed because of Mong. *h-. Cf. also *p`i̯àka 'mighty' (the two roots could interfere because of similarity).
EAS 53. A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.
ТМС 2, 304. A Western isogloss.
KW 118, АПиПЯЯ 294, Poppe 56, Lee 1958, 109. Despite Doerfer MT 236, TM is not borrowed from Mong. Mong. *h- (not b-) before a long vowel indicates PA *p`.

MEANING: to mock; to feel mocked at, be shy, distracted
REFERENCE: Цинциус 1984, 68.
Цинциус 1984, 46-47, JOAL 119, Street 1985, 646.

A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss; cf. perhaps Khalkha omgono- 'to chew with a toothless mouth'. On another possibility of finding Turkic and Mongolian matches see under *emV. {Cf. PAA *pVm,  *bʔu:m 'hold in mouth').
Cf. notes to \U*p`ujme\u for possible reflexes in Manchu, Jurchen and Korean.
A Western isogloss.
SKE 197-198. Most languages reveal a variation of meanings 'gap' > 'to gape' ( > 'laugh, smile, be perplexed'). On a possible trace of this root in Mong. see \U*àŋa\u.
An expressive root (possibly denoting originally some kind of locust or grasshopper), with some tabooistic changes in Turkic and Mongolian.
Цинциус 1984, 69-70, АПиПЯЯ 12, 281, ЭСТЯ 1, 301. Jpn. *piari instead of *piri probably under the influence of *pia 'edge, border' q.v. (or else it may indicate a reconstruction *p`èjrì). Cf. *p`ire.
Poppe 103, Цинциус 1984, 70. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Martin 230, Дыбо 14.  Cf. also MKor. pjə̀rằ- 'to purpose, intend' (cf. SKE 198).

EAS 54, KW 125, Владимирцов 285, Poppe 11, 79, ОСНЯ 3, 73-76, Цинциус 1984, 71, ЭСТЯ 1, 299, Дыбо 318-321, Мудрак Дисс. 194, Лексика 253-255, Rozycki 76. A Western isogloss. Assumption of Mong. < Turk. (Щербак 1997, 116) is impossible. Cf. also Mong. (h)arba- 'to spread (of fingers)'. It is also interesting to note the equation (see Lee 1958, 109) of Manchu fereχe siŋguri (lit. 'fingered mouse') 'bat' = MKor. pā̆rk-čúi id. (čui 'mouse'). This may be a trace of the root in Korean; however, also possible is a local merger (in Korean and Manchu) of this root with PA *p`ore 'feather, wing' - in that case the compounds would mean rather 'winged mouse'.
EAS 54, 102, Poppe 11, 65, , ОСНЯ 3, 77-78, Цинциус 1984, 71-72, АПиПЯЯ 79. Despite Doerfer MT 22, Rozycki 76, TM is not < Mong.
Lee 1958, 109. A Tung.-Kor. isogloss, with usual vowel loss between two stops in Kor. Cf. \U*pat`a.\u  On possible reflexes in Turkic and Mongolian (a result of contamination) see under *p`ắt`à(-kV).
An Eastern isogloss. Cf. also Kor. ptə̄r- 'shake'.
A Western isogloss.
Martin 226, АПИПЯЯ 67, Лексика 186.
KW 1, АПиПЯЯ 15, 71, 280 (with an erroneous Jpn. match, see \U*ā̀ja\u). A Western isogloss.
For semantics cf. MKor. săr 'flesh, muscle', 'skin'. АПиПЯЯ 283, Дыбо 14, Лексика 455.

The parallel seems interesting (with a semantic development 'call' < > 'name' > 'omen', 'fate'), but back *ā in Turkic is not quite clear (one should rather expect *ēt); perhaps we should reconstruct dialectal variants *p`ḗte / *p`ḗta.  See also notes to *pōto.
A Western isogloss.
Лексика 275. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
One of the few verbs losing *-lV in Jpn. (cf. \U *gèle\u , \U *si̯óle\u ), thus possibly a monosyllabic root (*p`ìl).

MEANING: a k. of nut or berry
REFERENCE: Martin 248, JLTT 397 (Kor.-Jpn.). {For Turk. cf. alternatively WMo düm 'дуб остролистный вечнозеленый'}
Цинциус 1984, 38-39, Poppe 1972, 99, АПиПЯЯ 12.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
PT *ɨra-k = PJ *pàrú-kà < PA *p`ìrá-k`V.
EAS 53, 150, Владимирцов 181-182, Poppe 12, 60, ОСНЯ 3, 119-124, Цинциус 1984, 39, Дыбо 14. Despite Poppe 1966, 197, 1972, 100, Doerfer MT 23, TM is hardly < Mong.
In Kor. cf. also psús-tōl 'whetstone', psɨ́- 'to rub', psùs- / psùč- 'to rub, to whet', psó- 'to sting; to shoot', pís 'comb'.
EAS 54, 82, SKE 231, Цинциус 1984, 40, Lee 1958, 110, АПиПЯЯ 296. A Tung.-Kor. isogloss. Since the TM forms meaning millet" go back to the same root
column17: the second of Ramstedt's etymologies (SKE 214
column18: comparison with Kor. \Iphi\i 'millet') should be rejected. In Kor. cf. also psắr '(fine) rice' (see Lee 1958

REFERENCE: АПиПЯЯ 13, 34, 283, Vovin 2000 (with a strange assertion that PT *jag- means `fall').

MEANING: spindle, part of loom or cross-bow
RUSMEAN: веретено, часть ткацкого станка или лука
REFERENCE: SKE 203. An interesting common Altaic cultural term.
The Kor. match is somewhat dubious (even if it is not a loan, its meaning was certainly influenced by the similar Chinese word), but Mong., TM and Japanese still form a plausible match.
KW 454, Владимирцов 196, Мудрак Дисс. 186. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss, but, despite TMN 2, 80-81, Щербак 1997, 95 hardly borrowed in Mong. < Turk.
АПиПЯЯ 108, 277.  Final vowel uncertain, due to contractions in Kor.-Jpn. originated by the loss of *-g-.

Martin 226, Menges 1984, 284, АПиПЯЯ 67, 288 (with a different Turk. parallel, see *eńa). Basically a Kor.-Jpn. isogloss (the Mong. form is poorly attested and has a somewhat obscure suffixation; besides, one would rather expect *huji- or *heji-). Jpn. > MKor. pòńắ, mod. posigi 'basin, bowl' (on the other hand, Kor. pắi may be the source of OJ pé 'bow, front of boat', see JLTT 403).
Lee 1958, 109 (Kor.-TM). Modern Jpn. hiyoko (JLTT 412) < Kor.
A TM-Kor. isogloss. One of the cases of prefixed *s- in body parts in Korean (cf. *s-pjə́ 'bone', *s-pɨ́r 'horn', *s-kòrí 'tail').
SKE 198, АПиПЯЯ 297.

EAS 53, 126, Poppe 11, 98, Цинциус 1984, 44-45, Rozycki 79. Despite Doerfer MT 23, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong. Kor. *pòròkí can be alternatively compared with PT *bele- 'to swaddle' (ЭСТЯ 2, 111-112).

SKE 202, Martin 228. Preservation of -i- in Kor. presents a problem, as well as very scarce representation in Mong. (only Kalm.). PA *p`- (not *p-) is reconstructed because of *(h) in Mong., together with high pitch in Jpn.
Дыбо 9.
Street 1985, 641, АПиПЯЯ 13.
A Western isogloss.

The comparison of PTM *piri with PT *jạ̄r (АПиПЯЯ 13) should be abandoned, since it does not explain PT closed *ạ (on the etymology of the Turkic word see rather *ǯḗro). For a possible Korean parallel see under *p`i̯ṓlo. Cf. \I*p`eri.\i
A Western isogloss.
An interesting common Altaic religious term.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Poppe 103. The Jpn. form may reflect a merger with another root > Mong. *bula- 'to dig, bury'.
SKE 199.
Владимирцов 187, Poppe 12, Цинциус 1984, 53. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.

PKE 22. Vowel length in Tung. is not clear (the root is attested only in some Evk. dialects, thus the phonology is not quite reliable here). Kor. has a usual vowel reduction between a stop and affricate.

АПиПЯЯ 283. Mong. ǯol 'luck', usually compared with PT *jōl (see VEWT 206 etc.), should be rather regarded as a loanword (because of the specific meaning), see TMN 4, 226-227, Щербак 1997, 124. The TM form is compared to Kor. pəl 'meadow, plain' (SKE 196), for which another etymology is given in АПиПЯЯ (see \U*p`āla\u). Note, however, that Kor. pjər- may be also derived from PA \U*p`i̯āre\u 'split, precipice' (q.v.).

In TM cf. also derived forms: Orok pīpu, Ul. pīpu, Ud. siɣi 'drill' (ТМС 2, 39) - possibly reflecting a contamination with \U *pi̯ubi\u  q.v. In Turkic one would rather expect *job-, so perhaps we should rather reconstruct *p`ṑjpo.
Дыбо 13. The etymology seems convincing, despite some vocalic problems (we would either expect *jāp- in Turkic or *pəp- ~ \I*pup-\i in Jpn.).
АПиПЯЯ 12. The Jpn. match is somewhat dubious semantically (possible if one assumes 'left' < 'West') and has an irregular low tone.
Irregular accent correspondence between Kor. and Jpn.  (besides, the Kor. vowel is aberrant: we would rather expect -u- or -o-, or a vowel reduction).
A Western isogloss.

Poppe 11 compares the Mong. form with TM \I*pule-\i which is less likely. Jpn. pà and MKor. pó reflect a contraction < *pi̯ugV-ga. An expressive root with not quite clear vocalic correspondences, rather difficult to distinguish from several similar: cf. \U\I*pok`e,\u\i  \U*p`ū̀ge,\u \U*p`ago\u.
The Mong. form is homonymous with *ugulǯa 'mountain deer' and may be unrelated (deer embroidery"?)."

EAS 55, KW 448, Цинциус 1984, 54, Rozycki 81. Despite Doerfer MT 23, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong. In Turkic cf. Bashk. jɨla `ash-tree' - although attested only in Bashkir, a perfect semantic and phonetic match for this root.

PKE 150, Martin 243, АПиПЯЯ 13, 36, 90, 277. In TM cf. perhaps Evn. hildenre- 'to dawn' (ТМС 2, 324). In Turkic one would rather expect *juĺ-, but the root is only used with the suffix *-du-ŕ, and in preconsonantal position *-ĺ- and *-l- were neutralized (Helimski's rule"). Note Turk. *jul-du- = Mong. *ho-du- ( < *hol-du-) ( = Evk. hil-de-)
column17: with the same affixation throughout the Western Altaic area."

REFERENCE: A Western isogloss, with not quite secure  correspondences: in TM one would rather expect \I*pun-.\i Thus it is not excluded that the Evk. and Evn. forms reflect a vowel metathesis < *puni-ki.
Delabialization in PT (*öŋir- would be expected) must be explained by the influence of *egir- q.v.
Because of the loss of initial *p`- in Turk. the root may interfere with \U *ṑr(e)ke\u  q.v.

In Kor. cf. also also pskə́-tì- 'to perish, disappear', pskắ- 'to strip off skin, peel', modern pasjə-ǯida 'crumble, go to pieces'; see SKE 192, 199, EAS 101-102; Цинциус 1984, 56. The isolated Daghur form could be a borrowing from Tungus (derivatives from this root can also mean 'scissors', 'razor', 'tweezers' - cf. Evk. husiwun, Evn. hụhoŋko, Orok pụsị̄qqụ etc.) - but the immediate source is unclear. On a possible Turkic reflex see under *isV.
EAS 54, 149, KW 301, Poppe 11, 65, ОСНЯ 2, 102, Цинциус 1984, 50. Cf. also an expressive OJ form: bjisi-bjisi 'sound of wiping one's nose'.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.

Дыбо 15, Мудрак Дисс. 198, Лексика 399. Mong. egeɣü is probably borrowed from Turkic. Closed *ẹ̄ in Turk. is not quite clear: it is either the result of narrowing in a polysyllabic stem, or a reflex of the lost *p`- (cf. the diphthongization in Chuv. jəgev).
OJ has irregular tone and vowel (one would rather expect -ə-), thus a loan from Korean cannot be excluded (although the Kor. and Jpn. meanings are rather distant).
In TM we must suppose *pebi- < *pobi- (with a frequent confusion of e and o after labials).
Cf. also Evk. heɣe- 'to sing and dance'.
Цинциус 1984, 46. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.

KW 304, Владимирцов 268, Poppe 11, 67, Цинциус 1984, 41-42. Borrowing in Mong. from Turk. is quite dubious, despite Щербак 1997, 161. The stem may be derived from *p`ojV 'to bind' - reflected in PM *huja- (HY 39 xuja-, WMong. uja-, Khalkha uja-, Mongor fujā-) id.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.
Kor. pathaŋ is probably < *păthaŋ through assimilation.
A common Altaic term, denoting probably some sort of trousers or stockings.
KW 294, Дыбо 13. A Western isogloss. Very scantily represented in Turkic and Mongolian, thus rather dubious.
ЭСТЯ 1, 520-521, Лексика 289. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. Cf. \U*p`uske.\u

Владимирцов 322, Poppe 12, 56, ОСНЯ 3, 126-128, Цинциус 1984, 46. Щербак 1997, 131, TMN 1, 539. A Western isogloss. Doerfer MT 67 (following Sinor 1962, Poppe 1966, 198, 1972, 99) would wish Mong. to be borrowed < Turk. and TM < Mong.; phonology, however, speaks plainly against it.

Дыбо 14. An expressive and not quite regular root: in Turkic and Korean we probably have to presuppose an assimilative variant *p`ók`u, whereas the TM form points rather to *p`óku. See also notes to *bū́gà.
Poppe 12, Цинциус 1984, 60. АПиПЯЯ 37, 289, Rozycki 81. A Western isogloss.
SKE 216, EAS 56.

RUSMEAN: передвигаться (с трудом: в воде, в траве)
REFERENCE: The common meaning may be postulated as 'to move with some difficulty, through some substance (water, grass, snow etc.)'.
A Western isogloss.

EAS 54, 147, KW 300, Martin 232, Menges 1984, 286-287, АПиПЯЯ 73, 93-94, 98, 275, Лексика 358. Mong. örde- may be < Turk.; but cf. also Khalkha ürevse- 'to flame up'. Jpn. *pə̀- presupposes a suffixed form *p`ŏ̀r(e)-gV.
KW 459, Poppe 111, Цинциус 1972a, 52-59, 1984a, 62-63, АПиПЯЯ 47-48, 286, Лексика 116, Doerfer MT 137. Jpn. *pú < *p`úr(i)-gV ( = Turk. *urug etc.)
The root is not very widely attested, but seems quite reliable.
SKE 206, Лексика 532, ТМС 2, 333.
Poppe 12, 51; Цинциус 1984, 56-57; UAJ 1995, 88 (Kor.-Jpn.).
SKE 265 (criticized with no reason at all in TMN 2, 10: unannehmbar")."
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss; cf. \U*p`učV\u (on a possible Mong. reflex see under \U*ōt`a\u).

Cf. perhaps \I-pók\i in MKor. pắi-s-pók 'navel' (*'belly cavity'?); TM *pokV-n (ТМС 1, 469) 'corner of the eye'. In Turkic cf. perhaps OUygh. boɣaj (boɣań?) 'low', borrowed in Mong. as WMong. boɣoni (see EDT 322).  This all seems rather uncertain; but for Mong. the reconstruction *hügün (based on the archaic Mongor form fugun) seems probable, and the Mong.-Jpn. parallel at least seems satisfactory.

EAS 56, SKE 215, Poppe 110, KW 295, VEWT 371, Цинциус 1984, 47-48. АПиПЯЯ 296. Cf. also Old Koguryo *pä(l)lŏk- 'green', see Miller 1979, 9. The etymology seems quite satisfactory, despite Doerfer's (TMN 2, 161-162) critical attempts (semantisch nicht ganz befriedigende Vergleich")."
Cf. also  WMong. orbaji- 'in die Höhe stehen, emporragen', MTurk. orpat-, örpet- id. (KW 290). Despite Doerfer MT 39, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong. Cf. \U*ṓŕi.\u
Vocalic reconstruction is not quite certain in a trisyllabic stem. TM *pebgure probably < *pobgure (due to frequent variation of *o and *e close to labials).
Poppe 12, Цинциус 1984, 52. Despite Doerfer MT 47, Rozycki 76-77, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong.; but to be related, it has to go back to an earlier form like *pubta-kān.
A Western isogloss.
SKE 211-212, Lee 1958, 111. An Eastern isogloss; may be actually a variant of \U*p`ṑči\u  - if the original meaning was 'to blow out (fire)'. Kor. low tone reflects the stem's original verbal nature.

MEANING: a k. of willow, blossoming bush
REFERENCE: Poppe 11, 51; Цинциус 1984, 51.
Cf. \U*pṓt`o.\u

EAS 55, KW 455, Poppe 52, 111 (Tung.-Mong.), Цинциус 1984, 58. Despite TMN 1, 537, Doerfer MT 80, TM forms (except Evk. ude-) cannot be borrowed from Mong. {Dolg. ND 117 compares Turkic with Mong. *uda- 'be late, delay' which is less plausible.}
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.

VEWT 508, Мудрак Дисс. 147. A Western isogloss. MMong. hula, (IM) holā, WMong. ula, Mongor fula may be a different root, corresponding directly to TM *pula (ТМС 2, 343) id. (see EAS 55, Poppe 12, Цинциус 1984, 53, Doerfer MT 132) - however, in TM *pug(u)la is also reconstructable, and MMong. hula may well be a variant of *huhula.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
Poppe 67, Цинциус 1984, 59. A Western isogloss.

Poppe 12, Lee 1958, 110, Цинциус 1984, 59. The root is somewhat dubious: the older meaning attested in Kor. is 'to bind, tie up', and the root may actually reflect PA \U*p`émi\u 'twist a thread' (q.v.); the same is true of the TM forms that may in fact (especially because for Jurch. the meaning 'bind' is attested) go back to the same PTM root *pem-.
An expressive root; correspondences, however, seem to be regular.
EAS 55, Владимирцов 187, Poppe 12, 111, Цинциус 1984, 60, Rozycki 82. A Western isogloss. Despite Doerfer MT 23, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong.

EAS 55, KW 457, SKE 209, Lee 1958, 110, Poppe 12, 112, Цинциус 1984, 57, Martin 226. Not borrowed in TM < Mong., despite Rozycki 81. In Turk. the root has probably merged with \U*uĺV\u 'to freeze' q.v. (cf. the meaning 'to blow (of a cold wind)' in Chuv.).

SKE 1949, 209, Lee 1958, 109, Цинциус 1984, 61, АПиПЯЯ 291. The Mong. form can belong here only if the attested HY form o[li]mi is aberrant, reflecting the stage of language (or dialect) with h- already lost. Otherwise Mong. reflexes are to be separated from this root. On possible Turkic reflexes see under *ula.

SKE 210, 215-216. Cf. also MKor. părk- 'to get away or free from'; Bur. ülxe- 'to bead, string' ( > Evk. ulge- etc.). Despite Poppe 1972, 99, the TM forms cannot be borrowed < Mong. ülte- (see s.v. *uĺi).

EAS 55, Цинциус 1984, 53, Lee 1958, 110, АПиПЯЯ 75, Martin 228. Mong. *hurul regularly < *hulu-r. As for the Jpn. form, it may be a reduplication (as thought traditionally; in this case *pə- < *p`ùl(o)-gV), or reflect an already suffixed form, cf. e. g. Nan. polpị ( < *p`ùlo-pV).
A Turk.-Kor. isogloss; dubious because the Kor. word is very sparsely attested.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss; within TM attested only in Evk., thus somewhat dubious.

ОСНЯ 3, 83-84, Цинциус 1984, 61-62, АПиПЯЯ 29-30, 112, 275, KW 460 (Mong. ~ TM); an alternative etymology of Poppe (Poppe 70: linking the TM form with Mong.  ünegen 'fox' and Yak. ünügäs 'puppy') is obviously untenable. Cf. also Mong. *hö-dün 'feather' ( < *hön-dün  ?). {For *hödün cf. rather TM forms: Ma. fulǵači, fulsuri, Ewn. huloŋ, hultukta, ТМС 2, 343, 344, 346.}
An isolated Mong. stem: perhaps an old derivative of *p`uńe 'feather'?
Mergers with \U*pāt`e\u were possible (esp. in Jpn., where otherwise -a- would be expected). Reasons of the loss of -n- in Mong. are not clear. Cf. PAN *-petpet 'firefly'.
A Western isogloss. ? Cf. Jpn. pono-mek- 'to show vaguely, guess' etc. (if not the same as pono-ka).
In Turk. *üŋ would be expected; the vocalism was probably influenced by the homonymous \I*oŋ\i / *öŋ 'colour, exterior'. Kor. has a usual verbal low tone.
Mong. also has a back variant *(h)uri-, reflected in *(h)uri-ldu- 'to contest, fight' (WMong. urildu-, uraldu-, Khalkha uralda-) = PT *uru-ĺč- id.
EAS 54, 56, 149, Poppe 12, 111, SKE 210, ОСНЯ 2, 101, Цинциус 1984, 63-64. Despite Rozycki 83, TM cannot be borrowed < Mong.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.

EAS 53, 125, Poppe 101, Цинциус 1984, 55. A Western isogloss. Despite TMN 2, 87, Щербак 1997, 162, Mong. cannot be borrowed < Turkic; again, despite Doerfer MT 18, TM cannot be < Mong. (all because of archaic *p- preservation both in Mong. and TM). Quite enigmatic is the relationship of this root to synonymous \U*uk`urkV\u q.v.
An interesting common Altaic abstract term (although voicing in Jpn. is not quite clear).
Poppe 11, 65, 90, Цинциус 1984, 50-51; TM cannot be borrowed < Mong., despite Rozycki 76. Cf. \U*p`ŏk`i.\u
EAS 55, Martin 229. An  expressive  root (cf. also \U \I*pok`e,\u\i  \U *p`i̯ùgV,\u  \U *p`ago\u ).
One of the common Altaic Verba des Schlagens". Korean has a usual low verbal tone."
The root means 'to wipe off' in the Eastern area, but rather 'to rub off, crush' in Turkic and Mongolian.
EAS 55, 149. A Western isogloss.
The original root structure is not quite clear: perhaps one has to suppose a monosyllabic root *p`ō-, with suffixed *-ba(n) or *-n.

VEWT 511 (with a dubious Mong. parallel), АПиПЯЯ 286. A Western isogloss. The TM vocalism is not quite clear (we would expect a diphthong *ia). Kor. pogɨm(čari) 'nest', compared with TM in SKE 204, cannot be related for phonetic reasons.

SKE 199 (Turk.-Tung.-Kor.), Цинциус 1984, 37-38, АПиПЯЯ 284, Дыбо 11, Лексика 104. A rather complicated case, because of contractions and compounds. For the second part of the PT compound cf. perhaps  Mong. gesi-ɣü(n) 'branch'.  The old compound *p`i̯ūju-*gVša, beside Turk. *ɨgač, may be reflected in OJ pàjàsi 'forest', ТМ *pā(j)k[š]a 'wood' (ТМС 2, 311)).
Martin 251, АПиПЯЯ 91, 278. Due to contractions of the sequence *-VjV-, the vowels are somewhat difficult to reconstruct.
KW 460, Poppe 112, Poppe 1950, Lee 1958, 109, Ozawa 140-141, Цинциус 1984, 66.

Лексика 335. The match is acceptable (as one of the Common Altaic monosyllabic verbal roots) if -rə in Jpn. is a historical suffix. Cf. perhaps also TM *sali- 'esteem; price' - which may reflect a merger of this root with \U*sáĺo\u 'love' q.v.
Лексика 179.
Mong. and TM reflect the common derivative *sago-dV.

Note an identical derivative in Mong. and Jpn.: Mong. *saɣadag 'quiver' (WMong. saɣadaɣ, Khalkha sādag, L 656, KW 316-317, MGCD 584; Mong. > Chag. saɣdaq, Oyr. sadaq etc., see TMN 1, 337, Щербак 1997, 209, Лексика 567, ЭСТЯ 7) = PJ *sàjá 'sheath' (OJ sàjá, JLTT 520).
The root is poorly attested in TM, but the Turkic and Japanese words appear to form a good match.
An expressive root; in Jpn. we must assume a vowel assimilation (*-ə- would be expected).
An Eastern isogloss. Dag. sajarin 'dawn' is probably < Tung.

EAS 85, KW 317, Владимирцов 194. Poppe 29, 59 (Turk.-Mong.), АПиПЯЯ 15. Mong. is hardly borrowed from Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 144. *-jg- is probable because of the TM reflex and loss of *-g- in Jpn.; Korean high tone (rather untypical for a verb) is also possibly due to contraction (see also *sắjV 'shallow place' - a possible source of contamination).
A Western isogloss.

Дыбо 1993. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. Not quite reliable because of poor attestation in TM. Note, however, that PM *sigaji 'knucklebone' would be a good match - if it were not derived (or secondarily contaminated?) from *siɣa, see under PA *siŋu.
EAS 153. The Jpn. word may be related if one assumes an original meaning 'interval (in general)'. Mong. *söɣem < *seɣöm (with a frequent labialization transfer).

KW 314, SKE 225, PKE 173, Дыбо 12, АПиПЯЯ 297. The unexpected -b- in Mong. may be due to a mixture with *serbe- 'bristle, stand on end', see under *sirp`a. Medial *-j- is to be reconstructed to account for the loss of *-r- in Kor.
KW 313, VEWT 402, ТМС 2,64 (Evk. sar < Mong.), KW 313.   Cf. also Jurch. siel ( < *siar-) 'hawk'.
KW 320, Владимирцов 284, Poppe 29, 67, TMN 3, 236 (möglich"). In Korean the original root may have interacted with *sắi- 'leak
column17: ooze' < *săjgo (q.v.)."

REFERENCE: KW 354, Дыбо 8, Лексика 175. An onomatopoeic reduplicated root. Cf. other similar bird names: MKor. kāčhí id. (Martin 236), koskori 'oriole'; OJ sazaki (mod. miso-sazai) японский крапивник"; Karakh. čekik 'lark'
column17: TM *čukčeŋē 'кулик'. Ozawa (99-101) compares Mong. (Altan Tobči) čaɣčaɣai
column18: Khalkha cagcxaj 'a k. of small bird' ('чекан

REFERENCE: The meaning in Japanese ('edge') must be a generalization of the more concrete earlier 'end (of a stick, pole)'.
A rather dubious Tung.-Kor. isogloss; perhaps a variant of the root \U*sak`V\u 'to ferment' q.v.

An Eastern isogloss; cf. perhaps also Oyr. sagalak 'рыбка-урюп', Mong. (L 657) saɣamqa 'salt water fish, perch(?)'. Like in many fish names, details are not clear: note that the TM forms may be actually borrowed from Jpn. sakana `fish' (originally `wine-side dish'). Cf. also *suku.
Lee 1958, 116 (Kor.-TM). Korean has a verbal low tone.

A not quite secure Tung.-Jpn. isogloss. Since words for 'hunt' often go back to names of hunted animals, one can think of comparing PT *sajkak ( ~ *sajgak) 'antelope' (attested since Chag., see VEWT 395, ЭСТЯ 7), with the resulting correction of the PA reconstruction to *sajk`a. Cf. also *sĭ́gò and *sū́ku.
An Eastern isogloss.
Лексика 183.

EAS 91, KW 308, SKE 220 (Doerfer's skepticism in TMN 3, 255 is hardly justified). The variation of *-g- and *-k- in Turkic and Mongolian is suspicious (cf. also the Nanai form pointing rather to *-k-), perhaps indicating that we are dealing with a merger of two different roots - cf. also the variety of reflexes in Korean; cf. also \U*sak`o\u and \U*zi̯úko\u.
KW 309, Martin 245, Martin 1996, 76, Street 1985, 640.
KW 323, SKE 227, EAS 72, Street 1980, 296. Cf. also Mong. salaŋ 'negligent, careless' ( > Kirgh. salaq etc., see ЭСТЯ 7, VEWT 397).
SKE 234.
A Western isogloss.
An Eastern isogloss; but cf. perhaps also Turk.: Chuv. šъldъr 'beautiful' (Ашм. XVII 289), Yak. ɨllar- 'сильно увлекаться'. Cf. also notes to \I*sa.\i
Kor. has a usual vowel reduction between a fricative and a stop.

Phonetically a good match, but otherwise not quite reliable: if the Turkic parallel is to be removed as a late loanword, the semantic match between 'fumigation' in TM and 'charcoal' in Japanese becomes less convincing.
Ozawa 117-118, JOAL 68. The parallel seems interesting, but front vocalism in Mong. demands some special explanation.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss; valid if TM *saŋa- < *sań-ga-.
KW 313, Лексика 151, ЭСТЯ 7. A Western isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. Note also Tar. saŋgila- 'herabhängen (von den Ohren)' (KW 312, VEWT 400) - hardly a loanword from Mong, but phonetically strange (why -g-?).
An Eastern isogloss; Mong. *sinu- 'to covet' would fit semantically, but phonetically rather continues PA *si̯ā́ńi q.v.; cf. also *sĭ̀ni.
АПиПЯЯ 112, 274.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A common derivative *sápa-kV is reflected in Turkic, TM and Korean.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss; may be just a specialization of *sĕpo q.v.
Дыбо 15 compares Tung. with Turk. *sep- 'to equip, fit out; dowry', but this is phonetically less plausible because of voiceless *-p- in Turkic; see on this root under *si̯ap`u.

PKE 177, Martin 227 (Kor.-Jpn.). The accent variants in Jpn. are due to a confusion of PA *sáp`i 'stick' and \U *sī̀pe\u  'swamp vegetation' q. v.  As opposed to *sèp`u 'long twig, rod' (q. v.) this root must have denoted twigs and branches used as firewood and also suitable for making fences (cf. Mong. sibeɣe 'fence' and OJ siba-gakji 'twig fence').

An expressive root, but nevertheless with satisfactory correspondences. Korean has a usual vowel reduction in two of the root's derivatives. Mong. *sabir- may be a result of partial contamination with *sĕpo 'throw, scatter' q.v.
A good common Altaic root, although not very widely represented.
Ozawa 96-99. A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss. ?Cf. perhaps Turk. *sarsal 'weasel' (EDT 854 etc.)
KW 422, Лексика 187. An onomatopoeic insect name, with usual in such a case assimilations.
SKE 224. The vowel in Kor. is aberrant (one would expect *ă); otherwise quite regular.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. In Kor. and Jpn. the reflex of this root may have merged with \U*sílgu\u q.v. (cf. PKE 175).

A Western isogloss. Note some of the Turkic derivatives (Kum. sarqɨm 'thin flow', Tat. dial. sarqɨm 'thick whey left after pressing curds' etc., see ЭСТЯ 7) which may speak in favour of the original meaning 'to ooze, be filtered'. In this case the root may actually be derived from *sā̀rV 'to be rare, thinned out' (q.v.) (assuming that length in TM was secondarily shortened); cf. especially the common Western derivative *sār-k`V 'maw used for filtering / fermenting'.
Cf. *s[é]rko, with a possibility of contaminations.
A common derivative *sáŕo-kV is reflected in OT sozaq, PM *sirö-ge and Orok sarụqa.
Some evidence from Mong. (Bur. harig) seems to indicate that the  root may be just *sara, with the old derivative *sar(a)-p`V reflected in most languages.
Martin 242, АПиПЯЯ 73, Doerfer MT 82. The root must have denoted a k. of stick used in agriculture, most probably digging stick or hoe, with a later transition to plough"
column17: and in TM
column18: exotically
column22: whereas the original root is preserved as *sorbi 'stick
column23: staff' (although the -o-vowel here is a bit strange - *sarb- would be expected; perhaps we are actually dealing with a suffixed form like *sorbuji

REFERENCE: A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
ЭСТЯ 7.
KW 332, Rozycki 186.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
Martin 248, АПиПЯЯ 296. In Kor. earth" < "bottom" (cf. the meaning in Jpn.); *stá- reflects a usual reduction < *sV̀tá-(gV)."
An expressive and rather insecure root: the Turkic form are late attested and irregular.
Mong. is usually regarded as < Turk. *seŕik, see *sā́ŕi (see VEWT 413, Clark 1980, 40; cf. also WMong. sesig id.).
Japanese has an irregular low tone.
АПиПЯЯ 76 (with a wrong inclusion of Jpn. *sátə́-, see *sṓra)
KW 321. A Western isogloss.

The comparison seems probable, despite tonal incongruence between TM and Jpn. Ramstedt (SKE 222) compares  Manchu  forms  with Kor. sam 'a speck or mote in the eye'  (that may rather belong to \U*sḗmi\u q.v.).
One of common Altaic verbs of emotion. The original meaning was probably something like 'languish', which would explain all the individual semantic developments.
Лексика 179, Miller 2000, 61-62. A Western isogloss. Cf. also Kor. salgi 'Amur grayling', perhaps borrowed from TM.

EAS 71, KW 325, Poppe 29, 82 (Turc-Mong.), Murayama 1962, 111, 1978, 277-278, Miller 1981, 852, ОСНЯ 2, 107-108, Ozawa 228-229, АПиПЯЯ 74, 91, 276, Дыбо 14, Martin 234. TM preserves length in a monosyllabic root after loss of the resonant. Mong. cannot be explained as a loanword, despite Щербак 1997, 144.
Miller 1985, 151. A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
Cf. *săp`í, *sapV (with a possibility of partial mergers).
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. Cf. perhaps mod. Turkic forms like Turk. suǯuq 'entrail' etc. - perhaps < PT *sab-čuk.
Лексика 266.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss, with a typical loss of *-d- before *-r- in TM.
Cf. \U*sík`e.\u
Лексика 235. A Western isogloss. Turk. *sügsün < *segsün through vowel assimilation.

MEANING: a k. of small fur animal
REFERENCE: A Western isogloss. Mong. *sowsar < *saɣu-sar, with labial attraction.

SKE 225, PKE 171. Medial *-j- is reconstructed to account for loss of *-r- in Kor. Cf. perhaps also Man. sertej  'three-lipped, having a harelip'; MKor. sə̀hɨ̀rə̀i, mod. s:əre 'rake, harrow' ( = Mong. *sereɣe).
Владимирцов 282, Мудрак Дисс. 101, ЭСТЯ 7, TMN 3, 308-309. Despite Щербак 1997, 144 not borrowed in Mong. < Turk.
KW 318. Mong. is hardly borrowed from Turk., despite TMN 3, 218-219, Щербак 1997, 144. Korean has a usual verbal" low tone. Cf. \U*si̯ā́k`a.\u {For Jap. *sùk- cf. alternatively PT *suk 'greed
column17: envy
column18: greedy'.}"

REFERENCE: A common Altaic derivative *sela-mV is reflected in PTM *selu-mi-, PT *sal-ma and possibly (with denasalization) in Mong. *sil-bi-.
A Chinese origin of Kor. súr, suggested in Martin 1996, 92, is quite improbable.

SKE 59 (without the Turk. parallel), Whitman 1985, 168, 235, АПиПЯЯ 286. Mongolian parallels (both in SKE 59 and in KW 309, VEWT 397) are highly dubious. For the Auslaut relations cf. \U*gèle\u: one of the possible PA monosyllabic verbal roots (*si̯ól).

EAS 71, KW 323, Poppe 29, Дыбо 14. It is interesting to note OJ same-nuri 'a way of applying varnish' (if same- here is not = sama- 'to fade'). Despite Poppe 1974, 120, *-ǯi in Mong. is a quite common suffix (see Poppe 1973, 234) and the Mong. form can hardly be regarded as borrowed < Turkic (Clark 1980, 39 says that the case defies explanation" (as a borrowing); likewise
column17: the TM forms are difficult to explain as borrowed < Mong."

REFERENCE: See also notes under \U*sāmo.\u
In Mong. cf. siɣaqai 'slippers' (if not < siɣa 'knuckle bone').
Лексика 222. A Western isogloss.
KW 328. MKo also has sjə̄'ə́r 'bastard' which may be related to the same root. The Jpn. form presupposes a suffixed *sejŋ(i)-gV ( = TM *seŋgi).
Basically a Turk.-Jpn. isogloss; Mongolian may be < Turkic.
A Western isogloss.
Lee 1958, 116 (Kor.-TM), Лексика 520. The Kor.-Jpn. tones are irregular, perhaps because of some interaction between this root and {\U*si̯ṓjru}\u, \U*ši̯ṑri\u q.v.

MEANING: a k. of box or bag
REFERENCE: Tone correspondences are not quite clear; the Kor. word is alternatively compared (see Lee 1958, 117) with Manchu šulχu 'basket'. Cf. \U*sóra.\u
A Western isogloss.
A suffixed form *sése-k`V is reflected in PT *ses-ke-n- and PK *sìs-kú-.

EAS 102, АПиПЯЯ 79. For the Turk. semantics cf. OJ wi-no-sisi 'pig, swine'. The Turkic reflex, however, is not quite secure: there is only an isolated Chuvash word and the vowel reflex seems aberrant; also unclear is the phonology of the Hung. ( < Bulg.) loanword disznó (presupposing *ǯisnaɣ, see MNyTESz 1, 646-647).
A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss.

EAS 71, Doerfer MT 240, Дыбо 14. Despite Doerfer's (TMN 3, 316) doubts, the root is common Altaic. The Jpn. vowel is quite irregular: perhaps in Jpn. and Kor. we should presuppose a suffixed form *sebV-p- ( > Kor. sipɨ-, PJ *sua-p-, with further suffixation *sua-p-ap-). Cf. also WMong. (L 653) sabla-ldu- 'to show favour, be gracious'.

EAS 85, KW 319, Владимирцов 266-267, Poppe 29 (Turk.-Mong.; Doerfer TMN 1, 372 refutes the match for absolutely unclear reasons), АПиПЯЯ 289, Мудрак Дисс. 182. The semantic correlation 'blood': 'health, healthy' is rather usual, thus the TM form belongs here with great probability. Kor. has a usual verbal low tone.
Exceptional preservation of length in a monosyllabic stem in TM.
High tone in Jpn. is irregular.
SKE 222-223. An Eastern isogloss; on Jpn. tone see note above.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
EAS 72, АПиПЯЯ 52, 284.

KW 360, АПиПЯЯ 73, 83, 87, 276 (confused with the reflexes of *si̯uru q.v.), Лексика 182, Whitman 1985, 168.  In Turkic a secondary narrowing (*sirke < *serke or *si̯arke) occurred. Mong. may be < Turkic. In Kor. we have to suppose  *si̯àjri > *hjə̀ (with tone modified because of contraction).
Despite Doerfer MT 69 hardly a loan in TM from Mong.
A Western isogloss.
Because of assimilations the original initial consonant is not quite clear.
The Turk. form must go back to *sidüre- ( = Mong. sidur-). In TM cf. perhaps Man. sidara- 'to stretch, straighten', siǯi(r)χun 'straight' (ТМС 2, 79),  if not < Mong., as suggested by Rozycki 181).
SKE 239. Note Khak. sɨzɨm = PM *siǯim, but hardly a loan from Mongolian, and pointing to a common derivative *sido-mV.
KW 367, Лексика 380-381, Doerfer MT 50-51, Rozycki 180 (but hardly borrowed in TM < Mong.). A Western isogloss.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.
The root is very sparsely attested in Turkic, but the attestations are archaic and the root seems generally reliable.
Cf. *soge.
ТМС 2, 78, Martin 236, Martin 1996, 27. Kor. *čhắč- is an assimilation < *sVhắč- = PJ *sá(n)kas-.
KW 367, Poppe 30, 58, АПиПЯЯ 79, Rozycki 197. The TM form is classified as a borrowing from Mong. by Doerfer MT 47, which cannot be excluded.
VEWT 418. Cf. \U*si̯ók`u.\u Mong. has also sige-, siged- 'to get stuck, become inserted' - which is compared in KW 356 with PT *sik- 'coire'.
Ozawa 220-221. Kor. has a usual vowel reduction between a fricative and a stop.

MEANING: a plant with specific smell or taste
RUSMEAN: растение с характерным запахом или вкусом
REFERENCE: Cf. Kor. siktä 'Pleioblastus Simoni'. The root also means umbrella" in Mong.
column17: and as such may be actually identical to *sík`e `detail of the house' (perhaps as an old name of some umbellate plant?)."

MEANING: a detail of the house entrance
REFERENCE: Cf. \U*ségi.\u
EAS 154, KW 344, Владимирцов 324, Poppe 30, 55. Mong. is hardly a borrowing, despite Щербак 1997, 147. The Jpn. form is a partial contamination with \U*sĭ́lgu\u q. v.
Vovin 2000 (comparing *sùkuà- and *hòk; but his attempt to separate PJ *sùkù-na-  and *sùkuà-  is hardly successful). An Eastern isogloss.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.

АПиПЯЯ 276. Martin (1966, 237) compares the Jpn. form with Kor. sái 'new', but this word has probably a different origin (see *zèjńa).  The Turkic form is very poorly attested (only in MK's phrase) and somewhat dubious.

EAS 71, 122, KW 357, SKE 233, 235, Poppe 30, 76. Mong. is hardly borrowed from Turkic, despite Щербак 1997, 144; Tung. is hardly borrowed from Mong., despite Doerfer MT 46. The meaning in Kor. and Jpn. may reflect the influence of another root, PA \U*saŕi\u q.v.; in Jpn. there is an additional contamination with \U*sĭ́k`u\u 'press' q.v.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
SKE 230, EAS 71-72, VEWT 435. Cf. also Old Koguryo *salgan 'frost' (Miller 1979, 8).
It is hard to determine the original meaning of the root - some kind of middle-sized bird, probably with a big beak.
Mong. *süj probably (with a rather usual vowel interaction) < *sĳü.
EAS 120, Дыбо 313-314, Лексика 287. A Western isogloss, but cf. \U*siŋu\u: the form may be an archaic derivative.
EAS 120, Мудрак Дисс. 43, Лексика 264.
KW 440, АПиПЯЯ 285, Дыбо 314-315, Мудрак Дисс. 42. Cf. \U*siŋri.\u

KW 352, Poppe 30, 46. Correspondences are quite regular, and there is hardly any need in assuming (despite Poppe 1966, 198, Doerfer MT 123) Tung. < Mong. However, Mong. may be borrowed from Turkic (see Щербак 1997, 148-150), in which case a reconstruction *síba is also possible.

For the usage of the root to denote bitter plants cf. also OJ sibu-kusa 'sorrel'; perhaps also MKor. psúk 'Artemisia' (which is tempting to identify with Mong. sibag). In Kor. we have a secondary metathesis < *spɨ-, like psɨ́r- < *spɨr- < *šĭp`V 'sweep' q.v.
Poppe 46. An expressive root, cf. \U*si̯ū̀bi.\u
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss; a Turkic parallel could be found in Russ. \Iсапсан\i 'peregrin' (considered to be Turkic [Шипова 278], but the source is actually unknown). Cf. \U *č`ĭ̀p`[u].  \u
A good Mong.-Tung.-Jpn. verbal match.
The Jpn. form may be actually a combined reflex of PA *sĭ̀bi, *suba and *ši̯ū̀po, all distinguished only in the Western Altaic branch.
Tekin 1969, 70. A Western isogloss.

MEANING: a measure of length or width
REFERENCE: ЭСТЯ 7.

KW 360, Мудрак Дисс. 45, Лексика 268. A Western isogloss. Mong. sirke-, serte- may belong here if they go back to *sirp-ke-, *serp-te- (cf. the TM and Turkic forms). See also notes to \U *sajri\u  'stick out, protrude'.
Мудрак Дисс. 44-45. A Western isogloss; cf. \U *si̯ŭ̀ŕi, *si̯òri.\u
In MKor. cf. also sìtɨ́r- 'to be emaciated, wither'.

KW 351, SKE 217. The etymology seems plausible, despite Doerfer's (TMN 3, 318) doubts (Zusammenhang der kor. Form mit der tü.-mo. scheint zweifelhaft") - although the Korean vocalism is in fact not quite clear."
A rather striking Mong.-Jpn. isogloss. Cf. perhaps also Evk. čitarān- 'натянуть, затянуть (ремнем, поясом)' (ТМС 2, 400); Sol. š́īttũ 'летняя обшивка юрты из прутьев' (ТМС 2, 426).

АПиПЯЯ 277. Initial *š- must be reconstructed because of Kor. *s-. Kor. sà'òrí appears to be genuine (cf. the match with Jpn. *súwá-r-), but a loan from Mong. saɣuri(n) 'seat' (whence certainly Manchu sōrin) cannot be excluded, see Lee 1964, 192-193.

The TM form is somewhat irregular: we would rather expect *šiči. Note, however that in Manchu we may be dealing with assimilation (čeče < *šeče), while other TM forms may in fact be borrowed from Manchu.
VEWT 429, Дыбо 11. A Western isogloss. Length is reconstructed to account for *-ia- (after a fricative) in TM.
Korean has a rather frequent loss of vowel between a fricative and a stop (*skór < *sVkor).
Martin 230 (Kor.-Jpn.). Kor. s- (not h-) before *-i̯a- requires reconstructing PA *z-. In TM one would rather expect *suxa-.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss. The root is poorly attested and rather dubious.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Correspondences are quite regular, and the root seems reliable.

KW 365, Poppe 30, 60, 114, VEWT 406 (without the Korean parallel), AKE 8, EAS 155, Miller 1985b, 205, АПиПЯЯ 291,  Дыбо 11, Мудрак Дисс. 195, Лексика 93. Despite Poppe 1972, 100, Doerfer MT 65, the TM form is hardly borrowed from Mong. The Turk.-Mong. match is characterized by Doerfer (TMN 3, 222), in his usual style, as lautlich und semantisch unsicher". In Kor. cf. perhaps also MKor. hɨ̀rì- 'dirty' ( < *hằri with vowel assimilation?)."
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.

KW 349, Владимирцов 146, 318, Lee 1958, 117, АПиПЯЯ 26, 73, 86, 278, Мудрак Дисс. 195. Mong. is not borrowed from Turkic, despite Щербак 1997, 144 (Doerfer TMN 3, 221 says: aus lautlichen Gründen unwahrscheinlich" (?)); the meaning 'yellow'
column17: however
column18: may be secondarily induced by the Turkic forms - since the original meaning of the root
column20: was most certainly 'white'.  Medial *-j- is reconstructed to account for the loss of *-r- in Kor. Cf. also Old Koguryo *šilap 'white' (see Miller 1979

REFERENCE: Cf. also Evk. sirahun 'whey' (possibly reflecting an unattested Mong. *sira-sun). MMong. širxe 'vinegar' (HY) is most probably borrowed < Turk., see Щербак 1997, 145. The vowel in Turkic is not quite clear (*sürke or *sörke would be expected); cf. also Karakh. (MK) sorquč (perhaps sarqɨč or sɨrquč - vocalization is uncertain) 'a k. of spicy plant (chicory?)', see EDT 848.
Мудрак Дисс. 195. Cf. \U*sèk`u.\u The variant with *-g- in Mong. is obviously assimilative.

MEANING: to be distressed, think with sadness
REFERENCE: Cf. *sĭ̀ni and *saŋe: the roots are sometimes different to distinguish.
An expressive root, but probably of common Altaic origin.

A Western isogloss. The Mong. root noun *seb makes the inner Turkic derivation < *sep- 'to scatter' (see e.g. ЭСТЯ 7) rather improbable. The TM form presupposes a semantic development 'skin defect' > 'wrinkled skin' > 'fish skin'; cf. for it, however,  alternatively WMong. sabkin 'dressed leather'.

KW 319, Дыбо 306, TMN 3, 225 (doubting the common origin of the Turk. and Mong. forms).  Kor. həri  was originally attributed (see PKE 54, Martin 245, АПиПЯЯ 76, 289) to PA \U*k`éĺe\u; it seems, however, that the root is just *hə-, and it is  better to derive it from *si̯óga, both for this reason and because of an apparent lack of development *k`- > h- in Korean.
Cf. also PT *sagɨr 'kettle' (VEWT 393).
A good common Altaic anatomical term.
Delabialization in Turkic is not quite clear (*sug would be expected).

Lee 1958, 118, АПиПЯЯ 49, 81, 292. An Eastern isogloss. It is also interesting (cf. Whitman 1985, 148-150) to note MKor. hànắr 'sky', which may, together with PJ *suàrá id., go back to a complex form *si̯og[u]n-lV.
The match seems plausible, despite somewhat scanty attestation.
Cf. \U*sĭ́gu\u, with a possibility of mergers.

MEANING: a k. of small fur animal
REFERENCE: Лексика 165. The Kor. form is somewhat unclear morphologically;  the -ɨ- vowel may be a distortion of the expected *-ă- or *-u- in a long form. Cf. \U*sólukV\u.
A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*ši̯ằĺi\u (with possible contaminations). {Cf. WMo šalǯa 'overcooked meat', Ewk. silamačin 'мясо с верхней части ног медведя}.
ТМС 2, 70 (TM-Mong.). In Korean one must suppose a semantic development 'to be quick, smart' > 'to charm, seduce'.
PKE 176, KW 337. {Unclear is Manch. samara 'big wooden bowl'.}
SKE 244-245. Initial *z- is reconstructed because of Kor. *s- (not h-).
The match with Japanese is both phonetically and semantically precise, so the root seems quite reliable (despite sparse attestation in TM).
Räsänen 1955. A Western isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
KW 328, Владимирцов 250-251, Poppe 73, EAS 119. A Western isogloss: on a possible Kor. match see under \U*si̯oga\u.
KW 341; Doerfer MT 61-62 (Mong.-Tung.: schwierige Verhältnisse"). A Western isogloss. Phonetically a good match would be Kor. həpha 'lung'
column17: but the meaning raises some doubts."

REFERENCE: The original meaning is well reconstructable as 'to follow by sideway', possibly an element of hunting terminology.
A Western isogloss.
Мудрак Дисс. 67. A Western isogloss.

The Kor. reflex is irregular (we should expect *h-), perhaps due to the influence of the second -s-. It is alternatively possible to reconstruct *sisu with an irregular labialized reflex in PT (instead of *sɨs-), on analogy with \I*sub\i < *sɨb 'water'. One should also keep in mind that Middle Korean has actually two forms (sìs- 'wash' and sɨ́s- 'cleanse, wipe off') that have merged in modern \Is:it-,\i so we may in fact be dealing  with a confusion of two original roots.
Cf. *sắp`í , *sèp`ù (with possible contaminations in Mongolian).
Jpn. *sìmà-r- may reflect both *si̯ṑmi-lV (Mong. *sima-la-) and *si̯ṑmi-rV (Mong. *sima-ra-).
A suffixed form *si̯ṓp`ì-nV is reflected  in  PT *siāpan and PJ *sípína.
Medial *-jr- is reconstructed because of the Korean reflex. Some confusion was possible between this root and the synonymous *ši̯ṑri q.v.
A Western isogloss.

EAS 96, 144, SKE 36-37. Mong. is hardly < Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 145. Mong. and Kor. have an assimilation (*s- > *č-), usual for this type of roots. In Jpn. cf. perhaps OJ susu-pana, MJ sùsú-bànà 'snivel from the nose' (cf. mod. hana-kuso, lit. 'nose faeces').

Cf. also MKor. sòiròkí 'a k. of bird'. The Kor. word (with an unsuccessful etymology in SKE 218) was compared with Turk. *sar in АПиПЯЯ 295; but the latter should be rather compared with Kor. súrí, see *sàru.
Cf. *sák`a and *sĭ́gò.
Лексика 185. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
SKE 240.
Мудрак Дисс. 42-43, Лексика 186. An insect name, with tabooistic irregular vocalic changes.
Basically a Turk.-Mong. isogloss; the Kor. form is late attested and somewhat insecure. Cf. perhaps also Manchu suŋǵen 'clever, smart' ( < *'perceiving'?).
Originally probably a shamanistic term ('soul', 'shape').
KW 333, SKE 234, АПиПЯЯ 81. The vowel in Turkic is unclear. Cf. also Old Koguryo *ṣäñäli 'zephyr' (see Miller 1979, 7). The Kor. and Jpn. form reflect a derived form *si̯ùŋ(e)ĺV.
An element of common Altaic hunting or warrior terminology.

MEANING: a k. of knife or lance
REFERENCE: Possibly connected etymologically with *si̯úŋe 'fight'.
The meaning 'shallow place' explains the semantic developments ( > 'island', 'sand'; 'tussock in a swamp').
KW 338, Lee 1958, 119. Despite Doerfer's criticism in TMN 3, 296 the comparison seems reliable.

The etymology seems plausible, despite some phonetic problems, both explainable as metatheses in an expressive plant name: Mong. surgar instead of an expected *sargur, and TM *seŋkürē instead of an expected *serkü-(ŋē?).  Cf. *sáro, with a possibility of contaminations.
In Turkic cf. perhaps *sürmeč 'women's plait' (VEWT 438), Chuv. sərme kobъz 'violin' ('string instrument'). See SKE 63.
Мудрак Дисс. 45-46. A Western isogloss.
The root is very sparsely attested and thus not quite reliable.
Korean has a frequent loss of vowel between a fricative and a stop. The medial consonant is not quite clear: perhaps Turk. *süglen < *süklen with a secondary voicing.
An expressive root, cf. \U*sĭ̀pi\u.
АПиПЯЯ 70, 295, Мудрак Дисс. 46. Turk. *sīb-ri < *sɨ̄b-ri (with a frequent fronting ɨ̄ > i).
Doerfer MT 241. The Mong. vocalism is not quite regular: perhaps -i- instead of u~o under the influence of the following *-j- (which has to be reconstructed to account for Kor. -i-).
ТМС 2, 73, Rozycki 182. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. The root tends to merge with \U*ši̯ṑli\u 'juice, fluid' (q.v.).
EAS 71, KW 333, Poppe 30, 70, Ozawa 231-232, АПиПЯЯ 72, 274. Mong. is hardly < Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 147.

MEANING: arrow; fight, battle, success in battle
REFERENCE: The Korean reflex is somewhat dubious, being traditionally derived < *sār- 'to live' (sară-čap- = 'to take alive'). This, however, may be a secondary folk etymology, the original meaning of the compound being 'to take booty'.

Лексика 449. Mong. cannot be a Turkic loanword, despite Щербак 1997, 150. The form must be traced to *süt-sün > *sü-sün (with a regular dissimilative development > *üsün). Kor. has a frequent loss of vowel between a fricative and a stop. The original meaning must have been 'liquid' or 'milk-like liquid' (with drops or bubbles on the surface) - whence, on the one hand, sweat" and "soak"
column17: on the other - "milk" (in the Turk.-Mong. area)."

REFERENCE: KW 329, Лексика 153, Miller 1985, 146, 1986, 49. Cf. *sák`a and *sū́ku.
A Western isogloss. Mong. *süji- is a usual metathesis < *sĳü-. Cf. also *sĳu 'ear-ring'.

EAS 108, VEWT 424, Doerfer TMN 3, 325-326 (with quite unjustified doubts), MT 240 (Turk.-Tung.), Miller 1970, 129, Street 1980, 300, АПиПЯЯ 288, Дыбо 13, Мудрак Дисс. 41-42, Лексика 228. The comparison with Kor. and Jpn. seems very probable, although here we have a rather rare case of tonal irregularity: one would expect a low tone in Kor. and a high tone in Japanese. In Jpn. the tonal irregularity could be explained by a contamination with some different root - e.g., with the root reflected in PT *sanč- 'to pierce' (ЭСТЯ 7); but the Kor. high tone is still unexplained. It is interesting to note the common Turkic-Mongolian derivative meaning 2-year-old sheep or camel": Turkic *siĺek / *diĺek (see VEWT 424)
column17: MMong. šilegu
column18: Khalkha šilbe
column19: Bur. šülge (certainly not a loan in Mong. < Turk.
column21: 215 with a detailed analysis of the words
column23: 123). The variant *diĺek (attested in MK tišek and in Yak. tisege
column24: see EDT 563) is an obvious innovation in a part of Old Turkic dialects
column25: following the replacement of *siĺ 'tooth' by *diĺ q.v.
column26: just like WMong. sidüleŋ "2-year-old sheep" is an innovation following the replacement of original *sil 'tooth' by the suffixed formation *sil-dü > sidü."

REFERENCE: EAS 72, 124, 150, SKE 230, Мудрак Дисс. 42.

ТМС 2, 76, АПиПЯЯ 79. Despite Poppe 1966, 198, Doerfer MT 52, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong. The irregular voicing in Jpn. ( < PA *-p-) must be due to a confusion with a very similar root, *sìmpá ~ *símpá 'firewood' < PA *sắp`í; Jpn. dialects show a great deal of confusion between these two roots.

Cf. also PT *sɨ̄pɨŕgu 'flute' (ЭСТЯ 7). In TM one may note Neg. sịwsaxawụn 'wire (for pipe cleaning'), Nan. sịosaqo 'wire (for burning a hole), sịosan- 'to burn (a hole with a wire)', Oroch siapti 'mouthpiece (of a tobacco pipe)' (ТМС 2, 74, 75). These words are hardly borrowed from Mong. sibsiɣür, but are rather reflexes of original *sibe- 'pull out, pick out' (see \U*zi̯upi\u) influenced by the Mong. word.

АПиПЯЯ 275. The Jpn.-Kor. comparison see in Martin 235 (with a somewhat fantastic reconstruction). Actually Korean drops -g- quite regularly, while -r is an obvious suffix; the vowel -u-, however, is a problem (*-a- would be expected), and should be probably explained as a result of contraction (thus *sù'ɨ̀r < *sagV-bVr or the like). Existing TM forms (see ТМС 2,106) are clearly borrowed from Mongolian, see Doerfer MT 39, Rozycki 186. Cf. also Karakh. suɣdɨč 'winter parties, arranged by turns'.
ЭСТЯ 7. Cf. *sĭ̀ga.

VEWT 429, KW 335, Владимирцов 213, АПиПЯЯ 285. The Mong. form can be borrowed from Turkic, but the Tungus and Korean forms are evidently genuine. The variation *sigöl / *sögöl in Turkic points perhaps to original *segöl (which would be the expected form).
Note the morphological match between Evk. suɣulēn and PT *sögü-l- (or *sögü-ĺ-).
A Western isogloss.

EAS 71, 148, KW 333, Poppe 30. A Western isogloss. The Mong. forms may be < Turkic (cf. OT sökit-); but cf. also Mong. soɣsuji-, Kalm. soksī- ( > Oyr. soqsoj- etc., VEWT 426) 'to sit without motion' (KW 329).
Cf. \U*sṑk`e,\u \U*ši̯ŭk`u,\u \U*sák`a.\u

MEANING: a k. of small fur animal
REFERENCE: SKE 221, Lee 1958, 117, Poppe 1950, 579, Miller 2000, 62 . Cf. \U*si̯alo(-kV)\u.
