The original meaning was probably 'inner angle in a robe' (hence 'right lap' in Mong. and 'sleeve' in Kor.), with a generalization ( > 'inner angle') in Japanese; the TM match is semantically plausible (a further development 'gusset' > 'fish fin'), but very scantily attested and thus dubious.
SKE 60, ТМС 2,11, АПиПЯЯ 296.
The Kor. form is a secondary derivative from an unattested verb *sàn-hă-, which explains the verbal" low tone (although the -a-vowel is not quite expected
column17: possibly - a dissimilation from *sằn-hă-). The Jpn. meaning is obviously secondary ("hunting" > "fishing")."

REFERENCE: KW 331, Дыбо 10. Despite Щербак 1997, 166, hardly a borrowing in Mong. < Turk. Hypotheses about the Chinese origin of the word (KW 331, Дмитриева 166-167) are hardly grounded: one has to suppose Chin. > Mong., with a secondary addition of the Mong. plant suffix -gina, with a subsequent borrowing Mong. > Turkic (which is hardly plausible because of old attestation within Turkic); the Manchu parallel also speaks against borrowing from Chinese. See also notes on *sugu 'weed' (there may have been some confusion of these two roots in Kor.-Jpn. and in Turkic).
EAS 119, KW 337 (the Turk.-Mong. match seems valid despite criticism in TMN 1, 348).
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss. Korean has a frequent vowel reduction between a fricative and a stop, which explains the -t-reflex.
Korean has a usual verbal low tone. Cf. \U*sŏ̀k`o\u.
KW 336, SKE 221 (the Kor. form is found only there and thus questionable). Despite Doerfer MT 26, TM forms are hardly borrowed from Mong.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. Cf. also Mong. sonubtur 'султан' (на голове) - either < *sanu-btur or secondarily borrowed from Manchu.
Martin 234 (Turk.-Mong.-Kor.).
Martin 242. Mong. has an assimilation *čuč- < *suč-, usual in roots of this type.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.
An Eastern isogloss. Cf. Karakh. sügič 'a k. of bird' (?) (EDT 819).
Martin 247 (Kor.-Jpn.). It is hard to choose between *-u- and *-o-: Turkic and Korean evidence is not decisive (in Turkic - only MK; in Kor. so'ok could well be an assimilation < *să'ok).

ТМС 2, 105, Doerfer MT 145. Cf. also Kalm. soɣə 'a k. of big plant; a k. of reed' (KW 329). In the Kor.-Jpn. area there may be some confusion between the reflexes of this root and PA *sogŋV 'onion': Kor. sɨŋ'a and modern Jpn. forms like sukampo and suiba may actually go back to the latter.
Medial *-j- should be reconstructed to explain loss of *-l- in Kor. The root seems to be a Wanderwort  (see Аб. 3, 194-195, Cтеблин-Каменский 1972, 31, NCED 965), but may be reconstructable for PA.
A Western isogloss. It looks as if it were derived from *sī́ju 'bite, break' q.v. - lit. 'an ear-biter' (?).
KW 336, Дыбо 15. Cf. *ši̯uga(lV) (with possible contaminations).
The comparison with Jpn. sakana 'fish' in JOAL 98 should certainly be rejected (the only meaning of sakana attested in OJ is food (vegetables) eaten with sake"
column17: thus the modern meaning 'fish' is obviously secondary). Cf. *sàk`ò."

REFERENCE: The Turkic and Mongolian forms basically denote 'tamarisk' or 'tamarisk branches', but whether this meaning was original is not quite clear. Perhaps the root just denoted dry branches (used basically as firewood).
A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss. Suffixation in Korean is not quite clear: perhaps a compound with ko'ăr 'district' q.v.
A Western isogloss. Rather sparsely represented and not quite reliable.

Martin 233. Jpn. *sua presupposes a suffixed form *súm(e)-gV. The root can be traced in all branches, but everywhere is rather scantily represented and thus not quite reliable; the exact sort of the denoted plant is also not quite clear.
A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss. {Cf. PTM *simi ~ -ü- 2, 176; mod. Korean sam.}
АПиПЯЯ 280. A Turk.-Jpn. isogloss. The root is rather dubious (because of its scarce attestation and specific meaning in Turkic borrowing from some unknown source is not excluded).

Cf. perhaps some Turkic forms: Karakh. (MK) sorɨš-, sorɨt- 'to wrinkle', Tuva sortɨla- 'to be painful', sortɨlāš 'dimple', Khak. sortɨx 'hollow cheeks' (although one would rather expect *a-vocalism and preservation of labial in Turkic).

SKE 237, EAS 71, Martin 245. Doerfer (TMN 3, 252) protests against comparing Turk. and Tung. because TM *u (Benzing's *ö) does not correspond to PT *ü. This is of course not true; but the root still has a slight irregularity, namely, high tone in Korean (generally not typical for a verbal root, and not corresponding to Turkic length).
АПиПЯЯ 275; Miller 1981, 869. Cf. *i̯ā́ga.
SKE 242, Martin 250. An Eastern isogloss. Cf. perhaps Khak. sara 'a vessel for sifting flour'.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A common Altaic monosyllabic root.
A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*sĭ̀p`i,\u \U*ši̯ū̀po.\u The three roots are very difficult to sort out; *suba seems to be particularly connected with harnessing.
KW 333, Poppe 109. Hardly borrowed in Mong. < Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 147. Medial *-j-, preserved in Manchu, explains the vowel -i- in Jpn. (otherwise *suk- would be expected).

KW 337, Poppe 30, 70. A Western isogloss, and a quite exceptional case of a V̄ : V̄ correspondence between PT and PTM (expressive root? or an old loanword, cf. Doerfer MT 46 ?). On the possibility of Mong. < Turk. see Щербак 1997, 147.
АПиПЯЯ 277. The root is rare in Altaic, but has reliable external parallels (see МССНЯ, 1, 7). It may also be represented in Turk. *sajɨ- 'each, every', Mong. sajiki 'the same').
Because of the uncertainty of Turkic vowel the vocalic reconstruction is not quite certain.

KW 444, Владимирцов 407, SKE 41; Martin 232, АПиПЯЯ 77. The root seems quite reliable, although not devoid of phonetic peculiarities: the Jpn. form seems to points to a diphthong, while  the Turkic and Mong. forms would be better derived from a form like *suč`u or *suč`o.
A Western isogloss. Preservation of labial vowel in Turk. is exceptional: *seje- would be normally expected.
An expressive root with some vocalic irregularities.
The root must have denoted some blossoming berry or shrub.

KW 359, Владимирцов 173, Poppe 31, 72, 116 (Turk.-Mong.), Мудрак Дисс. 43. Mong. siŋge- may be borrowed from Turk. (see Щербак 1997, 144), but cf. also WMong.  suŋɣu-, šuŋɣa-, Kalm. suŋgə-, šuŋgə- 'to dive', Dag. šungu- (KW 337, 368, MGCD 726; Mong. > Kirgh. süŋgü- etc., see ЭСТЯ 7) < *siŋV-kV. The Jpn. form fits here rather well (*síntú- = TM *suŋ-ta), but we would rather expect *-u-.

EAS 96, TMN 3, 308; Лексика 168. A Western isogloss. The root seems plausible, but has some phonetic irregularities. Instead of Evk. suǯakī one could perhaps compare Tung. *šolčikī 'ferret'  (ТМС 2, 405). Shor čolasčaɣa, Khak. čolǯanaχ 'ласка, хорек' (VEWT 115) is probably < TM.

KW 332, VEWT 429. The Jpn. and Kor. forms (compared in Whitman 1985, 168, 236, and additionally in Vovin 2000 - although his further attempts to link the Kor.-Jap. root to PA *k`i̯ăli should be rejected) seem to fit here  phonetically (although there is a tone discrepancy);  as for semantics, one should probably reconstruct the original meaning 'suck', whence 'lick' and 'tongue' in the Eastern area. Medial *-j- has to be reconstructed to account for the loss of resonant in Kor.; it had also probably caused a dissimilation in the Western area (*si̯ōjri > *sōjri), which explains the -o-reflex in Turkic.

Phonetically OJ subaru is a quite satisfactory match for Mong. and TM forms, so Miller's (Miller 1988) attempts to derive it either from Arabic al-zubra 'mane' (name for the two stars of the 11th lunar station) or from MKor. spɨr 'horn' are probably not necessary.
An Eastern isogloss (Kor. *čə́s is = *čə́č, an assimilation < *sə́č).
Владимирцов 248, Цинциус 1984, 12-13, АПиПЯЯ 293. A Western isogloss. The Mong. variants *čaji- / *čeji- reflect most probably a merger with the root \U*šā̀ŋu\u 'clear, light' q.v.

Mong. has also *čaji- / *čeji- 'be white, whitish', associated in the modern language rather with *čaga-ɣan 'white' (see \U*šāk`a\u), but phonetically rather going back to *čaŋi- < *šaŋu. Despite Rozycki 193, the TM forms are hardly borrowed < Mong.

Mong. s- points to a following front vowel or diphthong, so one should reconstruct *ši̯ā-; in TM *-ā- and -ia- are frequently neutralized after a palatal.  Jpn. *sitəki = Kor. *stə́k; both forms reflect a derivative with a velar suffix (*ši̯āt`i-k`V 'smth. burned, baked'); borrowing Jpn. < Kor. or Kor. < Jpn. is not excluded (see Martin 1996, 45).

KW 423, Poppe 63 (Turk.-Mong.). Mong. is not < Turk., despite TMN 3, 217, Щербак 1997, 144. There are some phonetic uncertainties: Korean has also a variant čə̀čí- 'to soak' (see PKE 30); in TM one observes a variation between *-i- and *-e-.
Лексика 221. A Western isogloss; cf. perhaps MKor. sjə́k 'bridle'.
The root is expressive, but well reconstructable for PA.
A common derivative *šèru-p`V- is reconstructable for Turko-Mongolian (PT *sara-p, *sara-pa-n, PM *sara-b-či). The root evidently denoted some sort of lattice used in construction.
Ozawa 223, KW 358, Lee 1958, 117, АПиПЯЯ 17, Martin 242, Whitman 1985, 127, 212, Martin 1996, 82. Korean has a not quite clear high tone; otherwise correspondences are quite regular.
Дыбо 322, Лексика 257. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. *č- in Turk. is due to assimilation.
A Turko-Mongolian isogloss.
EAS 150, Владимирцов 212, Poppe 30, 47, Мудрак Дисс. 43-44. Mong. cannot be explained as a loanword, despite Щербак 1997, 144, or as bloßer Zufall"
column17: despite TMN 4
column18: 288. In Kor. one has to suppose a secondary development *psɨ́r- < *spɨ́r-."

REFERENCE: The root is rather sparsely attested in Turk. and TM, and the vocalic reconstruction is not quite secure (note that Jpn. -mp- speaks rather against the reconstruction of diphthong - unless the form is not actually a contraction of *súwu-mp- with a labial suffix).
Дыбо 9.
Дыбо 311 (Mong.-Tung.); Martin 232, Miller 1986a, 49, АПиПЯЯ 95, 279 (differently). The root must be kept distinct from \U*si̯ŏlo\u q.v., but contaminations were possible.

MEANING: to see badly, have bad eyesight
REFERENCE: АПиПЯЯ 17.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss. Cf. also Kalm. söb, söwö̆ 'wart' quoted in Владимирцов 1912, 213.
АПиПЯЯ 287, Лексика 197. Kor. has an assimilation, usual for roots of this type; Manchu also demonstrates an assimilation (šoša- < *šosa- which would be regularly expected).

АПиПЯЯ 281, Дыбо 11. Other comparisons of the above roots (Poppe 61, KW 335, VEWT 425a, SKE 233,240) are quite unreliable. The Kor. form sik- may go back to *sig-Vk- (cf. Turk. *sogɨk); a similar prototype can explain Manchu šaxurun < *šig-ak-urun. It is also interesting to note WMong. (L 658) saɣsurɣa 'hoar-frost' ( < *sug-sarga or *suɣa-surga) {and PT *sạgu-k}.
Мудрак Дисс. 41. Cf. \U*sép`a.\u
Лексика 406. A Western isogloss. Mong. and TM have an assimilation (Mong. *sač > *čač > *čas, TM *šusu > *šušu), usual in roots of this type.
Владимирцов 199, АПиПЯЯ 17. Korean has a usual vowel reduction between a stop and a consonant.
A Western isogloss.
EAS 155, Ozawa 111, Murayama 1962, 110, Мудрак Дисс. 41. The Turkic vocalism is quite irregular, probably due to contamination with \U*si̯ūli\u 'gall, pus' q.v. (a similar merger occurred in PJ).
EAS 71, SKE 235, Poppe 30 (with some confusion of this root and {\X0*si̯ṓjru\x} q. v.). A Western isogloss; but cf. notes to \U*seri\u.

Владимирцов 160, АПиПЯЯ 27, 284. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Mong. *u-su can be explained as a normal dissimilation < *su-su ( < *sub-su); cf. similar cases in *sisegeji > *isegeji 'felt', *sü(t)-sü > *ü-sü 'milk', *sus- > \I*us-\i 'disappear, perish'.   The relationship of the Mong. and Turk. forms is strengthened by the presence in Turkic of archaic derivatives *sɨb-sɨ-, *sɨb-sa-.
A Western isogloss, with some vocalic irregularities (the reconstruction *šuga would contradict, however, the consonant reflex *s- in Turkic and Mongolian). Cf. *sŭ́ku.
The etymology seems plausible, although the precise meaning of the root in PA is not quite clear (some sharp instrument used for carving, chopping or ploughing).
Whitman 1985, 181, 233 (Kor.-Jpn.). Korean has a usual vowel reduction between a fricative and a stop.
A Western isogloss. The root may in fact be the same as *si̯òri (reflected in the Eastern area) q.v., but modified under the influence of a synonymous  \U*ši̯ŭŕu\u  q.v.
A Western isogloss.

SKE 238. Mong. may be < Turk., see Щербак 1997, 198. The genuine reflex may be Mong. \I*sir-\i (Khalkha šürge-, Kalm. šürgə- 'to rub off', WMong. sirgü-, KW 371; Khalkha širǖn, Kalm. šürǖn, WMong. sireɣün 'rough, shaggy'; WMong. sirbe- 'to sweep') - although the -i- vowel here is not quite clear. The root generally displays some variation between *ši̯ŭ́re and *ši̯ŭ́ru.
A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*suba,\u \U*sĭ̀bi.\u
EAS 72, KW 329, SKE 219.

KW 355, Владимирцов 198, Poppe 31, 62, АПиПЯЯ 17, Мудрак Дисс. 40-41, 44. Irregular voicing in Mong. can be explained by the root's expressive nature. Cf. also Mong. siǯiŋ 'a person urinating in his bed' - probably reflecting the derivative *šī́gdi < *šī́k`di, attested also in Turkic, TM, Korean and Japanese.
A Western isogloss.
Мудрак Дисс. 41.  Cf. \U*ši̯óp`a.\u
EAS 72, 112, Мудрак Дисс. 44, Лексика 411. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss (but cf. also OUygh. serit- 'to melt (butter)').
KW 429, Владимирцов 255. Cf. also Neg. čaw, čawụ 'rash' ( < Mong.?). An expressive root, with a number of contaminations and irregularities.
KW 428, 430. A Western isogloss.
EAS 155, Martin 234, Miller 1976, 370-371, 1979b, 17-31, Martin 1996, 35. The parallel seems quite plausible (on a similar interchange between island" and "forest" see
column17: e.g.
column18: under *ā́rV)
column19: but vocalism raises some doubts. The reconstruction *ši̯àmi is possible if one assumes PT *simek < *semek (which is quite possible
column20: because the word is only attested in OUygh. and may have actually been semek)
column21: and PTM *šumi < *šimu (cf. the Udehe (An.) form simb́o - perhaps archaic)."

REFERENCE: For Jpn. cf. alternatively TM *tab(u) (ТМС 2, 149) or *topV (ТМС 2, 198).
An interesting common Altaic economical term. Let us note, however, that non-standard affixation in Japanese, as well as irregular tone correspondence,  may suggest a borrowing from Korean.

A Turk.-Mong. isogloss; not quite reliable, because in Turkic one has to suppose assimilative voicing (*dẹg- < *dẹk-). In Korean and Japanese the reflexes of the root could have merged with those of *taku (q.v.)
A Western isogloss.

A designation for some root-crop or grass root. Mong. deg-ne-, Karakh. taɣ-na (although its PT antiquity is somewhat dubious, see above) may reflect a common derivative *tagù-nV. The resemblance of Jpn. tsuku-ne also may be not accidental (although synchronically \I-ne\i is, of course, analysable as \Ine\i 'root').
АПиПЯЯ 71. The Mong. form is somewhat dubious here for semantic reasons. Cf. perhaps also MKor. tái- 'mast' ( < 'stick, prop').
Basically a Kor.-Jpn. isogloss; the Tungus parallel is dubious.
An isolated Japanese pronominal stem. [Cf. the PA demonstrative ??]
АПиПЯЯ 76. Jpn. has *-ə- instead of *-a- because of bad compatibility of *a and *ə in PJ. {Cf. WMo dalĳi- 'lean to one side', dali-, dalbi- 'awry' etc.}.
EAS 110, SKE 257, Martin 225. Vocalism is insecure (Kor.-Jpn. point rather to *tólu).
In Turkic one would rather expect *dạm: perhaps the variants \I*dam\i and *dɨm reflect original *dạm with later interdialectal borrowings.
SKE 254-255, ЭСТЯ 3, 146. Cf. \U*t`úŋi.\u
ЭСТЯ 3, 114. A Western isogloss.
Lee 1958, 107 (TM: Kor.), Дыбо 10. PT *dạrɨ-g is usually regarded as derived < *TArɨ- 'to cultivate (ground)' (see sub *t`i̯òra) which is not excluded.
An isolated Sib.-Turk. form without etymology.
A Western isogloss. Mong. *düji-ren < *dejü-ren, with a frequent metathesis of labialization.
Final -čh in Kor. orthography is probably secondary, as in a number of other cases; for Kor. SKE notes also a variant \Itot.\i Cf. also Oroch toti 'trap' (ТМС 2, 201) < Kor.?
Дыбо 12. A Western isogloss, rather unreliable: the etymology is acceptable if the TM forms are not < Chinese.
Cf. Bur. Olkh. dajdaj 'auntie'.
ТМС 1, 561. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
EAS 50-51, Poppe 22, 74, Дыбо 13, Мудрак Дисс. 186; TMN 4, 186 (lautgesetzlich unwahrscheinlich"). A Western isogloss. The Turk. reflex of the root is usually assumed to be *jālga- 'to lick' - which
column17: however
column18: also matches very well PA \U*ǯālu\u 'saliva
column19: swallow' and should be rather attributed there. In Pre-Turk. we have to postulate a semantic shift 1) 'lick' > 'bite'; 2) 'saliva(te)' > 'lick'."

REFERENCE: A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. The semantic match is perfect, but front row vocalism in Turkic is unclear (*doĺ- would be expected). {Cf. WMo dolu 'bast, bark'}.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss; seems plausible, despite irregular tone correspondence. Cf.  Chuv. tiŋgəl, teŋgəl 'bench'.
SKE 272, EAS 141, Дыбо 9.

Poppe 104, Menges 1982, 105, Дыбо 13. A Western isogloss. There exists also a not quite reliable variant *t`abi id. (Mong. \Itab\i 'clinch, rivet'; TM *tabi- 'to forge' (ТМС 2, 149, with yet another variant *tabi-ti- > *tapti- / *tipti- id., see ibid. and ТМС 2, 186).
The root reveals quite regular correspondences and is semantically plausible (Jpn. 'servant' = 'one who obeys, endures').

EAS 51, Poppe 22, 79. A Western isogloss. The Jpn. reflex could have merged with \U*či̯úŕu\u  q. v. TM *daran can be borrowed < Mong. (see Doerfer MT 73), but *dā- (with preservation of length in a monosyllabic stem after the loss of -r-) is certainly genuine.
Лексика 256, Lee 1958, 107 (Kor.-TM). Cf. *t`ájri.

MEANING: to make knots, tie to a hook
REFERENCE: A Western isogloss. Turkic -ü- is quite strange here ( < *degü-?), so the Turkic match is somewhat dubious.

Jpn. and Kor. may reflect a common derivative *télki-rV (although the source of -u- in the second syllable in Korean is not quite clear). Most languages point to the original meaning 'board covering', probably 'duck-boards in a boat or raft' (with a secondary development > 'plank covering in a sleigh' in Turkic.
A Western isogloss.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss; dubious because of very scarce attestation in TM.

АПиПЯЯ 285, Лексика 264-265. Mong. tamir 'sinew; strength, force' is borrowed from Turkic (to judge from its phonology; see Щербак 1997, 153); but the comparison with daŋgi 'root' may be accepted only if one assumes a secondary assimilation *dam-gi > daŋgi.
A Turk.-Kor. isogloss; Mong. teŋkeleg 'axle' is probably < Turkic. Kor. *thòŋ < *tòŋh.
KW 90, Poppe 23, 45, Ozawa 247-248, Miller 1985, 150, 1985a, 82, ОСНЯ 1, 217-218, АПиПЯЯ 110, 275. Borrowing in TM from Mong. (Doerfer MT 117) is hardly acceptable.

EAS 123, KW 384. A Western isogloss. Mong. cannot be < Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 154, and the Turk.-Mong. match cannot be rejected on phonetic grounds, despite Doerfer TMN 2, 437. However, in this case we must suppose a secondary assimilation in Mong.: tata- < \I*data-.\i
Low tone in Jpn. is irregular (but see above on dialectal reflexes of *tútúap-).
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
A Western isogloss. One of several monosyllabic verbal roots.

Poppe 58, 89 (Mong.-Tung.; on Turk. *jẹg- see under *di̯òge), SKE 260, EAS 51, 145, Цинциус 1972, 4 (but ТМ \I*dǖ\i 'top, above' cannot belong here for phonetic reasons), Miller 1985, 143, АПиПЯЯ 283. TM cannot be borrowed from Mong., despite Doerfer MT 20, Rozycki 58. Korean parallels for Jpn. taka-, take in Martin 236 are improbable; but cf. also Kor. thjə 'up' in compounds, see SKE 48; another old derivative may be Kor. tòt- 'to rise' = Mong. degde-]. A different etymology proposed for PT *dāg is the comparison with WMong. tajiɣa 'forest' (see e.g. VEWT 454). The etymology as such cannot be accepted (because of the wrong correspondence PT *d- : Mong. t-), but Turkic may in fact have merged two originally different roots - which would explain an abnormal correspondence of Turkic long vowel to PJ low tone.
A good common Altaic verbal root.
Дыбо 12. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
АПиПЯЯ 284, Лексика 383.
Tungus-Manchu has -d- as a result of regular assimilation after *d- (cf. *tūti and *dē-du- 'lie' < *dē-tV).
Владимирцов 199, Poppe 15, Ozawa 121-123, JOAL 99, Miller 1985, 144-145. Mong. may be < Turk. (see Щербак 1997, 156), but not necessarily.
АПиПЯЯ 284, Мудрак Дисс. 38, 70, Лексика 228. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
Martin 231. High tone in Kor. is quite exceptional for a verb root and irregular.
АПиПЯЯ 297.

In Turk. one would expect *-ɨ-; the reflex -u- is probably due to the effect of the original labial in -ĺb-. Note that some forms (Tat., Bashk., Yak.) actually reflect *-ɨ-, so perhaps for PT one should rather assume here a form like *dɨĺo-.

EAS 49, 108, KW 444, Владимирцов 145, Poppe 15, 77, Poppe 1974, 133-134, Martin 243, Miller 1970, 129, Street 1980, 301, 1985, 646, АПиПЯЯ 37-38, 71, 92, 277, Дыбо 11, Мудрак Дисс. 196. Certainly not borrowed in Mong. from Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 154. Counterarguments against the etymology by Doerfer (TMN 2, 437-438) are not convincing.

Poppe 28 (Mong.-Tung.), Lee 1958, 113, АПиПЯЯ 19, 33, 292, Rozycki 128. In Mong. one would rather expect *č- in front of -i- as the result of palatalization of *t-; preservation of the voiced consonant may be due to the interaction of expected variants *čiwrin ~ *duirin. The root is no doubt a very archaic one; it is probably attested also in several common Altaic derivatives. Cf. PTM *du-dgu 'couple, spouses' = OJ t(w)otug- 'to marry' (*tub-tu-); PM *dab-ku- 'twice, double, layer' ( > Chag. tapqur, Evk. dapkur etc., see Poppe 1966, 195, TMN 2, 429, Doerfer MT 101), also reflecting a -i̯-less form like *tub-k`V-; PTM *ǯūpti (*ǯub(i)-pti) id.
Cf. also Evk. ǯik- 'to wash away (shores)', possibly < *ǯük- (see ТМС 1, 256).

EAS 50, 150, KW 85, 439, Poppe 16.  A Western isogloss. In Mong. we also have Kalm. dekə- 'to stick in; coire' (KW 85), which Ramstedt (ibid.) compares with the Turkic and TM word; if this were the true cognate, we would have to think that Mong. *čig, *čike is borrowed < Turkic (as suggested in TMN 2, 659). The poor attestation of Mong. deke-, however, raises doubts (so does the final -e in Mong. čike, hardly to be expected in a Turkic loanword), so the traditional comparison (Turk. *dik : Mong. *čike) might be the best solution after all.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss; cf. perhaps also Mong. duldaj 'stick, staff'.
In Turkic one has to suppose vowel metathesis in a trisyllabic word (*dabɨlku < *dɨbulka). An interesting common Altaic plant name.
Дыбо 13.
A Turk.-Jpn. isogloss. The root should be distinguished from *t`úbé q.v.
Ozawa 242, JOAL 68. A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss. In Turkic cf. perhaps Turkm. doGum 'courage'; Kirgh. tuɣulčuɣ 'courageous, skillful'; Oyr. tūragar 'wild, mad, ferocious'.
Miller 1986, 54.  An Eastern isogloss; cf. perhaps Chag. tögä-baš 'Steinplatte auf einem Grab'.
The meaning 'base of a horn' attested in some Turkic languages is probably original and explains well the semantic development elsewhere ( > 'callosity'; 'forehead (of an animal)' etc.).
Дыбо 15.
A Turkic-Jpn. isogloss; not quite reliable, because the Jpn. form can have many possible protoforms.
Владимирцов 368, Doerfer MT 125. Despite TMN 1, 325, EDT 502 Mong. cannot be < Turkic (initial d- cannot be explained). See notes to *t`ṑle.
Martin 245.
Whitman 1985, 126, 218. An Eastern isogloss.

EAS 146, KW 100, Владимирцов 360, Poppe 110, Ozawa 154-156, Murayama 1962, 108, JOAL 35-36, TMN 1, 329-330), АПиПЯЯ 71. In TMN 2, 608 Doerfer tries to deny the comparison with TM (es gibt kein Lautgesetz mo. ö = tu. ü")
column17: which is not justified."

MEANING: birch bark, vessel made of birch bark
REFERENCE: KW 103, TMN 2, 612 (was nicht ganz unmöglich wäre")
column17: Лексика 103."

REFERENCE: SKE 275-276, АПиПЯЯ 71, Дыбо 12. Cf. perhaps Karakh. (MK) tuvur- 'to prick (ears)'.
Whitman 1985, 141, 217.  Mong. and part of TM forms reveal an assimilation; it is not excluded that TM forms like čuču-n are secondarily borrowed < Mong.
ТМС 1, 220. An onomatopoeic root, but with good correspondences.
Mong. has t- due to contamination with tog-si- 'to hit, knock' q.v. ; Kor. has tìh- with irregular vowel (low tone is usual in verbs) due to contamination with tìk- 'to dip  down, imprint' q.v.

The isolated Even parallel is somewhat dubious, but the rest of the forms are well explained by the original meaning 'perceive' (whence both 'listen' and 'ask') and correspond well to each other. {In Mong.  cf. also WMo don-duɣ 'соображающий', donuj- 'осмысливать';  for Evn. duja 'noise' cf. Mong. düj 'возглас для подзыва собаки').}
ТМС 1, 223 (TM-Mong.), Дыбо 13. A Western isogloss.
An expressive root, reduplicated in Japanese.
ОСНЯ 1, 223. A Western isogloss; cf. perhaps Jpn. tsumbo 'deaf'.
A Turk.-Jpn. isogloss.
ТМС 1, 216, АПиПЯЯ 286, Дыбо 11. A Western isogloss.
The isolated Manchu parallel is somewhat dubious semantically (not a 'relative by marriage', but a coeval), but the Turkic and Jpn. forms correspond well to each other.

KW 105, Владимирцов 165, EAS 51, Poppe 23, 82, Miller 1996, 151, АПиПЯЯ 71, Дыбо 12, Лексика 207 (but PT *jǖŕ is to be separated, despite all the above sources). The TM forms may be < Mong. (see Doerfer MT 76, Rozycki 65), but not necessarily so.
Martin 229, Murayama 1962, 110, АПиПЯЯ 71, Лексика 173. Cf. also (phonetically unclear) Mong. toɣuriɣun 'crane' (KW 397).

All meanings are well explainable from the original 'make, produce a sign'; the diphthong -jə- in Korean is somewhat unexpected and makes us reconstruct PA *tū́jk`ú (otherwise *tū́k`u would serve just as well).
АПиПЯЯ 48, 290. Korean has a verbal" low tone."
A Western isogloss.
Владимирцов 366, Лексика 79. A Western isogloss.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. The relationship to TM *dō- 'to sit down (of birds)', suggested in ТМС 1, 211, is unclear; if it exists, we may be dealing here with an archaic case of *-p`-suffixation.
A good match, but with irregular tone in Jpn.
On TM *-d- see under *tḕtu.
АПиПЯЯ 14, Лексика 279. Jpn. *(d)ə-i goes back to a suffixed form *ti̯ṓl(e)-gV ( = Mong. deli-ɣün).
EAS 126, KW 393, Lee 1958, 118, АПиПЯЯ 52, 289, Rozycki 207, Doerfer MT 26 (Elementarverwandtschaft"). Cf. Mong. terteɣe 'on that side'
column17: \Iterse\i 'inimical
column18: adverse' = Turk. tetrü 'opposite side'

REFERENCE: A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Cf. also TM *tagdī- 'to pull out' (ТМС 2, 150-151), PT *dāga- `to stray, disperse, diverge' (ЭСТЯ 3, 119-120) - either a different root, or a variant of the above.
Martin 246. Medial *-j- accounts for -j- in Kor.; Mong. has a frequent secondary labialization *torku < *tarku.
The Jpn. suffixed form may reflect either *t`ắkta-lV (cf. Tuva tadɨla-) or *t`ắkta-rV (cf. Kirgh. tatar-).
Дыбо 15.
The root is not widely spread, but phonetically and semantically plausible.
In Turkic one has to suppose *toku < *taku, with secondary labialization.

An Eastern isogloss; cf. also Chag. taq 'Name eines Baumes, der langsam brennt', see SKE 250 (Kor.-Turk.; but it may be < Pers., see TMN 2, 439 and Bailey 42). Possibly more than one root: cf. also OJ tuga, mod. \Itoga\i 'a k. of fir tree'.
A somewhat dubious Tung.-Jpn. isogloss: the comparison is possible only if  Jpn. *túká- 'pickle' is distinct from *túká- 'soak'  (see \U *t`éku\u ). {Cf. PE *taʁju- (*taʁəRu- ?) 'salt'.}
ТМС 2, 153. {Cf. PE *taka- 'rack, trivet, tripod'}
The root is rather abstract, but seems quite reliable.
KW 387, Poppe 13, 55. A Western isogloss.
Phonetically plausible (although containing a rare cluster *-kl-), but, as in many cases, the original sort of the tree is difficult to establish.

Дыбо 46. A Western isogloss. The old meaning of the Turk. form can be reconstructed on the basis of the Mong. loanword  tašaɣa 'hip' (Khalkha tašā(n) 'hip, thigh; piece inserted between cloth laps', Bur. tašān 'hip, side', Kalm. tašā id., Ord. dašā id., but Mongor tašaG 'scrotum'), see Дыбо 1992. The Turkic form is sometimes derived from *diāĺ 'stone', with a semantic parallel in Finn. kivi 'stone' - kives 'testiculi'; let us note, however, both a phonetic discrepancy (*diāĺ 'stone' has voiced *d- and a long vowel), as well as a semantic inconclusiveness: Finnish kives is a diminutive with the first meaning plummet on a net"
column17: whence metaphorically "testicle"
column18: whereas no "plummet" or "sinker" meanings are attested anywhere in Turkic."

REFERENCE: KW 377, Doerfer MT 55 (onomatopoetisch-verdächtig"). Cf. Oyr.
column17: Khak. tamɨ 'taste'. Jpn. *tamias- may be alternatively derived from \U*t`emV\u q.v."

REFERENCE: Miller 1981, 857, АПиПЯЯ 275. A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss. Ramstedt (SKE 254) compares the TM root with different material (Kor. tam- 'to fill, put into' etc.), but we prefer this comparison (for Kor. tam-, Manchu tama-, tami- 'to collect' cf. rather Jpn. tum- 'to fill, put into', see *t`amu).
EAS 116, SKE 254, Lee 1958, 118, АПиПЯЯ 70, Martin 233. Rozycki 201 considers TM < Mong., which is not excluded.

In Jpn. the root has partially contaminated with \U*čèm(b)a\u  'round' q.v. (which may explain the accent disagreement with Kor.). In Turkic cf. Dolg. (Stachowski 216) \Itana\i 'alter, ausgetrockneter Rentierknochen': semantically most close to the Evk. word (see below), but -n- is strange for a loanword < Evk. taŋa.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss. Somewhat dubious, because in Jpn. the root is confused with *tamura 'plot, camp, encampment' (see *t`āma), while in TM the form may be derived < *taŋ- 'count' (see *t`ănŋu).

An interesting common Altaic religious / juridical term. The proposed etymology presumes that the meaning 'sky' in Turkic is secondary ( < 'God'); if it is not the case, one could accept S. Georg's thesis about a loan in Turkic < Yenisseian *tɨŋgVr- 'high' (see Georg 2001) - although we must admit that other loans from Yenisseian are unknown to us.
Cf. Turk. \I*Tan-\i 'deny, disclaim, be treacherous' (EDT 513-514).
Cf. also Kor. tǟ- 'to tell, indicate, confess' (SKE 249, EAS 120); MMong. ta'ul- (HY 40) 'to understand, distinguish'  ( < *taŋul-).
One of common Altaic bird names.
The final vowel is not clear: Turk. points to *-i, but Jpn. - to *-a or *-o; otherwise quite regular.
Владимирцов 211, Poppe 47, Miller 1981, 854, Street 1985, 640, АПиПЯЯ 67. In Turk. *-ɨ- would be expected; perhaps *topul- is a result of secondary labialization < *tɨpul- (*tɨpol-).

Владимирцов 208, Poppe 13, 47, PKE 222, KW 386.  Mong. cannot be < Turk., despite TMN 2, 429, Щербак 1997, 153 (although the vowel correspondence is not quite satisfactory: one would expect -e- in Mong.).
Владимирцов 210. A Western isogloss. Mong. has a frequent secondary assimilative labialization (toɣur- < taɣur-). Cf. also OT (Suv.) (kir) tapča 'грязь'.
The root must have denoted some small wild animal (marmot or racoon-like).

Ozawa 245-246. Despite TMN 1, 253, Щербак 1997, 154, Mong. is hardly borrowed from Turkic (the OT form is tar-, while modern Kypchak forms like tara-, tarqa- are most probably borrowed < Mong.); on Turk. *dar- see under *tā̀ro. Medial *-j- is reconstructed to account for the loss of *-r- in Kor.
A Western isogloss. Some Turkic forms may have been influenced by *torgaj 'lark' (q.v.).
A Western isogloss.
KW 389. Suffixed forms are perhaps Mong. tesi- 'slide', TM *tisa- 'swim' (ТМС 2, 188).
Basically an Eastern isogloss: the Turkic parallels are late attested and somewhat dubious. A common Altaic derivative *t`ā̀ki-rV is reflected in PT *TEkir- (?), PK *thɨ́r and PJ *ti(n)ki-ri.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss. Cf. perhaps also WMong. taqu 'a k. of fish' ( > Man. taqu, Nan. taqụ 'толстолобик').
KW 376. Mong. may be < Turk (see TMN 2, 543, Щербак 1997, 152); but Turk. hardly < Samodian, despite Helimski 1995.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.

EAS 116, KW 377. Mong. (Kalm.) tam may be < Turkic. Although semantically quite plausible, phonetically there are difficulties: PT has a secondary voicing and Kor.-Jpn. have irregular tone (not corresponding to PT length). See VEWT 459.
SKE 256. Cf. also Karakh. teŋüč 'half cubit' (i.e. 'big hand-span', cf. Slav. pẽdĭ id. < pẽ-tī 'to stretch, pull').

MEANING: nose, part of face round nose
REFERENCE: Poppe 13, 69, АПиПЯЯ 289, KW 378, VEWT 460. A rather complicated case. Both Turkic and Mongolian forms are attested late, and can be borrowed from each other. If Mong. < Turk., then one could perhaps consider instead a possibility of comparing PT *T(i)āna with Mong. *taŋlaji 'palate' (whence again Chag. taŋlaj etc., see KW 379, VEWT 461-462, and Evk. taŋilai, see Doerfer MT 128). However, Mong. *taŋlaji may be alternatively compared with Turk. *damgak 'palate' (ЭСТЯ 3, 142; thus in Владимирцов 285, Лексика 230) - if one supposes a secondary assimilative change *t- > *d- in Turkic. PT *damgak 'palate; gills' may be, in its turn, alternatively compared with Evk. ǯalgama 'a piece of skin from deer's chin'. This knot of etymological problems is yet to be untangled.
KW 378 (Turk.-Mong.).
KW 385, Лексика 289. Cf. \U*t`op`u.\u The Turkic form is quite irregular - very probably a distortion of the expected *tāban under the influence of *dāp- 'to trample' q.v.
Лексика 412. An expressive reduplicated root, perhaps with variants *t`āt`u and *t`ōt`u (cf. Turk. *tōt and Evk. tuta-).
Владимирцов 256, Poppe 44, VEWT 468, Лексика 69.
Poppe 14, Rozycki 205-206. Cf. \U*t`ep`a\u , \U*t`ḕjbo.\u
The parallel seems reliable, although voicing in Korean is not clear (note a similar case in *t`i̯óp`a).
All branches may reflect a common Altaic derivative *t`édù-bV.
Lee 1958, 118, АПиПЯЯ 292.  As a noun the PTM root has the meaning seat
column17: bench"
column18: which makes the comparison with Japanese quite plausible. An Eastern isogloss - but cf. notes to *t`égè(-rV) 'edge

REFERENCE: Lee 1958, 118, Martin 238. The root seems to be homophonous to *t`égè 'sit, bed' and may be in fact derived ('edge, place' < 'sitting place'. The Turkic reflex here seems probable, but rather controversial: the word - if it continues PA *t`égèrV - has been heavily influenced both by PT *deg-ir- 'round' < PA *tega (hence 'surroundings') and *dẹg- 'to touch, reach' ( < *ti̯ok`e q.v.).
Mong. and TM reflect a common derivative *t`ĕ̀ja-bV.
An Eastern isogloss; see notes to \U*t`ák`u.\u
A Western isogloss. Lee 1958, 118 cites MKor. takar 'horseshoe' which we were unable to locate.
KW 390. Despite Doerfer's (TMN 2, 660) criticism, the Turk.-Mong. match seems quite probable.
Korean has a usual verbal low tone.
In Kor. the reflex is hard to distinguish from that of \U*t`ḕŕu\u q.v.
Most sources indicate that the root was used as a fishing term (either a string in the net or a needle for the net). Morphologically cf. the match between PT *temen and Manchu temene ~ temun.
АПиПЯЯ 286. A Turk.-Jpn. isogloss. Cf. perhaps TM: Ud. tumpali 'capsule', Evn. tumtej 'star' (ТМС 2, 213).
SKE 261, ТМС 2, 234. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss; but for a possible Jpn. parallel see \U*t`ama,\u  and for a possible derivative reflected in Turkic and Japanese see *t`ìnt`a.
An expressive Western isogloss.
An Eastern isogloss. Cf. perhaps Mong. temeɣel-ǯirgene 'dragonfly' (folk-etymologically merging with temeɣen 'camel').

Владимирцов 258. The root is rather difficult to distinguish from \U*t`ēpa\u  'to catch, embrace' and from \U *t`òp`u\u  'round, clot' : an expressive sound shape, liable to mergers. Note that within Turkic there may have also been a confusion of this root with PA *tújpè 'hill, top', cf. some Oghuz forms with d-  (Doerfer TMN 1, 450-452 attempts to connect Turk. *tepe with Mong. deɣe- 'above', which has a different, quite plausible etymology). The original meaning of *t`ep`a could be top of head" (whence "tuft of hair on top or back of head"): cf. the common Turk.-Mong. derivative *t`ep`a-lV 'spot on the forehead of an animal' (WMong. tögele
column17: Khalkha tȫĺ; Turkm. depel
column18: Az. täpel

REFERENCE: SKE 263, PKE 203, EAS 49.  An Eastern isogloss. Cf. \U *t`ebV\u  and  Bur. tebtēr 'cover (of pot)' - a word of obscure origin. For Jpn. cf. alternatively: WMong. čeger, Khalkha cēr 'taboo, prohibition', Turk. čeper 'fence, protecting fender', see Владимирцов 211-212; cf. also Oroch čeppe- 'to sin'?.
The root should be distinguished from \U*tā́p`V\u and \U*t`i̯óp`e\u q.v., although they certainly tend to be confused.

EAS 111. Cf. also WMong. (L 779) tarasu 'sp. of small eagle'. The root is practically homonymous with *t`eŕo 'bald' (q.v.) and may be in fact a specialization of the latter, as a 'bald eagle' (note that this is the traditional etymology of the Turkic word).

SKE 280, АПиПЯЯ 296. This comparison seems better than relating the Korean word to Turk. *tel 'wire' (SKE 282). Equally unconvincing is Doerfer's (TMN 1, 244) attempt of deriving the Turk. forms from an Iranian source.
A Western isogloss.

EAS 111, KW 380, SKE 250, Poppe 13. Despite Щербак 1997, 154 we cannot assume borrowing in Mong. from Turkic. Turkic has a secondary voiced d- (one of the cases of voicing in front of -ŕ-); but a contamination of two roots is also not excluded: cf. also Mong. dar-gar, dars-gar (L 233: darsa-ɣar) 'rough, warped (of skin)'. Cf. also notes to *t`ĕ́ŕa ( ~ -o) 'eagle, vulture'.
One should also note Ul. tarpigda 'a k. of knife' (ТМС 2, 169; from a Mong. form like *tarpagaj?).

EAS 109, KW 413, Владимирцов 255, Poppe 13, 44, 77, Новикова 1972, 123-124, Лексика 164, Miller 1970, 128, JOAL 118. Both in Turk. and Mong. there exist also verbal roots (PT *tabɨĺ- 'to run', e. g. Chag. tauš-, tawuš- etc.; WMong. tauli-, taɣuli- 'to chase, pursue', see EAS 109, TMN 1, 276, 2, 616). Despite TMN 1, 277, Щербак 1997, 151, one can hardly speak about borrowing in Mong. from Turkic.
Medial *-jb- should be reconstructed to account for -b- (not -ɣ-) in Mong. corresponding to *-b- in Kor. Cf. *t`ebV.
The etymology appears quite plausible both semantically (in Jpn. 'differ' < 'to be separate from') and phonetically.
Despite Doerfer MT 52, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong.
ТМС 2, 231. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Mong. has -ö- under the secondary influence of töl 'newborn young animals' ( < Turk. *döl q. v.).
Phonetically and semantically plausible, but rather sparsely attested in Mong. and Jpn.
Turk. *deŋgiŕ 'sea' (ЭСТЯ 3, 194-195; > Mong. teŋgis, see Clark 1980, 39) may also belong here (with a secondary voicing). See SKE 280, EAS 145. Cf. \U *t`i̯oŋe\u  'air or water space'.

Poppe 14, 45. Despite Doerfer MT 52, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong. The Kor. verb has a typical low tone. Kor. tabal 'bundle, bunch' (see Martin 227), which we have attributed to PA *t`ĕp`á, seems to be a better match for Jpn. *tà(n)pá, but Jpn. also has *ta(m)pua 'knot of hair', and the two roots actively interacted in the Kor.-Jpn. area.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
Contaminations with *t`ōŕe (in Kor. also with *t`elbu) were possible.
Mongolian has alone preserved the Nostratic 2d p. stem \I*t`i;\i other Altaic languages have retained only the other stem *si (*si̯a), with the oblique stem *nV.
EAS 88. A Western isogloss. Initial *d- in Turkic is  due to assimilation, but borrowing in Mong. from Turk. cannot be accepted, despite TMN 2, 671, Щербак 1997, 154.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. Very poorly attested in Turkic; but cf. a further Nostratic etymology (Ural. *täjV, Kartv. *ṭil-) in МССНЯ 335.

KW 439, Poppe 15, 16, 55, Мудрак Дисс. 37-38. Cf. also Kor. tìk-mə̀k- = MJpn. túí-pam- 'to peck' (lit. 'press and eat'). In TM one would rather expect *-x-; this means perhaps that we could reconstruct *t`ĭ́kù, with assimilation in Mongolian.
Дыбо 14. A Western isogloss.
Дыбо 13. A Western isogloss.
Мудрак Дисс. 39, 86.
A Turk.-Jpn. isogloss: but a possibility exists that the root is actually a contraction < *t`emi-t`a, derived from PA *t`emV q.v. (for the parallel PT *tint- : Mong. temteri- see KW 391).
A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss; not quite secure because of vowel reduction and metathesis in Korean (for a similar case cf. Kor. *psɨ́r- 'sweep' < PA *šĭp`V).
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.

A Western isogloss. Mong. *toguɣan must be a case of labial attraction < *tagu-ɣan. But cf. also \U*t`i̯áku\u, as well as Kor. tok `earthenware vessel', togani 'earthenware dish in which metal or glue is melted' ( < Mong.?); cf. also a Wanderwort in Tung. (Ul. tukuru etc. 'bottle'), Ainu tokkuri, Jpn. tok(k)uri 'bottle', Kor. tuguri 'round metal dish'.
KW 375, Владимирцов 206, Мудрак Дисс. 199-200.  Despite Щербак 1997, 152, not borrowed in Mong. < Turk. Doerfer's (TMN 2, 443-444) criticism is also hardly substantial.

Except for open *-e- in Turkic (one would expect *-ẹ-) correspondences seem regular - but the root is very similar to \U*t`i̯age\u q.v., as well as to some regional Wanderwörter, so there may have been some confusion of different etyma.
Martin 225. Korean has a usual vowel reduction in the first syllable. An Eastern isogloss.

A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. The root seems to be different from *nī̀k`e and *ńi̯ṑge, although there may have been some natural confusion. It is interesting to note Jpn. naka(ma) 'friend' - perhaps a secondary contamination with naka 'middle'?
SKE 253.
A Western isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss. Not quite secure because of the vocalic correspondence.
Irregular tone and vowel in Korean may suggest a possibility of loan ( < OJ tasi). Cf. also Mong. tasĳa 'lie' ( > Man. tašan, tašara- etc., see Doerfer MT 119).

A Western isogloss. See Дыбо 7, Лексика 154. The parallel seems probable, but PT should rather have a closed *ẹ. There may have been some confusion between this root and another one, represented by PT *Tagɨ 'female kulan' (OT taɣɨ, see EDT 466; Bulg. toxə 'horse') and borrowed in (or corresponding to?) Mong. taki 'wild horse'.

A rare case of high tone in a verbal stem in Korean. The unmistakable identity of PM *telej = PTM *tōli suggests that the association of Mong. teleji 'belt' with tele- 'to spread' is secondary, due to the merger of the roots *t`i̯ā̀lo and *t`ḗlù (q.v.).
A Western isogloss. MMong. may be < Turkic (though not necessarily); a Mongolian source is probable for Chag. tälgän, Nogh. dial. telegen, KKalp. telegen, see Лексика 534-535 with literature.
Doerfer (TMN 3, 207) considers the Kalm. form to be the source of TM, which is hardly plausible. Cf. \U*t`ḕŋa\u  'lowland'.
KW 373, 388, Poppe 13, 42, 47, Дыбо 15 (the root is often confused with *t`áp`a q.v.).

Владимирцов 272. Cf. \X0*tā́p`V\x, \X0*t`ĕ̀p`a\x (with a possibility of mergers). The Turk. variant *dēp- is secondary, probably under the influence of *dāp- < *tā́p`V, but may be rather old: cf. the match PT *dep-se- : PM *deb-se- 'to stamp, tramp' (a secondary loan is hardly possible in this case).

KW 380, 387, Poppe 62, Мудрак 181. Jpn. reflects a suffixed form *t`i̯òr(a)-gV (cf. Mong. tari-jan).  Cf. *tăra: if PT *dạrɨ-g 'millet' is derived from this root, then Mong. *tarĳa-n should be considered a Turkism, and the reconstruction should be emended to *tVra.
On Turk. *dīre-, *dīre-k see under *t`ī́ri- (a contamination). The Mong. (Dagur) and Manchu forms may ultimately have a Turkic origin.
A Western isogloss.
Martin 236, АПиПЯЯ 94, 278, Vovin 2000.

The Jpn. diphthong is not quite clear.  It is interesting also to mention Turkic data: cf. Karakh. tolun in tolun aj 'full moon' (MK, see EDT 501), with tolun formally being a participle from *dol- 'to be filled', but in fact used only in this phrase in the sense of full moon". Modern Turkish has dolunaj 'full moon' with d- (just as in dol- 'be filled')
column17: but the verb tolun- 'to become full (of moon)' - which would correspond quite regularly to PA *t`i̯ṑlo. One should reckon with a possibility of rather archaic contamination in Turkic (since most languages do not distinguish between the reflexes of *t- and *d-)."

REFERENCE: KW 413, Лексика 515. In Kor. cf. also thúkú 'helmet'.
An interesting Mong.-Tung.-Jpn. match.
PKE 211. A Tung.-Kor. isogloss (both TM and Kor. reflect a suffixed form *t`i̯uk-dV).
KW 409. A Western isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
Mong. -n- points to *-nŋ-; TM *tuŋsi- perhaps < *tunŋV-si-.
The *-p`V is probably an original suffix, but reconstructable already for PA.
АПиПЯЯ 287. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. TM also has variants *tilpa- / *tilba- (see ТМС 2, 180) meaning both 'dirt, smear' and 'snowstorm' and having arisen due to contamination with \U *t`elbu\u  q. v.

EAS 98, Владимирцов 293, Poppe 66 (Turk.-Mong.), Martin 228, АПиПЯЯ 96-97, 278, Лексика 147. Despite Doerfer's (TMN 2, 647-648) doubts, the Turk. form cannot be separated from the others, although it shows a somewhat peculiar phonetic development. PJ *túmá- < *túpá-n-: cf. also OJ tubunak(j)i 'ankle' ( = PT *tubńak, Evn. tuwnuke).
The root seems well reconstructable, although not very widely spread.
The root seems reliable, although the vocalism is not quite certain: see above the notes on variation *e/i in Turkic; Kor. -ɨ- is also unexpected.
KW 416, Poppe 112. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss; regarded as a loan in Mong. from Tung. by Doerfer MT 47-48, which is rather dubious.
АПиПЯЯ 282, Дыбо 10, Лексика 198. A Western isogloss.
EAS 148, Владимирцов 165, Poppe 112, Лексика 81. A Western isogloss. Despite TMN 2, 574, not borrowed in Mong. < Turk.

EAS 112, KW 415, Владимирцов 361, Poppe 112, Дыбо 6, Мудрак Дисс. 39, Лексика 286, Doerfer MT 69-70. Despite АПиПЯЯ 282, Mongolian and Tungus  forms should be still considered as genetically related to PT *dɨ̄ŕ (*dīŕ),  and the reconstruction must be changed accordingly. This is one of the few  cases of secondary voicing in PT (before *ŕ, *r): the original  voiceless reflex is preserved within the Common Turkic derivative *tir-sgek 'elbow' (Лексика 247-248) ( = TM *türē-kse; the latter form, despite Rozycki 213, cannot be borrowed < Mong.).

In Turk. one has to accept secondary fronting (*titir < *tɨtɨr - if the attested form is not actually tɨtɨr, just wrongly vocalized). It is also tempting to compare OJ t(w)od(w)o, mod. todo `eared seal, Eumetopias jubatus' (for a very similar semantic relation cf. PA *tā̀ŋo), but the vocalism is not quite clear.
KW 393, Poppe 14, 104, АПиПЯЯ 295. A Western isogloss. Cf. also Turk. *Terk 'quick, hurry' (VEWT 475), WMong. terkei, Kalm. terkɛ̄ (KW 393). {ND 568 mentions also WMo derkire- 'run, race'.}
EAS 150, SKE 35, Мудрак Дисс. 36-37. One of the cases of secondary voicing (*t- > *d- before the following *r, *ŕ) in Turkic.
KW 401. Mong. is not < Turk., despite TMN 2, 606-607, Щербак 1997, 158, Sukhebaatar.
The root tends to contaminate with *t`òp`ú 'round', but still seems to be clearly distinct in all languages.
The etymology was first proposed in fact by Vullers 1855, but rejected by Doerfer (TMN 1, 263) without due discussion.
A Western isogloss.
KW 408, Poppe 60, Rozycki 200.
In Turkic languages the root may have been partially contaminated with a synonymic *t`ḕbà 'run' (q.v.) (PT *tabɨĺgan 'hare'); but the traces of PT *togus are still clearly visible.
Ozawa 253-254. An expressive root.

The TM word is usually considered to be borrowed < Samoyed.; this seems somewhat dubious because the Samoyed. (Selk. togɨl, Kam. tuɣul, see UEW 451-452) words point not to *-ŋ- ( < Ural. *suŋV-lV), but rather to *-k-, and thus may themselves be borrowed < TM.

KW 398. There may have existed an expressive variant with *t- (cf. some Turkic forms, Mong. doki-ɣur 'drumstick', doki- 'to hit, knock down' (KW 93), Evk. (May.) dokto- 'to hit, chop'); see Дыбо 13. The root is of course expressive (see TMN 2, 460), but seems reconstructable for PA, and distinguishable from *tùgi 'to pound'.

Дыбо 15. The word may be in fact identical (or derived from) \U*t`ok`V\u 'curved' q. v. Doerfer (TMN 2, 526) tries to dismiss the Turk.-Tung. match for reasons historical (the Manchu forms means Chinese button" - but in fact it means "metallic button in general")
column17: semantic ("Knopf!" - so what?) and phonetic ("das -n" - so what again? -n is a very frequent TM suffix). The obvious semantic development in TM seems to have been "buckle" > "button"."

REFERENCE: ТМС 2, 192. A Western isogloss. Cf. \U*t`ok`u \u  and \U*t`ū̀k`V\u (see also notes under *tegá). Despite Poppe 1972, 96, 100, Doerfer MT 69, TM is not borrowed from Mong.

A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. Mong. töl 'newborn animals' may reflect a merger of this root with a borrowing from Turk. *döl q.v.; but cf. perhaps tulbaɣa(n) (Khalkha tulbān) 'fry of the Siberian salmon', tulu 'Siberian salmon' - which can belong here if the meaning 'salmon fry' was original in Mongolian (with a later development > 'salmon' and consequent formation of the new derivative for 'salmon fry').
Лексика 204. The Kor. word may be analysed as bald"+"brain" (see *t`eŕo and *kèĺo)
column17: so it may be necessary to remove it from the etymology (although a folk-etymological reanalysis was certainly possible); if not
column18: the PA reconstruction should rather be corrected to *t`ōjlu."

REFERENCE: A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.
EAS 50, KW 399, Poppe 14, 68, Ozawa 261-262. Despite Doerfer MT 27, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong.
Ozawa 22-23.

MEANING: to bow, bend, turn upside down
REFERENCE: Despite Doerfer MT 82, hardly borrowed in TM from Mong. The Kor. reflex is questionable, but cf. some semantic developments in TM.
Cf. *tegá.
KW 408, Владимирцов 271, Poppe 14, 49, АПиПЯЯ 110, 279, Дыбо 6, Лексика 286.

АПиПЯЯ 284. See TMN 2, 596-601 (with a hopeless confusion of Turk. \I*top\i 'round thing', *toprak 'earth, dust' and *topɨk 'knee cap' - all of which have different etymologies). Cf. also *t`obú 'fruit, cone' (a different root, but a source of some contaminations).

Turk. *törü 'law' is probably an old derivative of *töŕ: *törgü, with an early disappearance of *-g-: cf. Hung. törvény < Old Chuv., pointing to *-g-. Mong. *töre may be < Turk. (see TMN 1, 266), though not necessarily so.
KW 407, Владимирцов 322, Дыбо 13. Mong. may be < Turk. (see Щербак 1997, 158).
KW 402, АПиПЯЯ 70, 274, Дыбо 8, Martin 228, Лексика 176.
The precise berry denoted by the root is of course unknown (notice the meaning 'currants' in TM and Korean).
SKE 269.   An Eastern isogloss. In Kor. cf. also tɨthɨi'ú- 'to move away, apart'.

A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Cf. also WMong. toquɣu, Khalkha toxū `joke, jest', possibly derived from the same root and pointing to PA *-k`-. Not quite clear is the relationship to some scattered TM forms: Man. taqda- `to praise, be surprised at', Evk. takā- `to lie'.
A somewhat dubious Turk.-Tung. isogloss (with a secondary voicing *t- > d-), see Лексика 272.
A Western isogloss.
KW 411. Despite Щербак 1997, 159, hardly a borrowing in Mong. < Turk.

KW 405, АПиПЯЯ 19, 70, 91, 274 (but Jpn. *tùti should be rather attributed to PA *t`ēŕu), Дыбо 11. Cf. Jpn. doro 'dirt' (PJ *tə̀rə̀; attested late and initial not clear). Contaminations with *t`ēŕu were possible.
Cf. \U *t`i̯ór(g)e\u  'support, beam' - a source of possible contaminations.
Дыбо 7. A Western isogloss.
Poppe 14, 79. In Kor. -ɨ- would be expected; -a- is possibly a result of vowel assimilation.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
KW 385, SKE 259, Lee 1958, 117, АПиПЯЯ 70. Cf. perhaps Bulg. (Mudrak) etə 'five' (cf. the Jpn. form).

MEANING: a k. of bird of prey
REFERENCE: The root evidently denoted some big bird of prey (kite, eagle or falcon); the isolated Ul. form fits in well phonetically, but not so well semantically.
A Western isogloss.
SKE 269 (Turk.-Tung.), Дыбо 14. A Western isogloss. The Turk.-Tung. match seems quite probable, despite TMN 3, 355 (rein zufällig")."
The cluster *-jb- (in this case preserved explicitly in TM) accounts for the preservation of *-b- in Mong. and for the development *-b- > -w- (-0-) in Japanese.
A good Turk.-Mong.-Jpn. match.
A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss.

MEANING: to come to an end, be exhausted
REFERENCE: KW 406, Владимирцов 154, Poppe 57, Miller 1981, 863 (Turk.-Jpn.). Despite Щербак 1997, 160, not borrowed in Turk. < Mong. It seems worth mentioning  Evk. dial. tịko- `to die (of exhaustion), starve' - which may, however, be a derivative of tik- `to fall'.

KW 409, Дыбо 7, Sinor 1962, 321, Лексика 434. A Western isogloss. Despite Doerfer MT 104, hardly borrowed in TM from Mong. The Turk.-Mong. parallel is dismissed by Doerfer (TMN 2, 525), because lautgesetzlich ist tü. -q- nicht = mong. -ɣ-" (?)."
Martin 1996, 109.  An Eastern isogloss.
See АПиПЯЯ 70, Лексика 161. Jpn. high tone does not correspond to PTM length (the latter, however, is reconstructed only on the basis of the Sol. form and thus not reliable).
Manchu may be borrowed from Mong. (despite vocalic differences), thus the Proto-Altaic antiquity of the root is dubious; see, however, a Nostratic etymology in МССНЯ 341.

MEANING: base of tree trunk or grass stalk
REFERENCE: KW 415. Cf. OJ twoma 'mat made of grass (miscanthus)'?
Accent correspondences between Kor. and Jpn. are irregular: cf., however, the irregularity in Jpn. dialects (especially Kagoshima tómò, pointing to original high tone in the first syllable).
АПиПЯЯ 109, 279, Ozawa 130, Лексика 483. Turk. *tumak > Kalm. toməɣə, whence again Kirgh. tomaɣa etc. (a similar source is probable for Manchu tomorχan), see TMN 1, 258.
? Cf. Turk. *tolmač 'translator'.
Jpn. reflects a suffixed *t`ŭ́ŋ(e)-gV.
Mong. > Evk. tuŋa, tuŋi. Cf. \U*tằnŋu.\u
A Western isogloss; however, in Jpn. the root probably merged with *ĕbà  'winnow, blow' q.v. (cf. especially the PJ form with a velar suffix *apu-(n)k-, OJ apug-).
An onomatopoeic root, but seems well reconstructable for PA (including the morphological derivative *t`ŭ̀p`i-k`V > PT *tübkü-r-, PJ *tù(m)pà-k-).

A Western isogloss: the PA antiquity is rather dubious because of late attestation and possible loans. Mong. may be < Turk., cf. TMN 2, 505, Щербак 1997, 159. The Turk. form itself is somewhat doubtful  because of a strange variation -m/-p (see TMN 2, 504-505, with a suggestion of an Iranian origin). A possible source can be Chin. 土卵 tǔluǎn, MC thólwấn, OC thāʔrhōnʔ 'yam', lit. 'earth egg', whence also MKor. thóràn, Kor. thoran, Jpn. tororo 'yam'.

Within Jpn. the form is analysed as a compound \I*ta\i 'hand' + *suka- 'help', which is probably a folk etymology in view of the external evidence; cf. especially Kor. thas which points to *tasVh- = Jpn. *tàsùkà-. Not quite clear is the position of several forms: WMong. tos- 'to receive, encounter' (maybe, following Clark 1980, 41 < Turk. *dūĺ- 'to meet' - although the latter is certainly borrowed as WMong. tus- 'to hit upon, fall to one's share', so this would be a somewhat unusual etymological doublet); Manchu tusu- 'to marry, celebrate marriage' (could be a Mong. loanword, but the semantics is strikingly different). Finally there is MKor. tā̆sk- 'to love, like'. This evidence suggests a possibility of a separate PA root *t`oso (*t`osu) 'to present to the guest, to celebrate'; but a possibility of later interdialectal loans of the reflexes of *t`i̯ŏ̀so should also be considered.
A Turk.-Kor. isogloss:  Mong. *hutuɣa 'smoke' must be separated - despite АПИПЯЯ 34-35, 285.
An expressive root, but no doubt common Altaic. The Turkic, Korean and Japanese forms correspond well to each other; the TM (isolated Evk.) reflex is more questionable.
Cf. \U *čā́kte. \u A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss.
Дыбо 14. A Western isogloss. The Turk. form may reflect a contamination with \U *togi\u  'mound, dam' q. v.
Despite Poppe 14, 55 the root should be distinguished from \U*t`ok`V\u 'curved' q.v.
A Western isogloss (with secondary voicing before -ĺ in Turkic).

KW 406, Дыбо 15, Мудрак Дисс. 70; not borrowed in Mong. < Turk., despite Rona-Tas 1972, 232. A Western isogloss. PT has *d- here because of secondary voicing before *ĺ, as in a number of other cases; despite АПиПЯЯ 97, 276 this (more traditional) comparison seems now preferable for us. {Cf. PE *tuluʁ- 'to drowse'}
A Western isogloss. Cf. perhaps various OJ plant names (tumi, tumama), although they do not refer specifically to plants with edible roots.
An interesting Common Altaic term indicating some sort of economic relations.

KW 397, 404, Martin 228, АПиПЯЯ 15, 71, Ozawa 248-249. Cf. Mong. *togta- 'to stop, establish' ( > late MTurk. toqta-, see TMN 1, 273, Щербак 1997, 211; Yak. toxtō-, Dolg. toktō-, see Stachowski 226; Man. tokto- etc., see Poppe 1966, 191, Doerfer MT 119). In Kor. cf. also MKor. tətăi 'slowly', tətăi- 'to delay, be slow' (compared with TM in Lee 1958, 118). Mongolian, Korean and Japanese accent variants may indicate that we are dealing more than with one root here, but the distinction is difficult to make.
In Mong. the root reflects a partial contamination with \U*út`a\u q. v.
The Turkic reflex is preserved only in Yak., which may be an important archaism.
АПиПЯЯ 282.
Phonetically plausible; however, late attestation and expressive reflexes in Turkic reduce the reliability of the etymology.
A Western isogloss.
A Turk.-Jpn. isogloss.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. EAS 153 (despite criticism in TMN 2, 141 the old etymology may still be valid), Лексика 435.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.
It is interesting to note OJ akwo 'child' (usually in addressing) - usually regarded as a-kwo my child"
column17: which may be a folk etymology. Cf. also WMong. (L 16) aɣul ači 'one's own grandson or descendant' ( < Turk.?)."

REFERENCE: A reliable common Altaic root.
Лексика 171. An onomatopoetic Western isogloss, which does not exclude its antiquity (despite TMN 2, 156).
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.

KW 456, Владимирцов 323,  (Turk.-Mong.), PKE 63 (Kor.-Turk.). Low tone in Jpn. (not matching the low tone in Kor.) is probably due to contraction. The Mong. form cannot be separated, despite TMN 2, 156 (lautgesetzlich mit der tü. Form nichts zu tun"). One should also note PTM *üge-n 'river duct' (Neg. īɣen
column17: Ud. jogo-so
column18: Ul. ui-n

REFERENCE: One of the many common Altaic names for small animals.
A Western isogloss.
The root probably denoted 'relative, kin' in a broad sense.
Martin 236, Whitman 1985, 187, 194, 245. A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss: phonetically very similar to *ójle 'small fruit' (q.v.), but the semantic   difference is baffling.

A dental derivative *uju-tV seems to be reconstructable on the basis of PT *uja-t-, PM *uji-d- and Manchu oj-ta-bu-. It cannot be excluded, however, that we are dealing with two different derivatives, somewhat mixed up: *uju-t`V- (PT *uja-t-, MMong. uji-t-, Manchu oj-ta-bu-) and *uju-dV- (OT uja-d-, PM *uji-d-).
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
Korean has a usual low verbal tone.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss; very scantily represented in TM, therefore dubious.
KW 447, ОСНЯ 1, 255-256 (Turk.-Mong.); АПиПЯЯ 289,  МССНЯ 333. Despite Щербак 1997, 167, there is hardly a reason to regard Mong. as a loan from Turkic.
For the Kor. form see notes to \U*k`ḗja.\u

Владимирцов 247, PKE 136-137. Despite Doerfer MT 96 and Щербак 1997, 120, the word seems to be inherited (loans Turk. > Mong. and Mong. > Tung. are not easily explained phonetically). The stem appears to be an old derivative with the suffix *-rga, but the deriving root is hard to find. Poppe 1972, 96 cites Evk. oku- 'to catch a bird with a snare' which we were unable to locate; there exists, however, Manchu oχolǯon, oχolǯi 'snare, loop' (ТМС 2, 10) which is likely to contain the same root. The relationship to the synonymous \U *p`urVk`V\u  'rope, lasso' q.v. remains unclear; the two stems are clearly distinguished in several subgroups, but (due to the development *p`- > h-, 0-) are easily confused. The Mong. form *uɣurga is interesting: it is exactly parallel to Turkic *ukruk and shows the same cluster development (*-kr- > -ɣ(V)r-) as *bŭkrV ( > buɣur-čak) and *č`ik`-rV ( > čiɣire) q.v.
Cf. *bū̀k`e. {Cf. PEsAl *aku- 'precipice'?}

SKE 174 (Mong.-Kor.; but the TM parallel drawn by Ramstedt and repeated in Doerfer MT 25 - Evk. ogonī - cannot belong here, being a reflex of PTM *xoba-nī, see ТМС 2,6), АПиПЯЯ 297. -g- in Mong. must be explained by assimilation.
A good Mong.-Tung.-Jpn. match. Borrowing in Man. from Mong. is hardly possible, despite Rozycki 166.
The root may be *ulo (cf. Mong. ulari- without the -b- element).
So far there are no certain Altaic parallels discovered: cf. perhaps -ül in Turk. *degül, see *tagi. A Nostratic etymology see in ОСНЯ 1, 17, 263-264.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. {Cf. WMo ülĳ 'бугорок над норкой', ülĳre- 'покрываться бугорками, быть разрыхленным'}.
Дыбо 9, Лексика 159.
Дыбо 9, Лексика 173.
For the meaning in TM cf. the semantics in Mong. (both 'crush into pieces' and 'boil (down to softness)'.
Лексика 241-242. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
KW 448, EAS 110 (Mong.-Tung.), Murayama 1962, 110 (Jpn.-TM). Korean has standard verbal low tone. In Turk. cf. perhaps Yak. ul- 'to melt'; Kaz. ɨlɣal, Turk. ɨɣal 'dampness' (ЭСТЯ 1, 645-646).
ОСНЯ 2, 110, АПиПЯЯ 286, Дыбо 12.
Poppe AU 115 (Turk.-Mong., although Turk. *uĺak is not separated from *ub-ĺak 'small' - which is the reason for Doerfer's objections in TMN 2, 63).
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss. {WMo ölčir 'able to stand the cold'}.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.   Cf. perhaps Karakh. (MK) \Ioš\i 'core (of a horn etc.)'.

The Mong. form may also be borrowed < Turk., see Щербак 1997, 166. Cf., on the other hand, Mong. omuɣ 'kin, clan' (which, however, may be a modification of the other attested form, Mong. obuɣ = Turk. *ōpa, under the influence of the present root; Mong. > Yak., Dolg. omuk, see Stachowski 193 ).

A Western isogloss. The stem may be derived from Common Altaic \U*úmu\u 'to bear, give birth' q. v., see АПиПЯЯ 58, 281, Дыбо 10, Лексика 149. The Turkic form, however, must have also been influenced by PA \U*nāmo\u 'testicle' (and/or *ǯi̯ŏmu `round'), which explains initial *j-.
EAS 116, Poppe 68-69, KW 450, VEWT 514, АПиПЯЯ 295. A Western isogloss.
A highly dubious comparison, because of extremely scarce reflexes in Turk. and Japanese.
Дыбо 306.
Ozawa 59-60 (Mong.-Jpn.).
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss. See ТМС 2, 274. {Cf. PE *unaʁə-ci- 'wood, drift-wood' ?}
KW 287, Rozycki 218.  Despite Doerfer MT 111, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong.  Mong.  (and some Turkic reflexes) go back to a suffixed form *uŋe-kV(jV).
Basically a Turk.-Tung. isogloss. If Mong. argali is related, then Turk. *arkar (see ЭСТЯ 1, 176, Лексика 155) 'mountain ram' must be an old Mong. loanword - which is somewhat dubious.
A Western isogloss.
See notes to *arV.
A Western isogloss.
ТМС 2, 286, Miller 1982, 402 (Jpn.-TM).
An Eastern isogloss.  Cf. also Shor uzan 'наплечник вроде капюшона из козлиной кожи, надеваемый звероловами в мокрую погоду шерстью наружу'.
An Eastern isogloss. Korean has a frequent initial vowel reduction.
A derivative *ut`à-lV- (probably *ut`à-li- to account for the fronting of the second vowel) is reflected in PTM *uti-l- and Kor. ə́tìr-.
Cf. \U*ùč`e.\u

The meanings 'island' and 'forest, bushes' are frequently associated in Altaic, so the etymology on the whole seems quite plausible. Note the common derivative *ót`ó-rV reflected in PT *ot-ru-g, Orok ute-ri-kte and PJ *ə́ntə́rə́.
Medial -ǯ- in Mong. must be due to assimilation.
Medial *-j- accounts both for an unexpected vowel development and preservation of -b- in Mong., and for -w- in Jpn.
EAS 143, KW 447. A Western isogloss. The Turkic and Mongolian forms clearly point to the original meaning 'pierce, sew', so the attribution of the TM form (to tie
column17: bind") is not quite reliable. One has to deal with a possibility that the TM forms
column18: despite their wide distribution
column19: are actually borrowed from Mong. uja- 'to tie
column20: bind' (which cannot be genetically related to Mong.
column21: since the latter goes back to PM *huja- - so far without Altaic etymology -
column22: with h- well preserved in Southern Mongolian languages)."

REFERENCE: KW 448, PKE 223, JLTT 742. An expressive root. Because of the merger of *l and *r the Kor.-Jpn. reflexes of this root may also be attributed to *óru (thus in Lee 1958, 118), and vice versa.
An expressive Western isogloss.
EAS 112, KW 452, Poppe 81, АПиПЯЯ 34, 283. Cf. *ūre.
Poppe 102. A Turk.-Mong. isogloss, but, despite TMN 2, 145, not Turk. > Mong. (-ŕ is not a suffix here!).
The Evk. form most probably reflects a suffixed *ner-gdi; less probable is a specific development of the cluster *-gr-. Cf. *ĺóre.
Closed *ạ in Turkic is probably an influence of *jạt- 'to lie, sleep' (see *dḕ).
АПиПЯЯ 30, 285. Regular except for a somewhat unexpected closed *-ẹ- in Turkic.
Jpn. *sə̀tə́ instead of *sàtə́ as in a number of other cases, because of bad compatibility of *a and *ə in PJ.
In Korean one has to presume a rather natural semantic shift 'young man' > 'male'.

KW 323, Poppe 29 (Mong.-Tung.), Лексика 412, Whitman 1985, 188, 234 (Kor.-Jpn.). In Turkic -lm- reflects *-ĺm- (Helimski's rule"). *-j- has to be reconstructed to account for the loss of -ĺ- in Kor. This is the only root pertaining to metal terminology that can be reconstructed for PA
column17: and it is not quite clear what metal was meant (perhaps meteorite iron - it is highly dubious that the speakers of PA possessed any kind of developed metallurgy). Note that in the Turko-Mong. area the metal name as such was lost and preserved only within the name of iron objects (sabre
column18: armour)."

REFERENCE: АПиПЯЯ 58-59, 283, Лексика 85. Cf. also  WMong. saja, Kalm. \Isā\i 'newly' (KW 316), EAS 72, probably a variant of the same root with different vocalization. Turkic reflects an attributive form (*jeŋi < *jeń-ki); medial *-j- has to be reconstructed because of the loss of *-ń- in Kor.

The Mong. -ü-reflex is not quite clear: since -ld- is not simplified in this case, we may suspect that the original form was *süle-de, probably with usual labialization metathesis < *selü-dü, with consequent vowel reduction.
An expressive root, but appears to be well reconstructable for PA.

Lee 1958, 116 (Kor.-TM), АПиПЯЯ 294. Mong. jara- 'to shine, glimmer', which is usually compared with the PT form (see KW 216, Владимирцов 317, VEWT 189) is an obvious loanword from Turkic. Illich-Svitych (ОСНЯ 1, ХV) regards Mong. sara as a prosodic variant of sira- 'yellow', which is hardly the case. Jpn. tone seems to contradict TM length, but the root is only attested in compounds and may be itself a contraction (see below), so the tone may well have been displaced. If the Jpn. word is indeed to be analysed as *sa- 'early spring' (+ *tukui 'month', 'moon'), then its original meaning must have been '(beginning of a new) moon cycle, season' -  cf. the meaning 'season' in Kor. and TM, and especially 'beginning of the year' in Kor. (note that TM \I*sē\i biaga has also the meaning 'first month of the year' > Manchu se-bĳa, Jurch. sei-bi(a)ha, see the discussion in Lee 1958). The form \I*sa\i itself has to be explained as reflecting a suffixed *zēr(a)-gV or *zēr(a)-ŋV - cf. Jurch. sejŋe-r and Mong. *sara-ɣu-l.
Poppe 115. Despite TMN 3, 315, hardly a loanword in Mong. < Turk.
The Turkic form may also have been influenced by PA \U*ni̯áŋa\u q.v. The Jpn. form is probably metathesized: *sìntúka- < *sìnkutá- ( = TM *siŋkuti-).

In Mong. and Tung. the root may have been confused with a local Wanderwort for 'sorgho', cf. Man. šušu 'holcus sorghum', Nan. sịso id. (cf. also Rozycki 196); Kor. susu id. The direction of borrowings here is difficult to establish, but note that Mong. *sisi violates the rule of dissimilation of fricatives - if it were genuine, we would rather expect *sisi > *isi. A possible scenario, therefore may presuppose a development of the meaning 'sorgho' (from 'lentils', 'peas') in the TM area, whence it penetrated into Mongolian and Korean. The root for 'lentil', 'pea' itself, preserved in Turkic, TM and Japanese, seems, however, common Altaic.
{In Korean one has to presuppose a semantic development 'be in a trance' > 'be vexed, sad'.}

KW 348. A Western isogloss. The Turkic reflex is difficult: on the one hand, it is usually not distinguished from *jaŋak 'door post' (which actually can go back to a quite different source, see *p`i̯àŋk`i); on the other hand, it may also be a modification of *jag-ŋak and have a connection with TM *ǯegi 'chin' (ТМС 1, 281).
Man. sasuqu 'cards', sasu- 'to shuffle' (ТМС 2, 67) probably < Kor. Mong. \I*us-\i < *sus- through regular dissimilation (cf. *ši̯uba etc.).

High tone in Jpn. is probably due to contraction (*suán-tai < *sugan-tai, where -tai = *tai 'hand'). If *zi̯ognV (with a rare -gn- cluster) < *zi̯onV-gV, the stem may be a derivation of *zi̯ōnu 'fist, hand' q.v.
Лексика 283. A Western isogloss.
The match is quite regular except for the somewhat unexpected closed *-ạ- in Turkic.
Mong. > Man. sadun et al. (see Doerfer MT 119, Rozycki 172) > Kor. sadon ( not < Chin.!).

MEANING: a small hole; to pull through a hole
REFERENCE: In Turk. \I*jib\i < *jüb (secondary dissimilation). Korean has a usual vowel reduction. Cf. also notes to *sī́p`i 'pipe'.
The Jpn. form can also reflect \U*sak`V\u 'to ferment' (q.v.).
EAS 72. {ND 2666 adds Mong. sölür 'bending backward (as a bow); one who throws back his head'}.
Лексика 264.  A Western isogloss.
A Western isogloss. On Mong. ǯeɣeken see under *čágo.
A good common Altaic root.
Jpn. *su reflects a suffixed *zur(u)-gV. For Turkic cf. alternatively Manchu ǯurun 'hole, cave'.
A Western isogloss.
The root has a general meaning 'cut' in the Eastern area (TM and Japanese), and a more specialized meaning - 'wound' - in the Turko-Mongolian area; it is not quite clear which one is more archaic.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss. Cf. Turkm. juvdarxā 'monster, k. of dragon' (contaminated with aždaxa < Pers.?)
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.   Cf. perhaps (with dialectal *ǯ- > j-?) MKor. jə̀-t- 'eight'.
Despite Doerfer MT 23, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong. Jpn. *dá- presupposes a suffixed *ǯál(o)-gV, cf. Mong. ǯal-ga-.
KW 480 - doubted by Doerfer in TMN 4, 223.
Poppe 28, EAS 64, Lee 1958, 113, Menges 1984, 266.

See PKE 24. Mong. ǯaru- 'to use, employ' may represent a merger of this root with \U*ǯi̯óra\u 'send' q. v. MMong. kerek ǯaraq 'needs' - probably < Turk. (see Щербак 1997, 164). Jpn. *də́rə́- instead of *dárə́- because of bad compatibility between *a and *ə in OJ.
Оzawa 299-300, АПиПЯЯ 297. Kor. čh- reflects in this case a metathesis of aspiration (čhări- < *čăr-hi-).
Дыбо 5. A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Cf. perhaps Man. dadara- 'to spread; yawn' (ТМС 1, 190; assimilation < *ǯadara-?).
The root is not widely represented outside the Turko-Mongolian area (only in Japanese), but the phonetic and semantic match appears to be quite satisfactory.
A Western isogloss (but cf. perhaps also Kor. čultti 'throat'). Cf. also \U*tā́lu\u.
Menges 1951, 109. A Western isogloss. In Turkic *jɨb- would be normally expected, but a shift ɨ > i after j- is rather common.

ТМС 1, 251, АПиПЯЯ 293. A Western isogloss. For the semantics in Turkic cf. the TM derivatives:  *ǯap-ku 'afflux, influx' (ТМС 1, 251), Man. ǯajfan 'place where rivers meet' (ТМС 1, 241); a foreign source for *jāp is, however, also not excluded.
Accent correspondence between Kor. and Jpn. is irregular.
A Western isogloss.
Correspondences are regular, and the etymology appears quite plausible.

MEANING: a k. of weed or swamp plant
REFERENCE: Jpn. *də̀mə́- < *dàmə́- because of the incompatibility of *a and *ə in PJ.
An interesting common Altaic cultural term.

A Western isogloss. In Turkic one could also compare *jarɨ (*jaru) 'side', but the word is attested late, restricted to the Kypchak area and may be in fact a simplification of *jāk 'side'+ directional -ru (cf. especially length in Oyr. d́ār); see ЭСТЯ 4, 145-146.

A difficult word. On Turk. *josun and Mong. josun see above; Mong. *ǯisü thus seems a better historical match for Turk. *josun. There still remain, however, phonetic problems: in Mong. one would rather expect *ǯüs- or *ǯös-, not *ǯis- (possibly we are dealing with a vocalic metathesis *ǯisü- < *ǯüsi-?); and Evk. ǯesē - although hardly a Mong. loanword because of semantic difference - is also not quite regular (one would expect *ǯis-).

EAS 65, Poppe 27, Lee 1958, 113, АПиПЯЯ 35, 281, Дыбо 13. Mong. *ǯoɣog 'meal; pleasure' was alternatively compared (see KW 477) with PT *juba- 'to enjoy; console' (see ЭСТЯ 4, 240-241) - which is not excluded, but does not weaken the rest of the etymology. The derived form with a labial suffix must have already existed in PA (Kor. čap- = ТМ *ǯe-p- = PJ *da-pa-). The root (one of a number of common Altaic monosyllabic roots) is quite valid, despite Doerfer's (TMN 4, 193) critical attempts. .
Poppe 27, JOAL 86, 153, АПиПЯЯ 77.  A derivative *ǯāj-nV- may be also reflected in PT *jānu- (~-a-) 'to whet, sharpen', Mong. ǯanu- id. (if not < Turk.).
Phonetically the TM form is a very good match for the rest; the meaning 'boast' may be connected if we suppose a causative formation ('cause annoyance (e.g. by boasting') > 'boast'.
EAS 52, KW 484, SKE 32. A Western isogloss; Ramstedt compares also Kor. \I-ti-\i (mod. \I-či-)\i 'to become', in which case the reconstruction should be changed to \I*di.\i
Turk. *jügür- reveals an assimilatory labialization ( < *jigür-).
KW, Владимирцов 209, Poppe 47, 80, 123. Despite TMN 1, 3, not a loan in Mong. from Turk.

Poppe 14, АПиПЯЯ 40-41, 285 (with some confusion of this root and *t`òŋke q.v.). An expressive root with some violation of correspondences; but borrowing in Mong. from Turkic is hardly acceptable, despite Щербак 1997, 154. In Mong., a variant *toɣ- may be present in *toɣuri- 'go round' (MMong. (SH) to'ori-, KW 408, Dag. tōri-; > Man. torgi-, ТМС 2, 204), tojira- id.; a variant *dug- in WMong. duɣuj, Khalkha duguj, Kalm. duɣu 'wheel, ring' (L 271, KW 101), whence Tur. dial. toɣaj, Kum., KBalk. toɣaj 'ring, part of wheel hoop'. Cf. also PA *t`ŏk`V 'curved', also a possible source of contaminations.
АПиПЯЯ 287. Medial *-j- accounts for loss of *-n- in Kor.
A Western isogloss.

Владимирцов 271. A Western isogloss. Closed *ạ in Turkic is not quite clear (perhaps secondary vowel assimilation in Yak.?). Mong. ǯubčaɣa (L 1077) 'fur-lined, cloth garment with fur inside' may be secondarily borrowed < TM.

MEANING: a k. of foliage tree, alder
REFERENCE: The etymology is possible, though somewhat problematic. Whether the Japanese Daphnyphyllum may be equated with the Turkic and TM alder is a botanical question requiring additional clarification; as for the equation of the Turkic and TM forms, it is possible if we assume PTM *ǯugde- < *ǯurke, with the original velar suffix reinterpreted as part of the root.
Jpn. *duá(m)p- < *ǯi̯āba-p- (with contraction).
Martin 230 (Mong.-Tung.-Jpn.), АПиПЯЯ 77, 291.

VEWT 205 (Turk.-Mong.), АПиПЯЯ 287. The Turkic form may belong here if PT *jogan < *jojga-n. The Japanese form goes back to an intermediate variant *ǯi̯oč`u-k`a (with assimilative devoicing of *-ǯ-). Korean has a frequent verbal low tone.

АПиПЯЯ 100, 275, Дыбо 46, Лексика 178, Vovin 2000.  TM *ǯoji (in fact *ǯobi) 'Salmo lenoc' (compared in some of the above sources) has a precise match in WMong. ǯebege and has to be separated; see *ǯi̯abo. The Jpn. form could also belong there phonetically, but the close match with Kor. thi makes its derivation from *di̯ági more plausible.
Лексика 89. A Western isogloss.
Semantically a challenging etymology, with some mythological connotations; nevertheless phonetically impeccable and seems quite probable as a common Altaic root.
Ozawa 160-161, JOAL 69.
Дыбо 10. A Western isogloss. Secondary delabialization in Mong. (*ǯedegene < *ǯödegene).
PKE 37, Lee 1958, 113, Дыбо 11.
A good Mong.-TM-Jpn. parallel (although poorly attested in TM).

KW 114, Лексика 557, Tekin 1981, 121-122. A Western isogloss. Despite Щербак 1997, 125, Mong. cannot easily be explained as a Turk. borrowing. Doerfer (TMN 1, 297) mentions Turk. *jular : Mong. *ǯiluɣa, but rejects without explanation.
KW 477, Poppe 28, 58, Дыбо 8. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.  Despite Doerfer MT 47, TM is hardly borrowed from Mong.

EAS 65-66, KW 110, ТМС 1, 272, VEWT 200 (but the Kor. form čičči-da, despite SKE 37, hardly belongs here), АПиПЯЯ 285; hardly justified is Doerfer's criticism in TMN 4, 254-255. A Western isogloss. For the Turk. forms meaning 'snake' cf. alternatively TM *sulama / *salama 'snake' (ТМС 2, 57) - if the latter is not borrowed from Russ. dial. саломея 'a mythical snake'.
Martin 234, АПиПЯЯ 15, 69. Low tone in Kor. is irregular.
A Western isogloss.

MEANING: hollow under knee or neck, corner
RUSMEAN: выемка под коленом или шеей, уголок
REFERENCE: An interesting term, basically anatomical, denoting a hollow or angle in some body part (angle in the corner of the eye; angle / hollow under the neck; angle / hollow under the knee). A common derivative *ǯòp`è-k`V is reflected in Mong. *ǯob-ki and PTM *ǯup(u)-ku.
KW 483-484, Владимирцов 188, АПиПЯЯ 282. One cannot exclude Mong. being borrowed from Turkic (see Щербак 1997, 126), but there are no special reasons for that.
Basically a Western isogloss; the Japanese parallel is somewhat ambiguous.
Дыбо 14. An expressive reduplicated root, but no doubt archaic.
Poppe 28, 101, Rozycki 128. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss; but despite Doerfer MT 24, TM cannot be borrowed from Mong.
A Western isogloss.

EAS 65, KW 479, Владимирцов 197, SKE 31, Poppe 28, 111, Дыбо 13. The comparison seems quite valid, despite doubts in TMN 4, 225. Despite Poppe 1966, 191, Doerfer MT 24, Rozycki 128, TM is hardly < Mong. Loss of *-g- in Turkic is probably explained by the fact that the root is only used with suffixes (*jüg(V)k > *jük, *jüg(V)d > *jüd-).

АПиПЯЯ 77, Rozycki 124. Tungus forms may be borrowed from Mong. (see Poppe 1966, 194, Doerfer MT 80).   Medial *-j- has to be reconstructed, as in a number of other cases,  to explain Mong. -b- (not -ɣ-) and Jpn. *-w- (not -p-); exceptional back vowel in Turkic may be also due to dissimilation with the medial *-j-. In Turkic one has to suppose a semantic development 'thin' < 'lean, weak' (the latter meaning is actually widely attested since the earliest texts).
SKE 36.
A common derivative *ǯi̯òto-rV is reflected in Mong. *ǯüde-re- and Jpn. *dàtùrà-.
The etymology is worth listing, but not devoid of problems: in Mongolian we have only an isolated Kalmuck form, and the Tung.-Jpn. equation is possible only if the variant *ǯōn- in TM is secondary.
ТМС 1, 258, АПиПЯЯ 293. A Western isogloss. The vocalism is hard to establish because of reduction in PTM.

Whitman 1985, 129, 243 (Kor.-Jpn.). The root presents considerable difficulties, and the reconstruction is by no means certain. Phonetically: in PT one should expect rather *jūŕ; the Jpn.-Kor. tone does not correspond to PT length; Kor. *j- is quite exceptional (a better match for Kor. would be perhaps Mong. *je(r)-sün 'nine', *jeri-n 'ninety' (Ozawa 32-33 compares Mong. with Jpn., but initial *d- in Jpn. is an unsurmountable obstacle ); in Kor. cf. also jə̀rə́h 'a big quantity, number'). Criticism see in TMN 4, 222. Still the Manchu-Jpn. match seems plausible, and some irregularities could be explained by contaminations or tabooistic reasons.
An isolated root in Amami dialects; external relations are unclear.
An isolated form (attested only in the Yonaguni dialect) of obscure origin.
An isolated obscure Japanese dialectal form.
An isolated and obscure form (in the Kagoshima dialect).
A specific Ryukyu root without reliable external parallels.
A Ryukyu root of obscure origin (?cf. PT *daŋ 'morning dawn'?}
Finch 1987, 17 (Jpn.-Mong.). One of the few exceptional cases of *ǯ- > *j- in Kor. (cf. *ǯa 'eight').
Poppe 37, 140, 158, JOAL 70. All forms reflect a dental suffix.
Martin 248. A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss.
Martin 231. An Eastern isogloss.
JOAL 98. A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss; cf. perhaps Tuva čakpa ( < *japka) 'fin'.
Whitman 1985, 185, 219 (Kor.-Jpn.). Korean has a usual verbal low tone.

A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Low tone and shortness may be reconstructed because of Mong. *h-. The root is similar to *p`út`a and *bòt`e q.v., but still should be probably reconstructed as a separate etymon.
An Eastern isogloss.
The original meaning is well reconstructable as 'to arrange, take or lead (smb. or smth.) in a row'.

A Turko-Mongolian isogloss. One is tempted to suppose lost *p`- and to unite this root with TM *pemu-, Jpn. *pàm- (see *pèma).
