This is, however, hardly possible, because both Middle Mongolian and Dagur have 0- here (while Mongor x- can easily be secondary in front of a voiceless stop). A possible solution would be a loss of *h- ( < *p`-) in Proto-Mongolian (or even Proto-Turko-Mongolian) under the influence of a phonetically close nursery" word
column17: *ĕ̀me 'mother
column18: female' q.v."

REFERENCE: SKE 101, Lee 1958, 112. An Eastern isogloss. The Jpn. *kə̀tə̀ seems a good match, but within Japanese it is rather hard to separate from the homonymous *kə̀tə̀ 'word, speech' (see *gĕ̀re(pV)). This is probably a secondary merger, but responsible for the irregular accent correspondence between Kor. and Jpn.

A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss. See Martin 241, АПиПЯЯ 297  (with some confusion of Kor. *kə̀čh 'exterior' and *kằč- 'near; end, limit', see under \U*kèč`a\u, \U*k`i̯oǯa\u). The root seems very similar to both *kèč`a and *k`i̯ŏ́ǯa, but in fact cannot be reduced to either of them. It is not even excluded that the root does not exist at all: Kor. kə̀čh 'exterior side' may be just a variant of kàčh 'skin' (see under *káč`u), while Jpn. kátà may go back to PA *k`ada 'side, to turn' (q.v.).

MEANING: a k. of fruit with seeds inside
REFERENCE: One is also tempted to compare PJ *kákí 'persimmon' ( < *kem-k`a), but the word can be alternatively compared with TM *gaka-kta 'cranberry' (ТМС 1, 136). Cf. also other similar plant names: \U*ki̯omga,\u \U*gi̯aŋu\u, \U*k`éma\u.

KW 476. A Western isogloss. Medial -m- in Mong. is probably secondary (assimilatory here). Note that all languages reflect a derivative *ńi̯ūno-gV (in Turk. cf. *jōn-ga 'chips, wooden shavings' = Mong. *ǯomu-gu-l = TM *ńüŋ(g)-).
Kor. has a usual verbal low tone.
A good Mong.-TM-Jpn. parallel.
Jpn. \I*na\i goes back to a suffixed form *ni̯āl(o)-gV ( = Kor. *nắrh); Mong. reflects a regular dissimilation *nüjile- < *nüli-le ( < *nilü-le or *nelü-le).
Despite EDT 828, the Mong. verb cannot be < Turkic.
A Mong.-Kor. isogloss.
Korean reflects a suffixed form like *sipo-kV. Cf. perhaps Nan. čịGbora 'black birch' (which would change the reconstruction to *š-).
A probable Jpn.-Turk.-TM match.
A Turk.-Kor. isogloss.
The root is actively (esp. in Mongolian) contaminating with *sī́p`i 'pipe' (as something which may be poked, perforated).
An interesting common Altaic body part name. The final vowel is difficult to reconstruct because of contraction in Jpn.
The root is rather difficult to distinguish from *si̯ā́ńi and *saŋe q.v.
An onomatopoeic root, but with quite good correspondences. Cf. also notes to \U*si̯ā́ńi\u. {ND 2092 compares also WMo seŋgene- 'sing (of wind'): possible if < *siŋgene-.}
Martin 242. An Eastern isogloss.
Originally opposed to *sắp`i (q.v.) as a long twig or stick with a handle (used for punishment etc.).
A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss. {? Cf. PE *aɣi-ʁ- 'to come'}
The etymology seems to be satisfactory both phonetically and semantically.
An expressive Western isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss; the Jpn. form reflects a suffixed *t`ŭ̀m(V)-gV.
Mong. *čoɣu-da- - with a secondary (usual) labialization < *čaɣu-da-. Cf. also *č`i̯op`a, from which this root is sometimes difficult to distinguish.
A common derivative *kìp`í-čV is reflected in all branches.

In TM one would rather expect *gialeŋē, but the existing forms may be explained as secondarily monophthongized. Despite АПиПЯЯ 80, the Jpn. form rather belongs here (semantically it is exactly = Mong. ɣalaɣun, and in case *kàrí < *gāŕV we would rather expect *kàtí).

In Turkic *Keĺ- would be expected; -ö- is probably due to the influence of a very close phonetically and semantically Karakh. kölige 'shadow'.  In Korean one would expect rather *kə́rVm-, so the tone and vocalism appears to be distorted. This all may be due to expressive (tabooistic) reasons, as well as to the interaction between this root and PA *k`òlmV 'cloud' q.v. {Cf. WMo ɣoluj-, ɣolu-ɣur 'потухший, тусклый, неяркий' - perhaps better for Turkic.}

KW 119, Владимирцов 323, Poppe 86. A Western isogloss. The phonology of the word strongly resists all attempts to regard it as an interlingual borrowing (Turk. > Mong. > TM, see, e.g., Rozycki 67), as well as attempts to derive it from Armen. \Ieš\i etc.
An interesting TM-Jpn. isogloss. It is perhaps worth noting the particle jamu mentioned by MK for contexts like sen barɣɨl jamu" 'go
column17: will you' (see EDT 934)."

REFERENCE: Lee 1958, 109. An interesting Eastern isogloss.
KW 119, Lee 1958, 108 (TM-Kor.), Rozycki 68. Despite Doerfer MT 20, TM *ele is hardly < Mong. (a particle in Mong. vs. a widespread verb in TM).
The etymology appears plausible despite poor attestation in TM.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss, but borrowing seems hardly feasible. Cf. *di̯ā́jgi. {? Cf. PE *ivica 'game-fish' ?}
The basic meaning of the root appears to be 'stupid', whence 'insincere' and 'proud, arrogant'.
One of the many Altaic Verba des Schlagens"."
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
The Turkic form may belong here if *-d is a result of dissimilation (*jɨd < *jɨj) or a suffix.
A common derivative *ǯebò-ĺV is reflected in Turkic and Mongolian.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.

A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss. There may be, however, some traces in Turkic as well: cf. Karakh. (MK, see EDT 891-892) jaδɨŋ suv 'water spreading over the surface of the ground', closely paralleling, e.g., Khalkha ʒadgaj usu 'pond, pool'. Cf. also the old name of the Ural river, PT *jadɨk, which is considered to be pre-Turkish (see EDT 981), but may be genuine. The attributive usage both in Turkic and Mongolian makes one wonder whether the root in fact is not a specialization of PA *ǯādV 'spread' q.v.

KW 388, Владимирцов 271, Poppe 13, 42, 47, Дыбо 15 (the root is frequently confused with *t`ébo q.v.). Mong. is hardly < Turk., despite Щербак 1997, 153 and, despite Doerfer's (TMN 2, 433) attempts at criticism.
The parallel seems plausible, with the semantic developments *'endure' > 'envy'; *'endure' > 'shun, abstain'.
The parallel appears plausible, with the semantics 'prevent' > 'interrupt' or 'prevent, be prevented from' > 'stay away from'.

SKE 38; Poppe 1950, 572, Lee 1958, 113, Menges 1984, 266, АПиПЯЯ 77; Дыбо 5, Martin 231, Miller 1985, 150, 1985a, 83, JOAL 99, Whitman 1985, 126, Лексика 276. The root is quite reliable, but not completely regular, probably due to contractions and assimilations (not quite clear is -i- in Mong. - on analogy with ǯirüke 'heart'? - and voicing of -k- in TM).

MEANING: door post, detail of a house
REFERENCE: The Turkic form raises some questions because it has actively merged with *jạjŋak 'cheek, jaw' < *zi̯ā̀ni q.v.
One of the common Altaic monosyllabic verbal roots; Mong. and Jpn. reflect suffixed forms.
A Kor.-Jpn. isogloss; Western parallels may have merged with *šŏ́mo 'to dive, scoop' q.v.
A Turk.-Jpn. isogloss. Cf. perhaps also Mong. segre- 'to be torn to pieces' (although delabialization is unexplainable).
A Western isogloss. If Sukhebaatar (212) is right in deriving the Mong. form < Tib. phye-mar `flour and butter', the existence of this Altaic root becomes rather dubious.
Cf. *kasa.
A Western isogloss.
A good Turk.-Mong.-Jpn. parallel.
Korean has a frequent vowel loss between *č`- and *-k-.
A Western. isogloss; borrowing in Mong. is possible, but not very probable for semantic reasons.
АПиПЯЯ 78.

A Western isogloss. It is interesting to note the Turkm. form sarGan, which may reflect an old derivative *sār-k`V 'maw, paunch and its products' (reflecting the role played by the maw, ventriculus in the filtering and fermenting process) : cf. PT *sarkɨńuk 'maw, paunch' (EDT 849-850, ЭСТЯ 7), WMong. sarkinaɣ 'ventriculus, second stomach' (L 676; possibly < Turkic); Evk. sargākte 'upper coverage of the stomach'. See also notes to *sark`V.

MEANING: a k. of small wild animal
REFERENCE: An expressive root; one of many common Altaic words for small animals.
A problematic case. The original meaning may be reconstructed as main direction" (whence "direction
column17: point of the compass" in Old Turkic and "main riverbed
column18: stem" in TM)
column21: Jpn. nusi may belong here only if -si is an original attributive suffix (*nu-si < *nuŋ-si). There is also a very similar root *ńi̯unŋe meaning 'direction
column23: with ample opportunity for contaminations - which in fact almost certainly occurred in TM."

REFERENCE: Cf. *si̯ằjrí.
A Western isogloss.
A secure common Altaic root.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
An expressive Tung.-Jpn. isogloss; like most words for 'round', not quite reliable.
Street 1985, 640. A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss.

Lee 1958, 113 (Tung.-Kor.). An Eastern isogloss. The Korean form is aberrant in several respects (-u- instead of expected -ɨ-, -t- instead of expected -r-, low tone instead of expected high), and one may suspect it in being borrowed < Japanese.
A Western isogloss. In Turkic one would rather expect -ɨ-, so the vocalism is not quite regular.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss. It resembles the 'silk' / 'China' ser-/sen-  Wanderwort, so it can actually go back to OC 纖 *sen (MC sjen) - but rendering MC -n with Kor. -r is extremely strange.
A Western isogloss.
A Western isogloss. Despite TMN 2, 137, Щербак 1997, 160, Mong. cannot be < Turk. (-uw- is unexplained this way).
The root should be distinguished from *dā́la 'wave, deep place', *čalu 'sea, to overflow' - although some contaminations were possible, especially in the Kor.-Jpn. area.

KW 470. A Western isogloss, but, despite Щербак 1997, 121-122, hardly a loanword in Mong. < Turkic (final -i of the Mong. form is unexplained). The Turkic form, however, due to a merger of *ǯ- and *d- can also reflect PA *dàli 'to roast, burn' (q.v.); cf. especially Kypch. jalgavuč 'frying pan' (ЭСТЯ 4, 13).
A Western isogloss. Despite Щербак 1997, 161, Mong. cannot be < Turkic (final -a stays unexplained). The Turkic form, because of a merger of *p`- and *0-, can also reflect PA *p`ŭ́li q.v.
A Western isogloss; Mong. may be < Turkic.

Martin 236. Basically a Kor.-Jpn. isogloss, and the precise reconstruction is not quite clear (if *-mp- is to be reconstructed, cf. Man. sampa 'crayfish, crab'?). From other languages one could link a quite isolated Turkish form semek 'fish' (used as a synonym for balɨq).
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss, and borrowing in Mong. < TM is not excluded (although the meanings differ); in Turkic cf. perhaps Chuv. śomga 'rainbow trout'.
Дыбо 323, Лексика 257. A Western isogloss.
The root is sparsely attested, but seems reliable {unless the Turkic forms are borrowed < Mong. abuɣa 'marshmallow' - q.v. sub *éba(-ku)}.

Lee 1958, 118, Poppe 1950, 580, Дыбо 10. Doerfer (TMN 2, 550-553), and similarly Щербак 1997, 157, regard the Mong. forms as borrowed < Turkic, where he derives all the above forms from *tul- 'abgesperrt sein' (a poorly attested reflexive form of the equally poorly attested *tu- 'absperren'): hardly acceptable. Since only the velar derivatives (in -kuk, -uk) are early attested in Turkic, it seems more plausible to regard forms like tulum / tulup as borrowed from Mongolian.
A Western isogloss. PM *komu-gal < *kamu-gal, with a frequent rounding before -u- in a polysyllabic form.
A Tung.-Mong. isogloss.
Cf. also potential forms in Mongolian languages: Ord. \I-ūn\i 'if it is possible to', Bur. -\Iūtaj\i 'going to'.
The vocalism is not quite secure due to assimilations; nevertheless the root seems well reconstructable.
A Western isogloss.
A Turk.-Kor. isogloss. Cf. also Nan. kiriske 'рюмка' (?) (ТМС 1, 398).
One of many common Altaic fish names; the precise sort of the fish denoted by the root is not quite clear.
ТМС 1, 613. A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.

MEANING: deep place, place far from the shore
RUSMEAN: глубокое место, место, далекое от берега
REFERENCE: The parallel seems plausible; the common meaning here may be formulated as a place (in the sea or river) distant from the shore". {PE *əkə- 'bay
column17: strait'}"

REFERENCE: -ằ- in MKor. is probably a result of assimilation ( < *kòńằm). Vovin 1993 compares MKor. kằńằm 'material, cloth' with Jpn. *kìnú, on which see rather {*k`i̯ùńí}; see also Robbeets 2000, 109.
A Turko-Mong. isogloss.

MEANING: to reach, arrive at, stay at
REFERENCE: Lee 1958, 107. An Eastern isogloss.
The root is well attested in TM, but other parallels are somewhat questionable: the Turkic word is attested late and may be derived from *Koĺ- 'join, unite'; on the Korean word see above.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Manchu baša 'wife's younger sister' is isolated and most probably < Mong. (see ТМС 78, Rozycki 26).
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss. Cf. *kúĺap`V.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
A good common Altaic root.
The TM form can be compared with Mong. and Kor. if it is a contraction  of a suffixed form *t`at`V-gV-. On a possible Japanese reflex see under *č`àro.
Turkic forms are usually derived < Mong. irɣaj id., but the direction of borrowing may be opposite; however, Yak. ɨarɣa is certainly < Mong.
An Eastern isogloss.

ТМС 2, 302. The root is not preserved in Turkic - but cf. perhaps the isolated Yak. buka barɨ 'all together', buka 'perhaps', buka-tɨn 'completely' (Dolg. buka 'exactly', bukatɨn 'completely', see Stachowski 64).
Lee 1958, 113. A Tung.-Kor. isogloss. Because of the MKor. form a reconstruction *ǯajk`V is also possible.

MEANING: a k. of insect or worm
REFERENCE: A common derivative *dile-kV (-k`V) is reflected in Mong. *dele-g- and TM *dilu-kē.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.

Ozawa 312-313, ТМС 1, 43. An interesting common Altaic cultural term. The TM forms could be < Mong. (see Rozycki 19), but the absence of -su(n) (universally present in the Mong. form) suggests rather their genuine nature.
A Western isogloss.
If the original meaning is 'a castrated animal' (as in TM), the stem may be a derivative of PA *k`ắka 'to break, tear off' q.v.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.

KW 123, Владимирцов 324, Poppe 79, 106, Цинциус 1972a, 45-49, ОСНЯ 1, 247, АПиПЯЯ 54, 283. A well known Turk.-Mong. isogloss. Borrowing in Mong. from Turk. (see TMN 2, 179, Щербак 1997, 115) is quite improbable because of the final vowel. Cf. *i̯òre.
SKE 47. It is worth noting that the Korean word also means 'sesame' or 'anise' (in compounds, see KED 1570, 1571): this may be in fact a merger with the reflex of PA *č`i̯umu 'seed, cone' (q.v.).
KW 73, Poppe 97, Дыбо 306, Лексика 147; TMN 4, 106 (...unklar"). The root seems to be distinct from *dḗlì (*dḗjlì) q.v."

Basically a Turk.-Kor. isogloss; the Mongolian form is poorly attested and may be borrowed < Turkic. In TM cf. perhaps Evk. kelpeke 'children's winter clothes', kelkē 'children's winter footwear' (ТМС 1, 446).
An Eastern isogloss; cf. notes to *si̯ŭ̀ŕi, *ši̯ŭŕu. In Korean we would rather expect *-ă- or *-u-/-o-; -ɨ- may be a result of vowel assimilation.
A Tung.-Kor. isogloss (but cf. notes to *zi̯ognV).
It is also tempting to compare PJ *tùnuá 'horn'.
Дыбо 1997a (Turk.-Mong.)
Владимирцов 210. A Western isogloss.
A Western isogloss. One should also mention seŋgesn 'drinking vessel' (KW 410), either an old variant or a modified Turkic loanword.
JOAL 147. An interesting Turkic-Jpn. isogloss.
VEWT 27, KW 18. A Turko-Mongolian isogloss; in Turkic the root has partially merged with PT *ārt 'back' (see sub *p`i̯ṑrí).
A Turko-Mongolian isogloss.
A Western isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
A Mong.-Jpn. isogloss.
Цинциус 1984, 110-111, АПиПЯЯ 11, 286.  A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
SKE 35. A Turco-Korean isogloss; cf. perhaps Evk. tapčikākti, teptekēkti, topčikakta 'name of a weed' (ТМС 2, 164).
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
Mong. and TM reflect a common derivative *gi̯àru-k`V.

EAS 93, Владимирцов 321, АПиПЯЯ 284.  Mong. *(h)ekire 'twins' = PT *ẹkiŕ (ЭСТЯ 1, 252-254) (although it is frequently regarded as borrowed from Turk., see TMN 2, 190-191, Щербак 1997, 119-120, Rozycki 115, this is hardly the case; borrowed is Mong. ikes 'placenta', see Clark 1980, 39). A different etymology of the Japanese word (: MKor. pask) see Martin 238.   Kor. has a usual verbal low tone. {Cf. Amer. *pok 'two, second' (R 798)}
A Turk.-Tung. isogloss.
Cf. perhaps also Mong. to-sun `melted fat' ( < *tod-su-n ?).
KW 416. A Turko-Mong. isogloss; in TM cf. perhaps Neg. tojkụ 'death', tojkụw- `to become ill (unexpectedly)'.
Martin 233, АПиПЯЯ 279. An Eastern isogloss; Korean has a usual verbal low tone.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss; see also notes to *ki̯ā́du.
A Western isogloss.
A Western isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A Tung.-Jpn. isogloss.
SKE 184. See also notes to *bi̯ura `abandon'.
A Tung.-Jap. isogloss.

MEANING: to be submerged; to pour out
REFERENCE: Ewk. kudu, kuduk 'saline; spring with salted water; well, spring' is semantically distant from the other forms and very probably borrowed from Mong. (but not from Mong. quǯir, despite Doerfer MT 104, but rather from quduɣ 'well' - itself borrowed from Turkic, see above). One can mention Mong. küdese- 'to swim (of a snake)', but both the vocalism and the meaning seem to be somewhat aberrant.
Despite ТМС 283, the TM form has nothing to do with Mong. ǯöbken 'only'.

SKE 34. A Kor.-Jap. isogloss, with Kor. -ph- < *-bV-k- and usual verbal low tone. In TM cf. perhaps Ewk. tūwkē 'stick in a cross-bow' (cf. the Kor. form), Ulch. tuj-ǯe- 'to make ready a cross-bow', possibly pointing to PTM *tub(i)- 'stick in a cross-bow'.
A Tung.-Jap. isogloss.
A Mong.-Tung. isogloss.
A Turk.-Mong. isogloss.

In Jap. cf. also sirus- 'to denote, mark', sirusi 'sign' (with high tone); the tonal reconstruction is not clear, because in Jap. the root is actively contaminating with *sìrà(m)pa- 'to tune, play music' and *sír- 'to know'.}
